narrative: On June 29, 2023, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a Pre-Licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicants Akua Birago and Kwame Appiah led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. Applicants are applying for a capacity of 4 ambulatory clients. The home consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with a full bed and a crib. It will sleep two residents - vacant. There were also a family room, a living room, formal dining area, a kitchen, a storage and one bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, The room consisted of a queen bed. It sleeps biological daughter, aged 19 years. Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with a queen bed. It sleeps biological son aged 20 years. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with a twin bed and a toddler bed. It will sleep two residents. Bedroom #5, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one king sized bed. It sleeps the applicants/Licensees. There was also a big loft well furnished, where children can play and a den, furnished and used as office. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in the closet upstairs by the entrance of the bathroom area. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked upper kitchen cabinet. There were no guns or weapons as stated by applicants at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 112 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items, and it was in the kitchen cabinet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request to be licensed for small family home will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicants.

In regard to the allegation that foster parents were not meeting FC1's diapering needs, it was specifically reported that FC1 was coming to school soaked in urine and feces and it was requested that the foster parents to provide larger diapers, however, foster mother was defensive. During investigation, confidential interview reported that FC1's diapers were not too small, however, FC1 takes bowel movement medication in the morning which may resulted in FC1 having loose stools while arriving at the school. The confidential interviews continued stating that the foster parents provided larger diapers brought from the store while pending larger diaper approval. An additional interview believe FC1 was receiving an appropriate care while at the SFH. LPAs were not able to obtain additional information due to FC1 limited verbal communication. Regarding foster parent not meeting FC1's medical needs allegation, it was reported that FC1 was crying profusely, drooling, and it was evident FC1 was in extreme pain. Additionally, it was reported that foster parents didn't take FC1 to the doctors when advised. Confidential interviews indicated that when FC1 came from school, FC1 didn't show any sign of pains or anything needing a medical attention. The confidential interview stated that FC1 was taken to the doctor after the school called Child Protective Services (CPS) and the doctor confirmed that FC1 didn't need immediate medical attention. LPAs were not able to obtain additional information due to FC1 limited verbal communication. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that foster parents were not meeting FC1's diapering needs and foster parents were not meeting foster child's medical needs may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights were reviewed and provided to the facility representative

On June 23rd, 2025, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Aguilera arrived at Birago Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct an unannounced annual licensing inspection. The Facility was toured both inside and out with Licensee Akua Birago. The home is a single-story family home with four bedrooms and two bathrooms. Upon entry of the home, LPA observed an open floor plan with office/play area, living room, dining area, and kitchen. The office/play area consisted of toys, books, and games. The living room consisted of two couches, television, and toys. The dining room consisted of a table with chairs. In addition, two stools were observed to be available in the kitchen island. The kitchen was fully inspected. All sharps/knives were locked and stored in a kitchen cabinet. The fire extinguisher was observed to be operable and located in the kitchen. LPA also observed a trash can in the kitchen that contained a tight-fitting cover. Through the hallway the laundry room was located and fully inspected, all detergents and cleaners are locked and made inaccessible to clients. A hallway closet was also observed and stores supplies for the client as well as the first aid kit. In addition, two medications boxes with locks were observed to be available for future medications. Bathroom #1 was inspected and fully functioning. Bedroom #1 consisted of two twin beds, closet, and dresser this bedroom sleeps licensee's adoptive son. Bedroom #2 always remains locked and sleeps licensee's adult brother. Bedroom #3 consisted of a crib and a play pen, closet, and a dresser; this bedroom is occupied by 3-year-old client.Bedroom #4 sleeps licensee and spouse always remains locked. Licensee's bedroom also included bathroom #2. The garage was also inspected and observed to be utilized for storage and one vehicle. The water temperature was tested and measured at 117.7 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. All windows and screens were in good repair. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. The following required posted items were observed accessible: personal rights, visitation policy, and emergency numbers. The backyard was also fully inspected, no hazards or obstructions were observed. There were four cameras in the outdoor of the home, which meet the Title 22 camera policy. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

On March 14th, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Bless KJC Small Family Home for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Nina Magee who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. The applicant is applying to serve a capacity of two ambulatory children ages 0-17 years old. The home is a two- story building with 3 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The downstairs consists of a living room with couches, a den with couches, TV, and a fire place that was properly screened. There was a kitchen with a table, fully stocked pantry and refrigerator with perishable and non perishable foods. Fire extinguisher #1 was located on the kitchen counter along with first ad kit that had all required elements. There was also a dining room with a table and adequate seating. There was an office that would store clients files but was missing the a lock on the cabinet drawer. The downstairs bathroom was fully functioning with water temperature reaching 120 degrees Fahrenheit. Applicant was advised that water temperature was at its maximum heat level. The upstairs had bedroom #1 that would be utilized for clients and had two twin size beds with the proper bedding, storage space, lighting, books, and games. There was a door leading to a balcony but applicant was advised to keep it double locked at all times. There was bedroom #2 that was for applicants biological son and was fully furnished with a full size bed. The laundry room was accessible to clients and had laundry detergent and cleaning supplies stored in a cabinet that was not made inaccessible to clients. Fire extinguisher #2 was also located in the laundry room. There was bathroom #2 that had dual sinks, toilet, and shower/tub. The bathroom drawers stored towels but trash cans needed tight fitting lids. The hallway had extra blankets and linen. There was a movie room that had couches, television, and games. Bedroom #3 was the master bedroom for applicant and had a queen size bed and bathroom #3 that was fully functioning with a bathtub and walk in shower. The applicant was advised to keep master bedroom locked at all times and supervise clients when in master bedroom. The garage was a three car garage that stored parked cars, extra household items, and bikes. The backyard was fenced with a side gate having a latch and was free of hazards. There was no pool or other body of water. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. There was no firearms in the home as stated by Ms. Magee at this time. The applicant understands that a telephone land line is needed in the home. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, Personal Rights and Visitation Policy were posted at this time. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: - Obtain trash cans with tight fitting lids - Obtain a telephone land line service. - Obtain a lock for cabinet storing laundry detergent and cleaning supplies. - lock box for refrigerated medication. After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so another inspection can be completed. Component III orientation was also completed this day of March 14, 2025. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Nina Magee.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted a Component III meeting with Applicant/Administrator Krishand Pearson. During the meeting the LPA covered a category specific to continuing requirement regulation review for Small Family Home program (SFH), with an emphasis on the facility operation and commonly found problem areas. This meeting provides the soon-to-be licensee with sufficient information to operate the facility within substantial compliance, as well as how to avoid common problem areas or pitfalls of a facility operation. It also provides a clear description of the LPA's role in the operation of the facility and provides a clear description of Civil Penalties. The following items were discussed and provided to the applicant: -Title 22 regulations on Small Family Homes - Continuing Requirements (General Licensing Requirements) - Buildings and Grounds requirements - Personnel Records (forms) - Client Records (forms) -Reporting Requirements -Health Related Services -Food Services -Deficiency Types -Civil penalties -PINs Notices - Other administrative forms An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report LIC809 and a copy of the Small Family Home (SFH) Component III handout was provided.

On 12/26/2024 at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Tira Logan-Shanks conducted a Component II - Face to Face Meeting at the Monterey Park Regional Office via Teams. The following were present Beatrice Mausah and Wilson Wamagatta, applicants. LPA and LPM discussed their application and program description and advised them of the following corrections. The following information must be completed and submitted to Licensing: Fingerprints are done and pending in Guardian. Section A LIC Hours of operations need to be completed, mark source of water on the application. LIC Applicants groceries are only $200 shown, applicant will revise. LIC 610C Emergency Disaster Plan for Children's Residential Correct spelling for the water hose (not horse), list available staff phone numbers and emails, add positions responsible and put TBD. LIC Facility Sketch. Needs to identify ambulatory vs non-ambulatory rooms, how many clients in each room, show all the emergency exits on the sketch including the balcony one, show utility shut of outside. Pool is located on the premises of gated community and the applicant will need to get a water safety certificate. Fire clearance - pending. Section B Adjust the capacity to 3 from 6. Elaborate more on the reporting requirements, licensee's duties and responsibilities and application of the Reasonable and Prudent Parent standard. Continue Page Page How the results of the services will be measured (developmental milestones, educational progress etc.) Discipline policies Please elaborate how the children and their representatives will be informed of the discipline policies in writing. Physical restraints are mentioned in your statements, but they are not allowed in the SFH. Please amend. Provide provisions for contacting the Law Enforcement in the case verbal de-escalation techniques are not working. Admission/Intake How will the clients and representatives will be notified if the home cannot meet their needs? Attach admission agreement or will you be using the Regional Center Admission agreement? Who will be signing the agreement? Emergency removal or dismissal How will the representative be notified; the timeline and that emergency removal will not occur without the representative being notified. Continue on page Page Allowance and safeguard for cash resources. Please provide the information on the children's allowance and how and when it will be distributed. And what the allowance will be spend for and how will the licensee ensure the proper records of the money received and money spend by the child. Clothing and hygiene provided and age and culturally appropriate. Needs and Services Plan (NSP) Who will participate in creating NSP, will it be based of Regional Center IPP? How often it will be updated? Provide what NSP will contain and if it is Regional Center will it be based on their IPP? Steps if NSP not provided to the licensee. Who will sign the NSP once it is created. Medical/Dental Insurance utilized and who is responsible for emergency medical treatment? Consent for the emergency medical treatment and who is notified in the case of emergency. Who is responsible if the medical expense is not covered by the insurance? Consent for emergency treatment. Medication administration procedures. Psychotropic medications procedures and regular medication procedures, how the record will be maintained and what forms will be used (LIC A (MAR) and LIC622B (PMAR)). Self-administration medication/injections procedures and what staff will be responsible, refusal procedures documentation. Continue on page Page Children's records What will be in the records, who will be responsible for updating and maintaining children's records. Personal Rights/ Personal Rights of Children with Special health care needs. How will the children and their representatives will be informed of the personal rights (forms)? What form will be used (LIC613B), elaborate more on the personal rights of the children with special health care needs (83072.2). Corporal punishment will not be allowed. Bedroom sharing Please include bedroom sharing policies. Transportation Who will provide the transportation? How vehicle will be maintained to ensure safe operation? How will ensure the vehicle is utilizing proper and age applicable restraint systems, no smoking in the vehicle either children present or not. Visitation rules and policies Who will be visiting, visiting hours and when visits not permitted. Visitation rules and times. Continue on page Page House rules Curfew times and quiet times. Chores and other assignments age appropriate and applying prudent parent standards. Cameras Will facility be utilizing cameras? Licensee will go over the PIN 24-09-CRP to review the guidelines. A signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant. Exit interview conducted.

met_with: Beatrice Mausah, Licensee Wilson Wamagatta, Licensee
narrative: On 01/31/2025 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. LPAs met with Beatrice Mausah and Wilson Wamagata, Licensees. LPA Maico conducted a physical plant inspection inside and outside the home alongside with the applicants. The following were observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a tri-level home located in a gated community residential neighborhood. The facility consists of 4 bedrooms, 3 full bathrooms,one half bathroom, a living room, kitchen, dining room, 2-car garage, laundry closet. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in good condition. The facility has a community pool located approximately 1000 feet from the home. The pool has a gate opening away from the pool and is over 5 feet tall fence. The fence is not obstructing the pool view, it has live plants on one side of the fence. LPA advised for the licensee to put the facility sketch next to the emergency plan and mark the emergency exits. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures in all rooms are maintained at 69 degrees (F). The hot water temperature was measured at 107.5 degrees (F). Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The fire extinguisher located on each floor of the home. The utility shut offs and emergency exits match the emergency disaster plan. Knives and sharps were observed on the kitchen table, licensee will get a lockbox for the sharps. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in the cabinet located under the sink in the kitchen, as well as in the bathrooms, and are locked. The facility has a working cell phone. The applicant reports no firearms on the premises as well as no poisons and pesticides. The grounds are free from obstructions and hazards. Facility will be licensed for 3 clients, 2 ambulatory and 1 non-ambulatory. Bedroom #1 downstairs has a full size bed with comfortable mattress, bedding, pillows. It also has closet space and drawers attached to the bed. Bedroom #1 has bathroom with sink, toilet and shower, toiletries. Bedroom #2 has bassinet and a queen size bed with adequate bedding and a table. It has a closet and laundry hamper. Bedroom # 3 has a full bed and and drawers for storage, as well as laundry basket in the closet. Bedroom is a master bedroom and has king size bed, walking closet, ottoman full of extra linens and bedding. Bedroom downstairs will be used by the non-ambulatory clients,, upstairs bedrooms will be used by ambulatory clients. LPA observed bathrooms to be in good repair and working order. Bathroom in the bedroom # 1 has 1 sink, shower with the shower curtain and a toilet. Bathroom # 2 located on the second floor has has a sink and a toilet. The third bathroom is on the 3rd floor and has shower and a bathtub, toilet and sink. Master bedroom (#4) has 2 sinks, shower. Individual beds are observed to be in good repair, equipped with good springs, clean mattresses and pillows, as well as appropriate clean linens in good repair. LPA also observed extra towels stored in the hallway closet. Medications will be centrally stored in the lockboxes in the kitchen cabinets. Snack cabinets had locks, licensee will remove it. Licensee will acquire first aid kit with the necessary items. Kitchen has a refrigerator, dishwasher, stove and adequate utensils and tableware to accommodate the number of clients. LPA observed the kitchen area to be clean and the refrigerator is clean. LPA observed snack fridge and cabinets in the kitchen. Licensee will post food menu in the kitchen. Dining room has a table with 6 chairs to accommodate clients and the living room has a couch with enough room for 3 clients. There are no cameras inside the home. The fire department clearance is pending. Before today's visit, the applicant submitted the final Program Statement/Plan of Operation to LPA Maico with requested amendments and corrections. LPA Maico will submit it for final review, and a new license will be mailed to the licensee upon approval. Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 80075(k)(1) - Licensee will get a lockbox for medication and will store in the kitchen above the fridge Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 80075(g) - First aid kit will be purchased by the licensee Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 80075(j)(1) - Licensee will get another lockbox and the fridge for the refrigerated medications in case medication needs to be refrigerated. Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 80088(e)(3) - Licensee will get non-slip rags for the bathtub and shower Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 83088(g)(1) - Bedrooms had plenty of closet space, drawers are in the bed frames Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 83088(f) - Toy room upstairs full of books, toys, puzzles Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 80087(b)(1) - Licensee will buy non-slip rags for the bathtub and showers Physical Plant - No Deficiency: 80087(c) - The non-ambulatory clients are able to enter through the garage and the front through the use of detachable railings Operational Requirements - No Deficiency: 80026(j) - Licensee will lock the cash resources in the office that will be moved upstairs Operational Requirements - No Deficiency: 80023(a) - The license and the casualty plan will be posted in the kitchen/living room area. During the pre-licensing a Component III was conducted on what to expect after licensing. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was provided to the applicant.

met_with: Beatrice Mausah, Licensee Wilson Wamagatta, Licensee

The signal system can be heard throughout the home. The pool has a tap key and opens away from the pool. The fence is on the concrete base (about 1,5 ft) and is about 5 ft tall ( about 6,5 ft in total height). Licensee obtained mini fridge for the medications that will need to be refrigerated and the lock boxes for the medications and knives. Lockboxes have keys or combination lock. Licensee has a first aid kit with all the necessary supplies and within the guidelines of the licensing requirements. The lock has been removed from the snack fridge. All bathrooms have non-slip rugs and the chemicals are all centrally locked on the third floor in the cabinet. LPA will submit all the paperwork for the approval once Guardian clearance is received.

Type B citation is issued. LPA did not observe water safety certificate for either licensee. Type B citation is issued. LPA interviewed the Licensee. Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Yesenia Vallejo met with Kevin Brock, Facility Administrator (FA) to conduct a Pre-Licensing inspection on 8/15/25. The facility will be licensed to care for 2 ambulatory children ages 6-17 years old. LPA inspected the facility inside and out. The facility is a one story family home and consists of 4 bedrooms and 2 full shared bathrooms. The home is open concept the kitchen has an open counter that oversees the living room. Laundry room is in the garage. In the backyard there is a locked shed used as FA office where client records will be kept. There is a hot tub in the backyard to which FA was instructed a cover is needed. The cover shall be strong enough to completely support the weight of an adult and shall be placed on the hot tub and locked. The room temperature was comfortable, and no odor was detected. On January 2, 2025 on 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Brookfield Developmental Home Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicants Matthew and Ayobukola Alabi who led a tour of the entire home. The applicants are applying for a capacity of six children ages 3-17 years old. The home is a one story building with 4 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. The home consists of an entry way with visitation/ sign in log, there is bedroom #1 that will be utilized as foster children's bedroom which is fully furnished with two twin size beds with storage space , 2 night stands, closet space and trash cans. Bedroom #2 will be utilized for other foster children and consists of two twin size beds with storage space , 2 night stands, closet space and trash cans. There is also bedroom #3 that will be utilized as foster children's bedroom and consists of two twin size beds with storage space , 2 night stands, closet space and trash cans. All three bedrooms will be utilized for foster children and are all currently vacant and have proper bedding essentials. There is a bathroom with fully functioning toilet, shower/bath, and sink with water temperature reaching 116.2 degrees F. There is a furnished living room with couch, television, home phone and games/books. There is a kitchen with fully stocked refrigerator and pantry, abundance of perishable and nonperishable foods, locked box full of sharp objects such as knives, forks, and scissors stored in pantry. There is a locked kitchen cabinet storing cleaning supplies, another cabinet storing first aid kit with all required elements and a locked cabinet storing client records, personnel records and cash resources . There is a dining room table with enough seating for foster children. There is a hallway across from kitchen that has personal rights, visitation policy, emergency disaster plan, menu, and weekly schedule posted on a bulletin board. The hallway also has a locked cabinet with house medication and a locked section for clients medication with a lock boxed that could be used for refrigerated medication and a fire extinguisher that is up to date. There is a master- bedroom with king size bed and bathroom for applicants that will be locked at all times. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children's belongings. The laundry room is open for foster children use with adult supervision but laundry detergent, laundry supplies, sanitizers and carpet cleaning substances are locked in cabinets. There is another fire extinguisher that is up to date located in laundry room as well. There is a storage closet that holds an abundance of linen, towels, extra pillows and hygiene supplies for multiple foster children. There is a garage that is free of hazards and debris that stores two deep freezers for meats and extra frozen foods, there is vacuum, broom and mop located there as well. The garage will be open for foster children to utilize for exercise, playing, or visitations as there is a television, stereo, and empty space for movement. The backyard is enclosed by a gate that has a side gate closed with a latch. There is a lounge seating area with shaded gazebo, a locked shed storing storage for housing such as decorations and extra home supplies. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. All trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms, there were no pools or other bodies of water, nor a fireplace in the home. There are no deficiencies observed at this time. Component III orientation was completed on November 14, 2024. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final review and approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicants Matthew and Ayobukola Alabi.

On March 4, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Deborah Lee arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Pre- licensing inspection for a Small Family Home License. LPA met with applicant, Jon Bujol who granted access into the home. The applicant and LPA toured the facility both inside and out. Currently residing in the home is applicant, his mother, and his two siblings . Applicant is requesting to be licensed for 2 clients ages 3-17 ambulatory only. The home is set up as follows: This is a one story house with 4 bedrooms, 3 bathrooms, Living Room, Dining area, kitchen, laundry/sitting room area, Garage converted to a Den. The home was inspected and the following was observed: The home was equipped with comfortable mattresses, clean lines, blankets, and pillows that are in good repair. The home is clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. Phone land line, electric and gas were in working condition. Living Room/Family Room: There is adequate furniture which appears to be in good condition. is equipped with mounted TV on the main wall, sectional sofa, electric fireplace below mounted TV and side wall there is an aquarium. The front door has a bar screen and wooden door. Alarms were tested during the inspection and they all appeared to be in working condition. Alarms are a combination smoke detector/carbon monoxide. investigation_findings: 13During the course of the complaint investigation, all pertinent parties were interviewed. The interviews produced corroborating evidence to support the allegation. A1 confirmed that she gave C1 the wrong medications but, as soon as she realized what she had done, told C1 to spit out the pills, but C1 didn't do it and he swallowed C2's pills plus his own pills. A1 contacted the poison control center and they told her to take C1 to the hospital to make sure he didn't have a reaction due to the high dose of Seroquel that A1 gave C1. C1 was placed under observation for approximately 5 hours with blood pressure and oxygen monitors. The Dr. told A1 that C1 had metabolized the drugs. A1 did not observe other adverse side effects. In addition, confidential interviews stated that they do not know the reason why A1 was administering the medication to C1 and C2 the day of the incident, when A2 is usually the one who does. SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On 12/23/2020, at 9:00am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced Tele-inspection to the Cabales Small Family Home to for the purpose of conducting a Case Management- Other. On March 19, 2021, at 11:15 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez, conducted an unannounced Case Management-Other inspection to the Cabales Small Family Home located at the above address. LPA met with the licensee and together toured the home in and out. Licensee is currently accepting consumers from Tri Counties Regional Center. The facility provides care and supervision to consumers with developmental disabilities, ages 2-17 years, ambulatory only. The house is a single-story family home in a residential neighborhood. It has four bedrooms, three bathrooms, a living room, a family room, a kitchen and a dining area. During the inspection the following was observed Inside the house Scissors on top of the sewing machine located in the den. A table located in the den with crafting materials, and a pair of scissors were on the table Craft materials on the dining table did not allow clients to sit . Kitchen • Chemicals (Ajax) dish soap on top of the kitchen sink accessible to consumers. • Butter knives soaking in water in the sink at clients reach. • Inside the refrigerator three rotten tomatoes • Steak knives on the counter by the kitchen sink accessible to clients • The lockbox for the cutting knifes was in the pantry without a lock accessible to consumers • Prescription medication for a consumer on top of the kitchen counter accessible to consumers Continue on LIC809-C Exterior Sharp Corrugated metal sheets in the backyard accessible to consumers Dog feces all over the yard Clutter all over the backyard table, pieces of wood,ladders, table chairs tires bricks, metal pipes, recycle cans, plastic cans The doors were not locked to the backyard that leads to the tool shed. Tool shed was unlock full of chemicals and sharp tools accessible for the consumers Garden tools displace throughout the backyard Backyard deck with a broken piece of wood Extension cord lying on the floor connected LPA Hernandez explained to the licensee about the importance of keeping the facility safe and healthy for all consumers in their care. The licensee stated that the knives in the kitchen sink were from last night's dinner and the reason they were next to the sink is because the dishwasher was full. The licensee stated that the scissors were there because she was working on Easter baskets. The licensee stated that the doors to the back patio were unlocked because her husband was the one who left them open. LPA told the licensee to remove all knives, scissors, and medication and to store them immediately so they would not be available to consumers. LPA Hernandez took photographs of all the deficiencies listed in this report. Based on today's inspection deficiencies were cited per California code of regulations Title 22 division 6. A civil penalty in the amount of $150 has been issued, due to Licensee did ensure the home to be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients. On January 11, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that minor sustained an unexplained fracture(s) while in care. During the investigation, there was no corroborating evidence to support the above allegation. Although the Department received information that the client sustained unexplained fractures while in care. The Investigator received inconsistent information that would indicate that the fractures of C1 were a result from abuse or neglect in care. Confidential interviews reported that the fractures observed on C1 can be a result from an existing medical condition and the application of a medical device used to meet C1's medical needs in care. Investigator Santana reviewed medical records and exams and the information was inconsistent in supporting abuse or neglect in care. Other confidential interviews reported that a combination of therapeutic regimens and the application of a medical device in care may or may not have contributed to the fractures to C1. There were no other known witnesses to the allegation and due to age and limit verbal communication C1 could not comment on whether the fractures were a result of abuse, neglect or if the allegation is untrue. Based on confidential interviews the allegation that minor sustained an unexplained fracture(s) while in care, may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with the appeal rights was provided to Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On May 8, 2024, 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Cynthia Urena met with Canopy Small Family Home (SMFH) Licensee Emma Jackson to deliver the investigative finding for the above stated allegation. On January 19, 2024, at 11: AM, Investigator Jose Santana with the Community Care Licensing Division Investigations Branch (IB) initiated the investigation at Canopy Small Family Home. Investigator Santana collected pertinent documents to assist with the investigation process. Interviews were conducted with two resource parents, four witness, a county staff member, and four medical professionals. Due to age and limited verbal communication Investigator Santana was unable to conduct an interview with a client involved therefore, no additional information regarding the allegation was obtained. Additionally, Investigator Santana conducted a comprehensive record review of medical reports, medical examinations, and a police report to further assist with the investigation process. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On June 19, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Canopy Small Family Home (SFH) for capacity increase. Applicant is applying for an increase to 4 clients, with one being non-ambulatory client. There is currently three clients in placement, ages 18 months, 5 years and 11 years old. The home was licensed to serve a capacity of three ambulatory disabled clients. The Facility was toured both inside and out with staff/spouse. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. During the inspection, LPA observed that the downstairs consisted of the kitchen, a living room, family room, the garage, a dining area with a large table and one bedroom. Bedroom #1 it was furnished with a full-size bed, a closet, drawer and a door to the outside with a ramp. It is currently vacant; it will sleep one non-ambulatory client. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet by the kitchen window. The garage was inspected and used for cars. The water temperature was tested and measured at 115 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients. In addition to the downstairs space, there was also two pantries and a cabinet used for storage in the bathroom. A trash can was observed to have tight fitting lid. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights, visitation policy, and current menu. The clients' medication log records were kept updated with no discrepancy. One fire extinguisher was observed and operable. The upstairs was a bedroom #2, it was fully furnished with two twin size beds, closet and lots of storage spaces; it sleeps one foster child. Bedroom #3 was fully furnished with two twin size beds, it sleeps biological son and a foster child, both boys aged 5 years old. Bedroom #4 was fully furnished with one twin bed and a crib, closet space, and lots of storage spaces. It sleeps an eighteen-month-old foster child. Bedroom #5, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one king sized bed. It sleeps the Licensee and spouse. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for each child's belongings. The medication was stored in a box upstairs by the loft. The first aid kit was store in the cabinet upstairs by the loft. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room and the garage. The upstairs space includes a loft a laundry room that always remained locked, an additional bathroom used for the clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee/spouse. There was a total of four cameras, all located outdoor which meet the title 22 camera policy. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Client's files and staff files were reviewed and found to comply. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Licensee.

On August 24, 2022 at 10:31am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez arrived unannounced at the facility to conduct an Annual Continuation inspection of the Required Annual inspection that began on 08/23/2022. LPA met with House Manager Ronald Almuete. During the inspection, LPA conducted staff file reviews. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the kitchen sink was measured at 111.4 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to the clients. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the medication closet in the hallway. On September 11, 2024, at 10:00 a.m., Children's Residential Program (CRP) Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Guadalupe Munoz, LPA Jacqueline Garcia, Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Ann Valenzuela, and Adult Senior Program LPM Alisa Ortiz met with CARE Small Family Home (SFH) Administrator, Michael Bradbury, Licensee's wife, Sarah Paul, and SFH House Manager, Ronald Almuete at the CRP Orange Local Office for an informal office conference. The purpose of the meeting was to discuss the following issues and concerns with the Licensee for CARE SFH regarding Title Continuing Care Requirements Section 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status and Health and Safety Code (HSC) Section 1522(c)(1) Administration. On 8/26/ Community Care Licensing (CCL) conducted an unannounced random annual inspection and cited the SFH for allowing a 25 year old client to live at the facility. Upon file review CCL determined that all clients in placement were over the age of 18 years. Licensee reported that they have had multiple plans in the past regarding oldest client because they have been in placement since age of 10 years. Primary original plan was to change the home to an Adult Residential Facility to accommodate the client's needs. The clients have been in placement and the Licensee stated, "it's their community". However, Licensee has now decided against this plan for the SFH. The plan discussed at today's meeting includes another property owned by the Licensee. The additional property will be converted into an Adult Residential Facility. LPM Ortiz discussed the importance of submitting an application as soon as possible to initiate the licensing process. Continued on page LPM Ortiz also stated that they would communicate with the application unit, the urgency of the current situation of getting the SFH into compliance. The Adult Senior Care Unit will assist with contacting the Application Unit to expedite the process and communicate with Regional Center regarding the vendorization process. All clients over the age of 22 will be moved to new Adult Residential Facility once it is licensed and vendorized, and Licensee will submit new application and update the program statement to included clients ages 18 years of age through 22 years old to allow clients to remain in care up until their 23rd birthday. On 9/11/24 the following plan was developed: · Licensee will submit Adult Residential Facility application no later than 9/27/24. If they need additional time, they will contact LPA Munoz via email to request the additional time needed to submit application. · Home identified for Adult Residential Facility currently has a tenant living in it. They need to move out (family friend in the home) prior to Prelicensing. · AR Certificate has been completed for new home administrator. · Program Statement will be completed within the next two weeks. · LPA Munoz will communicate will Licensee weekly. The plan of correction is due to CCL by 9/27/24. If more time is needed to submit the plan of action or there are any questions, please contact LPA Guadalupe Munoz at guadalupe.munoz@dss.ca.gov or (949) 701-3475. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Licensee. The signed report will be placed in the facility file.

On August 13, 2025, at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lanice White arrived at Caring Hands Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA was met by Applicant, Rachael Grate-Tyson, who granted access to the home a health and safety assessment was conducted. The residence is set up as follows: This is a single-story 3-bedroom, 1 bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining area, kitchen, laundry room, backyard, and a detached garage. Living room: is equipped with a two-piece sofa set, covered fireplace, mounted TV, and towards the hallway is the welcome board under the table is the file cabinet for client and personnel files. Dining area: is equipped with a wooden table and four (4) chairs. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a five (5) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational at the time of this inspection), a microwave. Sharps and knives are kept in locked kitchen drawers. Cleaning supplies are kept locked in the cabinet underneath the kitchen Laundry room: is located off the kitchen and is equipped with a washer, dryer, and storage shelves. Medication storage (lock box) is located next to the storage area in the laundry Cleaning supplies and laundry detergent are kept locked in the brown closet. (Continued see 809-C page 2) (page 2) Backyard: is equipped with an outdoor kitchen (1) sink, small refrigerator, and barbecue pit and a one (1) TV mounted. Detached garage: LPA observed the garage to be used for extra storage. Bedroom #1: Is used as the licensee grandchildren's room. The room is equipped with a bunk bed with dressers attached at the bottom, a chair, two (2) bean bag chairs, a mounted TV, and has two (2) windows, one (1) cabinet with storage cubes, and closet. Bedroom #2: is occupied by the Applicant. The room is equipped a king-size bed, two (1) dressers, one (1) night stands, working lights, one (1) walk-in closet, ceiling fan, and mounted TV. Bedroom #3: Will be occupied by the clients. The room is equipped with twin beds with gray bedding sets, two (1) dressers, a mounted TV, (2) small drawers, (2) lamp, 2 clothes hampers, and has (1) windows. The room contains a working ceiling light/fan and a closet. Bathroom #1: is located along the hallway past the linen closet. The bathroom is equipped with a toilet, a sink, and a combination shower/tub. The hot water was tested and found to be 125-140 degrees (F). LPA observed the home to have a fully charged two (2) fire extinguishers, a complete First Aid Kit, and a lock box to store refrigerated medications. The homes hallway cabinets store extra linen and hygiene products. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Extra disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons in the home. There are no animals on site. (Continued see 809-C page 3) Vehicle: Applicant will transport children in 2020, Volv. The monitor for the cameras is located in the kitchen. Camera 1.) mounted on the drive way facing the house Camera 2) mounted on the on the car port facing the detached garage Camera 3) mounted on back of the house on the left side Camera 4) mounted on back of the house on the right side Camera 5) mounted on the west back corner of the house Camera 6) mounted on the west front side of the house Camera 7) Front door ring camera Prior to being licensed the following is required: - Water temperature is reading 125-140 degrees. Licensee is having a plumber come out today 8/13/2025 lower the water temperature. - No sign was posted stating the water temperature is over 125 degrees. -Licensee will notify LPA Lanice White on Friday 8/15/2025, regarding hot water corrections. On September 6, 2023 at 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began a pre-licensing inspection for Carr Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Erica Carr who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there is no client in the home. The applicant is applying to serve 3 client ages 3 to 17. The home is a one story building with five bedrooms and two bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom # 1 (Master) has one bed sleeps the applicant and has a master bathroom. · Bedroom # 2 (bio children) two twin beds, it sleeps two bio children. · Bedroom # 3 (Client's) was vacant has one full bed, it will sleep one client. · Bedroom # 4 (client's) was vacant has one full bed, it will sleep one client. · Bedroom # 5 (client's) was vacant has one full bed and will sleep one client · A great room/living room, sitting room, kitchen, dining area, two bathrooms, an attached two car garage, and the backyard. The Client's bedroom was arranged so that no more than one client will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client's belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The five smoke detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The Carbon Monoxide detector is located in the hallway and was working properly. There is a dedicated phone line. The home's central air conditioning module was located in the back yard. The home's hot water heater was located inside the garage. The appliances were in working order. . The client's files will be locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. There was adequate food storage space. There was a two day supply of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid. The sharp knives are in a locked kitchen cabinet. The medications are located in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The hot water in bathroom one (master) measured to be 120 degrees Fahrenheit and in bathroom two 113.5 degrees Fahrenheit. The home's First Aid kit was accessible and is located in the closet in the hallway. Two fire extinguishers are present in the home one is located on the wall by the kitchen the second is located on the wall in the hallway. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There is no firearm in the home as stated by the applicant. There is no pool or other body of water. The backyard where clients will have access to play was fenced. There are no deficiencies at this time. The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights was provided to Applicant Erica Carr.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward held an office meeting with applicant Ruth Barker. The purpose of the meeting was obtain or emend documents where necessary. Mrs Barker was provided with the format to complete the Program Statement and asked to resubmit the program statement along with all other requested documents. Mrs. Barker was asked to submit the updated documents and program statement by August 31, 2022.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Miss Ruth Barker to evaluate the home for licensure as a Small Family Home Facility. The home is currently certified as a resource family home with the Los Angeles County Department of Children and Family Services. There are currently two children in placement under the DCFS certification. Miss Barker also has a minor daughter that lives in the home. This is 4 bedroom, 2.5 bathroom single story home located in the City of Gardena, CA. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no firearms on the premises. There is a gated fireplace in the living room and an electric fireplace in the applicant's bedroom. There is a large fish tank in the living room. LPA Jones-Steward observed a complete first aid kit. Knives and household cleaners were safely stored. There was a locked storage box for medication storage. Refrigerator and kitchen stove were in working condition. The food supply met Title 22 requirements. LPA observed a pet Shih-tzu dog in the home. Applicant produced records of his vaccinations. LPA observed working smoke detectors, carbon monoxide detectors and a fully charged fire extinguisher in the home. Security bars were found to be working. However the releases were blocked by furniture. LPA observed that the hot water faucet in the client's bathroom was not working. Applicant was advised to do the following in order to qualify for licensure. 1. Remove trash bags from backyard and make sure that trash cans remain closed and don't overflow. 2. Have hot water faucet in client's bathroom repaired 3. Re-arrange beds in bedroom #1 and #2 so that they do not block security bar releases. LPA will return to the home within two weeks to verify corrections.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward made a return visit to the facility to verify that the needed corrections were made pre licensure. LPA observed that the bedroom furniture was re-arranged so that it no longer blocks security bar releases. The security bar releases were found to be working, LPA observed that the hot water faucet in the children's bathroom is now working and dispenses hot water at a safe temperature. In the backyard, LPA observed that the trash cans are no longer overflowing. At this point the home meets the physical plant requirements to be licensed as a small family home.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie -Jones-Steward and Licensing Program Analyst Lakescia Smith met with applicant Ruth Barker to discuss items that need to be addressed in her application. LIC 503 - have the health questionnaire signed by a licensed physician, Program Statement & Plan of Operation - update the highlighted areas with more detailed information; remove all references to adult care. On May 21, 2024, at 1: P.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mary Shelton made an announced pre-licensing inspection at the home and met with Catherine Mwangi, Catherine Small Family home the Licensee, who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA inspected the facility's interior and exterior building and grounds. The facility is comprised of three bedrooms, two upstairs bedrooms and one downstairs bedroom and two bathrooms. The licensee can provide bedroom accommodations to meet the requirements related to the license capacity and client special health needs. At this time, there are no clients in care, however pending placement of a client into the facility, the licensee is prepared to provide care and has the following maintained at the facility: secure location and process for locking and maintaining medication in a centrally stored location; maintaining a separate client records for each client to ensure the confidentiality of the records maintained and a locked and secure location for cash resources to be entrusted to Licensee The facility has no swimming pool or bodies of water on the property, and no use of security recording cameras in private areas. The facility was observed to be clean, sanitary, and in good repair; and no deficiencies were observed. There are no firearms at the home. There is a fire pull alarm located on the second floor of the home. There is a fire extinguisher located in the kitchen. The home has telephone services accessible to clients in care. continued 809-C. LPA reviewed the Licensee's personnel record, and documentation pertaining to criminal record clearance, mandated reporter statement, and current (LVN) Nursing License and CPR and First Aid Certification. The Licensee is still working on changes needed to complete the Program Statement and will let LPA know when they are completed. LPA conducted an interview with the licensee and provided the following information and resources pertaining to: Fingerprint clearances/Guardian, LPA inspections, citation/advisory note process, civil penalty types, CARE tools, CDSS forms and how to find them, exceptions and waivers, PINs, reporting requirements, inspection authority, POCs, extensions on POC due dates, personal rights, updates to the Program Statement, and Small Family Home specific regulations; Technical Support Program, and the following websites:https://www.cdss.ca.gov/inforesources/childrens-residential/resources-for-provider, https://cdss.ca.gov/inforesources/community-care-licensing/subscribe, https://www.cdss.ca.gov/inforesources/cdss-programs/community-care-licensing/caregiver-background-check/guardian and https://www.cdss.ca.gov/inforesources/forms-brochures/forms-alphabetic-list/i-l On 5/21/2024, the facility was advised that the home is not ready to be licensed until corrections are made to the Program Statement. The Licensee will keep in communication about placement of clients into the facility and will submit required documentation to the Department as required, including Incident Reports and LIC 500, Employee Rosters after the license is issued. An exit interview was conducted with Catherine Mwangi, and a copy of this report was provided to them.

On 06/24/2025, at 01:10PM, Licensing Program Analyst, (LPA) Connie Goldie made an unannounced visit to conduct an Annual/Required inspection. LPA was greeted at the door by Administrator, Catherine Mwangi, who assisted LPA with the inspection. Administrator stated the client is present at the home. At 01: PM, LPA conducted a physical plant tour. At the front door entry, LPA observed a spacious living room area and formal dining room with adequate seating for client, staff and guests. The license and menu are posted in the kitchen area. LPA observed two fire extinguishers in the home that were in compliance. LPA observed kitchen/nook area to have adequate perishable and non-perishable food available as required. Water temperature measured at 115.1 degrees Fahrenheit in kitchen. The family room is an additional space for activities available to youth. A youth bedroom was observed to have adequate storage, linen as required and decor chosen by youth. A bathroom is adjacent to this bedroom and soap, towels and hygiene are available. LPA tested the carbon monoxide/ fire detectors which were in operative order. Four bedrooms were observed upstairs, two of which are for clients, with good lighting available. LPA observed a linen closet in the hallway upstairs. The home was a comfortable 71 degrees. The garage area has a washer and dryer in working order and an additional refrigerator. There are two bathrooms, which have trash cans with lids, and the water temperatures recorded at 109.1 degrees, within compliant range of 105-120 degrees. Soap and paper products were readily available. First aid kit is complete. Medications and sharps were secured as required. Cash resources are secured in the master bedroom. The back yard contained a locked shed with assorted items. A ping pong table, seating area and barbecue were available. LPA observed the crawl space area adjacent to the ramp on the left side of house to have a 1 foot by 1 foot circular hole which requires repair. Continued on LIC809C All Care tool domains completed during today's inspection which include: Physical Plant, Operations, Staff records, Client Records and Special Health Care Needs. LPA Goldie interviewed one staff member and one client. Five Title 22 deficiencies were cited during inspection. See LIC809D attached. Three technical violations were issued. These are not deficiencies. The annual inspection is complete. Exit interview conducted at 05: PM and reports along with appeal rights were discussed and provided to facility.

LPA asked about other potential employees S3 and S4. Administrator explained that those adults were potential employees but were not hired and never worked in the facility. LPA talked with Administrator regarding the previous complaint investigation that happened against the facility. LPA observed that S1 was not cleared on Guardian. Administrator explained that they believe S1 has the proper clearance from Guardian and that all the proper paperwork was submitted, but could not produce any paperwork to prove it. A Deficiency and Citation were administered and recorded on 809-D. Exit Interview was conducted with Administrator and a copy of this report and appeal rights were given to the Administrator.

LPA and Administrator discussed staff training requirements, First Aid requirements, Staff criminal record clearance, Law Enforcement investigations, & facility vehicles. No deficiencies cited. LPA informed Licensee of purpose of inspection. No residents are in placement on the date of inspection. During investigation, LPA Mariah Hawkins conducted a walk-thru of the home, interviews with Licensee, Social Worker, and reviewed of client files. Therefore, the allegation is Unsubstantiated. narrative: On 11/05/21 at 11:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Patricia Cooper and informed of the purpose of visit. LPA used the CARE Inspection Tool to conduct the inspection. The facility has maintained compliance and is in good condition. The following were observed: (1) Child C1's (See LIC Confidential Names) file did not include a TB test result. Licensee stated that an appointment would be scheduled. LPA issued a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Client Medical Assessment. LPA also advises that Licensee have the physician complete LIC 602. (2) Child C1 did not have a personal rights form signed by the authorized representative (social worker / Regional Center case manager). LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Personal Rights, that Licensee send this to be signed by social worker. (3) Staff temporarily not working in the facility for 1 year or longer due to COVID-19, but which Licensee intends to have return to work, do not have current first aid certificates on file. LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Health Related Services, that Licensee ensure staff are recertified prior to returning. (4) Staff temporarily not working in the facility for 1 year or longer due to COVID-19, but which Licensee intends to have return to work, do not have current health screenings and TB tests on file. LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Personnel Records, that Licensee ensure staff obtain health screenings and TB tests prior to returning. (5) Licensee confirmed that drills are completed every other month but are not fully logged. LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan, that Licensee ensure all drills are logged to ensure, and verify, completion. (6) Licensee has been using LIC 9040 as the register of clients, but as this form does not include all of the required information, including ambulatory status and medical contacts, LPA advises, per California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 80071, that Licensee use the LIC 9020 moving forward, which LPA provided at visit. LPA also advises that this form be update to reflect the current child(ren) in placement. Licensee also confirmed that a request to change the capacity will be submitted. LPA provided the LIC 200 and advises that Licensee submit the form and updated program plan for approval in order for LPA to process the request for updated fire clearance. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Licensee Patricia Cooper, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 11/28/22 at 10:50AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins and LPA George Karkazis made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPAs met with Licensee Patricia Cooper and informed of the purpose of the visit. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to complete today's inspection. A tour was conducted of the site and grounds and facility and resident records were reviewed. The below issues were observed. Hot water was measured above the permitted range. The water heater was lowered and hot water measured within range by the end of the visit. Psychotropic medication for resident R1 (See LIC Confidential Names, dated 11/28/22) was not logged on a separate log. Also the log for November was copied from a previous month, resulting in the log being pre-filled. R1 does not have a complete physician's report (LIC 602), and the last two pages were missing. R1's most recent complete needs and services plan is from 2019. Resident R2's file did not contain a written needs and services (from previous placement) or pre-placement appraisal. LPAs are issuing citations of Title 22, Sections 80069(c),80068.3(a), 83020(b)(12)(H)(1), 83070(b)(9), and 83070(b)(12). A continuation inspection will be conducted to complete the annual inspection. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report provided to Licensee Patricia Cooper, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Based on LPA's observations and interviews which were conducted and record review(s), the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegations (Resource parent does not obtain medical treatment timely for child in care, Due to not receiving timely medical care, child had not been fed for over 24 hours, and Due to not receiving timely medical care, child received burn from gastric fluid) are found to be SUBSTANTIATED. California Code of Regulations, (Title 22, CCR 83075(c) and Title 22, CCR 83072(d)(7)), are being cited on the attached LIC 9099D. Staff did not follow instructions to take child to receive medical treatment on a timely matter for special health care needs and did not follow Physician's instructions. Due to not receiving timely medical care, the client was not fed for over 24 hours and received burns and skin breakdown from gastric fluid. Deficiencies are being cited based on LPA's observation, interviews conducted, and record review in accordance with the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, see LIC 9099D. An exit interview was conducted, and appeal rights were reviewed and developed with the Administrator. A copy of this report was left with the Administrator, Patricia Cooper.

narrative: On 10/16/24 at 10:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti and LPA Shikya Belfield made a visit to the facility to review and discuss plans of corrections (POCs). LPAs met with Patricia Cooper, Licensee, and informed of the purpose of the visit. Also present was a CASA worker. The POCs were developed and agreed upon on 09/17/24 for 10 citations during a Case Management Teams Meeting (see LIC809 pages and LIC809-D pages dated 09/17/24). There were POCs that were reissued on 09/17/24, that were originally cited on 04/19/24. The due date for all POC's was 09/20/24. A request for an extension of the POC due date was requested by the Licensee on 09/23/24. The extension was granted and the POC due date was extended to 09/27/24. On 09/27/24 at 8:22pm, Licensee sent Community Care Licensing emails containing documents, photos, and videos. On 10/02/24, LPA Pierotti reviewed the documents, photos and videos submitted by the Licensee for the POCs. LPA Pierotti found the submitted files to not contain the POCs that were developed and agreed upon during the meeting on 09/17/24. On 10/03/24 at 1:32pm, LPA Pierotti called Licensee regarding the submitted documents and explained what the department was looking for in a POC. LPA Pierotti explained the department wanted Licensee to submit a written plan stating that in the future the Licensee will take these steps to prevent the cited deficiency from occurring again. LPA Pierotti gave Licensee an additional extension to submit the POCs by 10/7/24. On 10/07/24 at 6:57pm, LPA Pierotti received documents from the Licensee. LPA Pierotti reviewed the documents on 10/08/24 and found the submitted documents contained POCs from the reissued citations however, POCs from the reissuing were not submitted. LPA Pierotti also found the POCs that were developed and agreed upon during the meeting on 09/17/24 were not submitted. On 10/16/24, during the visit Licensee signed Plans of Correction for the 13 remaining POCs. Licensee agrees to follow the agreed upon POCs and to follow Community Care Licensing Regulations to remain in compliance with the Department. Although Civil Penalties will be assessed, they were discussed during this visit and LPAs will discuss with the department regarding the amount. LPAs will have a follow up conversation with Ms. Cooper on 10/17/2 at which time the appropriate forms will be submitted for review and signature. Currently there is an appeal date which has been extended to 10/18/24. The Licensee will be submitting evidence and documents to support their appeal for the citations. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Patricia Cooper, Licensee, whose signature confirms receipt.

This is a violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Article 6, Section 83075(g) Psychotropic medication shall only be used in accordance with the written directions of the physician prescribing the medication and in accordance with authorization requirements specified in Sections 369.5(a)(1) and 739.5(a)(1) of the Welfare and Institutions Code and Section 83070(b)(11) and California Code of regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 6, Section 80075(b) Clients shall be assisted as needed with self-administration of prescription and nonprescription medications. The facility is being issued citations on the attached page LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Patricia Cooper, Licensee, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

narrative: On May 23, 2024 at 9: AM, a Component II was conducted at the Monterey Park Children's Residential Program office with Cheryl and Jesse White Small Family Home. During the meeting, LPA discussed their application and the pending items needed. Documents required to be submitted: For Jesse White: 1) LIC Health Screening and TB test For Licensee/Administrator 1) Program Statement Revisions- submitted -needed to review **Revise the age capacity 0-21/non minor dependents **Revise the Discipline and Phone calls **Sign In and Out Procedure **Label the facility sketch with the Exit and clients room 2) Adult Son (living at home) - TB test Here's the Program website that you can review the SFH tool: www.cdss.ca.gov/inforesources/community-care-licensing/inspection-process Applicant was also advised to begin contacting placement agencies.
