On July 12, 2024 at approximately 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. Upon arrival, LPA met with Cheryl White, applicant. Together they toured the external and internal areas of the home. The following was observed at the time of inspection: Physical Plant This facility is a one story house located in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of four (4) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, dining area, family room, laundry room and backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in excellent condition. Passageways are free from obstruction. Knives and sharps, disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked and secured in the laundry room. Per applicant, there are no firearms on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures throughout the home during the inspection were comfortable. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The home has two fire extinguishers. The home has a working telephone that is available for client use. A fire inspection was conducted by the Rancho Cucamonga Fire Department on 05/06/24 and a fire clearance was granted for six ambulatory clients. Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies The home has toilets, wash basins, and one shower/bath for clients' use. Client bedroom #2 & #3 was observed to be clean, orderly, and contained a bunk bed and twin bed. LPA observed clean pillows, bed sheets and blankets. The client's bedroom has adequate closet and drawer space to accommodate client's clothing and personal belongings. Heath Related Services and Record Keeping Medications, the first aid kit will be centrally stored and locked in a cabinet by the hallway. The kit contains all required supplies. The client and staff files will be stored in a locked file cabinet in the applicant's bedroom. LPA also conducted Component III - Category Specific Orientation with the applicant. The following items were discussed and provided to the applicant: -Title 22 regulations on Small Family Homes - Continuing Requirements (General Licensing Requirements) - Buildings and Grounds requirements - Personnel Records (forms) - Client Records (forms) -Reporting Requirements - Other administrative forms LPA guided applicant to go to this website for additional information regarding the inspection and its CARE Tools and methods, please visit the CARE Tools web page or the Inspection Process Project web page.(www.cdss.ca.gov) Prior to today's visit, the applicant submitted the final Program Statement/Plan of Operation to LPA. The LPA will submit for final review and a new license will be mailed to the agency upon approval. No deficiencies were observed on this date. An exit interview was conducted a signed copy of this report was emailed to the applicant.

On February 20, 2025 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Juliet Robles and Caitlin Chambers conducted an unannounced inspection at the Small Family Home facility and met with the licensee, Cheryl White. The purpose of the inspection was about post licensing. Currently the facility has three (3) children in care. At 10:40AM, LPAs and licensee toured the internal and external areas of the home. The following was observed at the time of inspection: This facility is a one-story house located in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of four (4) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, kitchen, family room, dining area, laundry room and backyard. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in excellent condition. Passageways are free from obstruction. Knives, sharps, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are kept locked and secured in the laundry room. Per licensee, there are no firearms on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures throughout the home during the inspection were comfortable. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The home has two fire extinguishers: one in the kitchen and one outside. Medications, the first aid kit is centrally stored in a cabinet by the hallway. The first aid kit contains all required supplies. The home has toilets, wash basins, and one shower/bath for clients' use. The water temperature was tested at 112 degrees which is within regulatory guidelines. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom #1 sleeps Client 1 and Client Bedroom #2 sleeps Client Bedroom #3 sleeps adult son Bedroom #4 - Master's Bedroom sleeps Licensee Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good condition. Each bedroom has sufficient drawer and closet space. There are two full bathrooms in the home, all in working order. The licensee is the main caretaker of the home. Client and staff files are stored under lock and key in the file cabinet in the licensee's bedroom. Emergency disaster drills are conducted every six months. LPA reviewed three (3) client records and one (1) staff record. LPA checked required criminal record and child abuse index check clearance or exemption for all adults in the home. The client's files contained: Admission Agreement, Medical Assessment, Consent Forms, Emergency Information, Appraisal Form, Immunization Record and Personal Rights. LPA interviewed the licensee. Clients were not available for interview at the time of inspection. LPA will attempt to interview clients at a later time. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted and LPA provided a copy of the following reports: LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 811 to Ms. Cheryl White, Administrator/Licensee.

On August 21, 2025 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles made an unannounced visit to the Small Family Home (SFH) and met Jesse White SFH assistant administrator for the purpose of conducting a follow up case management inspection. The purpose of the visit is to confirm the usage of the camera and its location to submit a program statement addendum. LPA spoke with the Administrator, Cheryl White and stated that she cannot come to the facility due to an appointment at the doctor's office. The LPA and assistant administrator did a walk-through of the facility inside and outside. LPA observed that there are 8 cameras at the facility. 1) A video camera at the front door entrance, 2) living room facing the window, 3) part of living room facing the front door and hallway, 4) inside the family room facing the TV., 5) outside on the left side near the kitchen door facing the gate, 6) outside on the right side near the master bedroom window facing the playground, 7) outside left rear of the master bedroom facing the 2nd backyard and 8) outside on top of the roof or the eve of the home facing the street. Per assistant administrator, all video cameras both interior and exterior have their audio disabled. LPA advised the administrator to disable the camera until the approval letter is received. LPA requested the revise program statement to be submitted on or before August 26, 2025. LPA provided the facility a copy of PIN 24-09-CRP Video Cameras in Children's Residential Congregate Care Facilities. Based on the observation and information gathered, there is no deficiency cited at this time, no further follow up is needed. A copy of this report was given to the assistant administrator, Jesse White.

On September 16, 2025 at 11: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Juliet Robles conducted an unannounced inspection at the Cheryl and Jesse White Small Family Home facility and met with the Cheryl White administrator. The purpose of the inspection was about an Annual/Required inspection. Currently the facility has two (2) children in care. This facility is license to provide services to six (6) ambulatory clients for developmentally disabled children aged 0 -17 years old. LPA and licensee toured the internal and external areas of the home. The following was observed at the time of inspection: There are eight (8) cameras at the facility, all video cameras both interior and exterior have their audio disabled. Physical Plant: This facility is a one-story house located in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of four (4) bedrooms, two (2) bathrooms, a large area with couch, TV, and pet dog kennel, kitchen, dining area, family room, laundry/storage area and two (2) backyards. Passageways are free from obstruction. Knives, sharps, disinfectants, and cleaning solutions are kept locked and secured in the laundry room. Per licensee, there are no firearms on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures throughout the home during the inspection were comfortable. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. The home has a fire extinguisher in the kitchen. Medications, the first aid kit is centrally stored in a cabinet by the hallway. The first aid kit contains all required supplies. The home has toilets, wash basins, and one shower/bath for clients' use. The water temperature was tested at 107 degrees, which is within regulatory guidelines. The bathroom has protective nonslip material on rugs. There are fresh perishable and non-perishable foods in the home. The facility has a telephone service on the premises. The facility has an outdoor activity space which is free from hazards to life and health. Copy of facility license, facility sketch, emergency phone numbers, client activities, menu, personal rights and emergency disaster form were all prominently displayed in the home. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom #1 sleeps Client 2- bunk bed, comforters, linens, pillows, drawer, closet Bedroom #2 sleeps Client 1- bunk bed and 1 twin bed, comforters, linens, pillow, drawer, closet Bedroom #3 sleeps adult son Bedroom #4 - Master's Bedroom sleeps Licensee The licensee is the main caretaker of the home. Client and staff files are stored in a locked file cabinet in the licensee's bedroom. Emergency disaster drills are conducted every six months. Client Files: Client files have a signed copy of the admission agreement, medical assessment, written consent, dental and medical history, a copy of the client's needs and services plan and any modifications. The original documentation signed by the client and the authorized representative acknowledging the receipt of information regarding the child's personal rights, an account of the client's cash resources, personal property and valuables. LPA reviewed two (2) client records at the facility. Clients were not available for interview at the time of inspection. Staff Files: The administrator and staff have a health screening with TB test, documentation of criminal record clearance, have a current First Aid and CPR certificate. The administrator and staff meet the initial and ongoing training requirements. LPA reviewed one (2) staff record at the facility. LPA interviewed one (1) staff member at the facility. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A Technical Advisory was issued (see LIC 9102). An exit interview was conducted, and LPA provided a copy of the following reports: LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 811 and LIC 9102 to Ms. Cheryl White, Administrator/Licensee.

On 06/10/21, at 9:45 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Belinda Gilmer made an announced visit to this facility and met with Licensee, Edith Reynoso Silvia. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a required annual inspection. Licensee and LPA toured the entire home inside and out. Currently there are no children placed in the home. Licensee reported she is the only person living in the home. (see Confidential Name form (LIC 811) dated 6/10/21. The home is set up as follows: This is a two story single family home with six rooms 4 downstairs bedrooms are permitted by the City of Norwalk to be used as bedrooms, 3.5 bathrooms, a living room, dining-room, kitchen, Bedroom # 1 on the first floor is - vacate a twin beds, crib small refrigerator and closet space with mother's clothes in it). ( used to be her mother's bedroom) Bedroom # 2 - on the first floor vacate door with a direct exit to the outside (two twin bed, dresser and closet space). Bedroom # 3 - on the first floor vacate door with a direct exit to the outside dresser and closet space). Room # 4 - which was previous listed as a bedroom is currently being used as a storage area with a sofa, portable closet is being used as a storage room . Not permitted by the city to be used as a bedroom. Room # 5 - which was previous noted as a bedroom can't not be used as a bedroom per City of Norwalk inspector. The beds have been removed as required my the City of Norwalk. has one chair. Bedroom # 6 - occupied by licensee future son in law (twin bed and closet space) Licensee stated he has a full time live-in job and visits her on his off days. Bedroom # 7 - occupied by licensee. The gas stove, the smoke detector needs batteries; it was beeping. The carbon monoxide detector was tested and operable. Yet, LPA smelled gas during this visit. Licensee said she called the gas company in May because she also smelled something. When the gas company inspected her home they found potential explosive items in the trash can. However, the information licensee provided doesn't explain the gas smell that LPA smelled today. LPA will recommend Licensee contact the gas company again and have them reinspect the home and email LPA after the inspection. The home had a locked cabinet in the laundry area, disinfectants and cleaning solutions. The first aid kit is new and was sealed. The front and backyard were inspected LPA observed lots of plants. There were no pools and/or bodies of water on the premises. The licensee has current CPR and First Aid card that will expire on 12/03/22. Licensee has completed 8 hours of the 15 required hours of annual training. Licensee has 2 months to complete the additional 7 hours. Licensee is the only adults living in the home and she has obtained their criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. In accordance with California Code of Regulation, Title 22, Division 6, the following deficiencies were observed and will be cited. Exit interview was conducted and Licensee and a copy of this report was provided.

On July 21, 2022 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Timika Martin and Jenny Mundo conducted an unannounced Plan of Correction inspection to the above facility. The purpose of the inspection is to verify if deficiencies cited on July 1, 2022, were corrected. LPA's met with Administrator, Edith Silva and informed her of the purpose for the inspection. At 1: PM LPA's conducted a tour of the facility along with the Administrator for verification of the plan of correction (POC). During today's inspection the LPAs reviewed each violation previously cited as follows: Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status: The Licensee moved 3 clients from her Adult Residential Facility clients into the SFH licensed for children ages 0-17 (Corrected per Plan of Correction). Personal Rights: -The facility did not ensure cleanliness of the facility. The facility is in disarray with clutter and boxes throughout the home. The floors are not cleaned (Corrected per Plan of Correction). Buildings & Grounds: -The facility has an inoperable mini school bus in the driveway (Corrected per Plan of Correction). -The laundry room was disorganized with linens, clothes, laundry baskets and debris all over (Corrected per Plan of Correction). -The facility did not ensure cleanliness of the kitchen and dining room area. There was food located on the kitchen counters not properly stored, uncleaned dishes and boxes located in the living/dining room (Corrected per Plan of Correction). -There was a foul odor throughout the facility due to animal urine & feces not properly disposed. The facility has 12 cats/kittens and 1 dog roaming through the inside and outside of facility (Corrected per Plan of Correction). -The facility has flies/ fleas due to cat feces in the cat litter (Corrected per Plan of Correction). Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies: -Room #1 and room #2 both have one non-operable light bulb and bathroom #2 have a missing light (Corrected per Plan of Correction). -The beds did not have linens or pillows on the beds (Corrected per Plan of Correction). LPA's observed (9) out the (9) deficiencies cited to the facility on July 1, 2022 have been corrected as per plan of correction. Appeal rights were provided and discussed with the Administrator. An exit interview was conducted and copy of this report and Letters of Deficiency Citations Cleared were provided to the Administrator. .

deficiencies.title: Personal Rights
Buildings & Grounds

narrative: This is an amended report from June 30, 2022 and July 1, 2022. On 7/1/22 at 8: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Timika Martin and Jenny Mundo made an unannounced case management inspection to The Children's Station Small Family Home (SFH) and met with Administrator, Edith Silva. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up with the information gathered by Orange County, Harbor Regional Center and CCL Adult and Senior Care. The information indicated that Administrator, Edith Silva, relocated three (3) adult residents from her Adult Residential Facility (ARF) to the SFH without approval. At 8: AM LPAs toured the facility with Administrator and discussed the following observed deficiencies. 80010(a)(b) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status (a)A licensee shall not operate a facility beyond the conditions and limitations specified on the license, including the capacity limitation. (b) Facilities or rooms approved for ambulatory clients only shall not be used by non-ambulatory clients. 80087(a) Buildings & Grounds (a)The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. 80087(a)(1) Buildings & Grounds (a)The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. (1) The licensee shall take measures to keep the facility free of flies and other insects. 80072 (a)(2)(3)Personal Rights (a)Except for children's residential facilities, each client shall have personal rights which include, but are not limited to, the following: (2)To be accorded safe, healthful and comfortable accommodations, furnishings and equipment to meet his/her needs. (3)To be free from corporal or unusual punishment, infliction of pain, humiliation, intimidation, ridicule, coercion, threat, mental abuse, or other actions of a punitive nature, including but not limited to: interference with the daily living functions, including eating, sleeping, or toileting; or withholding of shelter, clothing, medication or aids to physical functioning. 83088 (a)(c)Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies (a) In addition to Section 80088, the following shall apply. (c) The licensee shall provide each child with an individual bed which is equipped with a clean, comfortable mattress, clean linens, blankets, and pillows, as needed, all in good repair. 80088 (d) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies (d) The licensee shall provide lamps or lights as necessary in all rooms and other areas to ensure the comfort and safety of all persons in the facility. LPAs discussed the deficiencies observed with the Administrator. Deficiencies observed pose a Health and Safety risk to the clients in which they serve as the facility is not following keeping the facility clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Exit interview completed, the following deficiencies were cited, and a copy of this report was left with the representative above. At 8: AM LPAs toured the facility with Administrator. This is a two-story single-family home with six rooms 4 downstairs bedrooms, 3.5 bathrooms, a living room, dining-room, kitchen. The Administrator stated that she does not currently have any clients living in the facility and that the facility has been vacant for approximately 2 years. The Administrator stated that the she moved in 3 adult clients (ages 21,25,34) into the SFH because she is currently having construction done to one of her adult facilities (Xavier II). The licensee was advised she is not operating within the terms and conditions of her license. The Small Family Home is licensed to serve 4 developmentally disabled (medically fragile or special health care need children) ages 0-17; may be non-ambulatory. The Administrator stated that this SFH is listed as her emergency relocation for those clients. The licensee stated that the adult clients were move in the SFH the second week of June 2022 and were moved out on 6/30/22 into an Extended Stay Suites located in La Mirada. The Administrator also stated that the clients will be at the Extended Stay Suites for about 2-2 ½ months. The administrator stated that she informed Orange County CCL and Regional Center of the relocation and that they both approved the re-location both times. The administrator stated that she did not inform CCL Monterey Park and LA County of relocating the adult clients to the SFH. During the tour, LPA's observed a non-operable facility school bus located in the driveway that was uncleaned and covered in cobwebs. LPA's observed two cat litter boxes with feces inside of them, surrounded by flies/ fleas. LPA's observed several fruit trees and potted plants located in the front yard along with cats and kittens roaming/sitting in the yard. LPA's observed flies/fleas surrounding the front door. LPA's observed flies/fleas roaming inside of the SFH. There was a strong smell of urine & feces throughout the facility. The Administrator informed LPA's that the odor we were smelling was Febreze and cleaning solution. There were approximately 12-15 cats/kittens inside and outside of the home. The administrator stated that three cats belong to the clients and out the three cats they made babies. There was one dog roaming inside the home. The facility floor was not cleaned. The facility is in disarray with clutter and boxes throughout the facility. In the dining and living room area, LPA's observed serval boxes and bags which the Administrator stated to be the adult client's personal belongings. LPA's observed that the kitchen area was unkempt. LPA's observed frozen foods located on the kitchen counters and canned goods, juices, etc. on the kitchen counter and not properly stored. LPA's observed uncleaned dishes inside of the sink, on the kitchen counters and on the stove. LPA's observed the 4 bedrooms downstairs. One bedroom is used for storage, and three bedrooms are used for clients. The three bedrooms contained two twin beds in each room with adequate drawer and closet space. LPA's observed that each bed had a fitted sheet on the mattress and 3 out of the 6 beds contained pillows. The bedrooms were not equipped with clean linens, blankets, and pillows. In bedroom #1 and bedroom #2 both have one non-operable light bulb. In one bathroom there is a missing light/light bulb. LPA's observed that the laundry room was disorganized with linens, clothes, laundry baskets and debris all over. There are two bedrooms upstairs, that are not for clients use. Both rooms upstairs are in disarray with one bed each and clutter. During the tour of the facility, cats/and kittens were coming from underneath the couches and down that stairwells. In the back yard there is a sunroom where the cats/kittens, food, cages and play area is located. LPA's discussed with Administrator regarding surrendering her license approximately three times during the visit and she refused. Administrator stated that she plans on having clients and that DCFS would like to place children in her home. The following deficiencies were observed and discussed: 80010(a)(b) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory Status 80087(a) Buildings & Grounds 80087(a)(1) Buildings & Grounds 80072 (a)(2)(3) Personal Rights 83088 (a)(c) Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies 80088 (d) Furniture, Fixtures, Equipment, and Supplies LPAs discussed the deficiencies observed with the Administrator. Deficiencies observed pose a Health and Safety risk to the clients in which they serve as the facility is not following keeping the facility clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. Exit interview completed, the following deficiencies were cited, and a copy of this report was left with the representative above.

On October 12, 2022 at 9:00AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Timika Martin conducted an unannounced inspection at the small family home (SFH) above for the purpose of conducting an annual inspection. LPA met with the licensee of the home, Edith Silva. The licensee stated that she does not currently have any clients living in the SFH and that the SFH has been vacant for approximately 2 years. The SFH is licensed to serve 4 developmentally disabled (medically fragile or special health care need children) ages 0-17; may be non-ambulatory. LPA toured the home with licensee and observed the following: This is a two-story single-family home with seven bedrooms (4 bedrooms downstairs and two bedrooms upstairs), 3.5 bathrooms, a living room, dining-room, kitchen and laundry room. Two out of the seven bedrooms are used for clients. There are two bedrooms upstairs, that are not for clients use. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space, including an outdoor yard. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. LPA observed the Emergency Contacts, Emergency Plan (evacuation), Regional Center poster and Covid-19 postings posted on the wall in the facility. LPA observed that the Personal Rights poster that was posted on the wall was not current. The facility is in disarray with clutter and boxes throughout the facility. In the dining and living room area, LPA observed serval boxes and bags which the licensee stated to be the adult clients from her Adult Residential Facility. Bedroom # 1 on the first floor is has a twin bed, crib small refrigerator and closet space with mother's belongings in it (used to be licensee mother's bedroom). Bedroom # 2 on the first floor contained two twin beds in each room with adequate drawer and closet space. LPA observed a pile of laundry on each twin bed. Bedroom # 3 on the first floor contained two twin beds in each room with adequate drawer and closet space. LPA observed a pile of laundry on one twin bed. Room # 4 is currently being used as a storage area with a portable closet. LPA observed the room to be cluttered and unorganized with boxes and clothing. Not permitted by the city to be used as a bedroom. Room # 5 previous noted as a bedroom can't not be used as a bedroom per City of Norwalk inspector. LPA observed this room to be a storage room, cluttered and unorganized with clothing, bedding, hangers and other miscellaneous items. Bedroom # 6 is occupied by licensee son. LPA observed this room to be unorganized filled with toys. Bedroom # 7 is occupied by licensee. LPA observed the bedroom to be cluttered and unorganized. LPA observed piles and boxes of papers around the room and other miscellaneous items. There were no pools and/or bodies of water on the premises. The licensee has current CPR and First Aid card that will expire on 12/03/22. Licensee has completed the required hours of annual training. Licensee is the only adult living in the home and she has obtained her criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. LPA reviewed licensee file and conducted an interview. No clients were interviewed due to none in placement. The following deficiency was observed and discussed: 80087(a) Buildings & Grounds (a)The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors. An immediate civil penalty of $250 will be assessed for a repeat violation. LPA issued a Technical Assistance (see LIC 9102TA). Exit interview completed, the following deficiencies were cited, civil penalty was assessed and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with the representative above.

On 07/02/24 at 1: P.M., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Demetris Teal conducted an unannounced Pre licensing inspection at the above named facility.LPA met with Stephanie L. Childs-Administrator. This facility is a two (2) story home with five (5) bedrooms, three (3) bathrooms, one of the bedrooms is a staff office, kitchen, dining room, a living room, and a laundry area. There are no bodies of water on the premises. There are no firearms or ammunition in the facility. At 2: P.M., LPA conducted a walk-through of the entire facility. Physical Plant, Operations, Staffing and Client Records were reviewed and discussed with the administrator. The clients files will be maintained in locked file cabinets. Medication is located in a locked medicine box. The files and medicines will be in a locked room where only staff will have access. Washer and dryers are located in the hallway. Laundry and cleaning supplies will be in locked cabinets. During the inspection the administrator shared that they are currently approved with San Bernardino County and 1 child is currently placed. During the pre licensing a Component III was conducted on what to expect after licensing. Exit interview conducted. A copy of the 809 was left with the administrator.

On December 6, 2021, at 10:30AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Humberto Flores, conducted an unannounced Annual Inspection at Chiu Small Family Home (SMH) and met with Jean Chiu-Torres. The purpose of the inspection was to conduct an Annual Inspection. The facility it is a two-story home located in a gated community of a residential neighborhood. The facility has 5 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. Currently there are two (2) ambulatory children in placement with special health care needs. Facility is licensed to serve two (2) ambulatory and two (2) non ambulatory children ages 0-17 years old. There are no bodies of water on premises. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom #1 (First floor), it has 2 twin beds. Adopted daughter and Child Ref #1 (C1)(see Confidential Names form LIC811 dated 12/06/2021) sleep in it. Bedroom #2 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps 14 years old adopted son. Bedroom #3 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps Child Ref #2 (C2). cont.# Bedroom #4 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps 19 years old adopted son. Bedroom #5 (Second floor) Licensee and her husband. All bedrooms have adequate closet and drawer space. During the inspection a copy of the Register of Facility Clients and Personnel Report was provided upon request. The following topics were inspected: PHYSICAL PLANT: A tour of the facility was conducted inside and out, along with the Licensee. The License was placed in a prominent place, 1st floor living room of the facility. LPA Flores observed that the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The passageways are unobstructed. The disinfectants and cleaning solutions were stored away from the kitchen areas, food preparation areas to the children. The food is safe and of the quality and the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. Each meal meets at least 1/3 of the recommended in the USDA Basic Food Group Plan-Daily Food Guide. Supplies of staples non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days are maintained in the facility. cont.# Medications are locked and accessible only to the Licensee and direct care staff. The temperature in the rooms that clients occupy are maintained between 68 and 85 degrees (F) and the hot water temperature was at 110 degrees (F). Emergency Intervention Plan: LPA Flores reviewed the Emergency Intervention Plan. CLIENT RECORDS: LPA Flores reviewed the 1 (1) client file records. The files contain: Admission Agreement, Medical Assessment, Consent Forms, Emergency Information, Appraisal & Needs Service Plan, Immunization Record and Personal Rights. The Safeguards For Cash Resources was missing for C1. Staff Records: A total of 1 employees' file was reviewed. The files contain the following documentation: Child Abuse Index Checks/Department of Justice (DOJ)/Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) criminal record clearances, criminal record statement and a health screening and tuberculosis and Certificate and Cardiopulmonary Resuscitation. # OPERATIONAL REQUIREMENTS: During the inspection review, LPA Flores observed the facility maintained an updated roster of the clients with pertinent information. The Licensee and direct care staff are the responsible and capable for communicating with emergency personnel if needed. No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was provided to the SFH representative. Exit interview conducted.

On November 18, 2022 at 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Timika Martin conducted an Annual inspection at the above facility. LPA met with the licensee Jean Chiu. At 9: AM, LPA conducted a complete tour of the inside and outside of the small family home (SFH). This two-story SFH has 5 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. See Confidential Names Form (LIC 811) dated November 18, 2022. Currently, there are two ambulatory clients in placement with special health care needs. Facility is licensed to serve two (2) ambulatory and two (2) non ambulatory children ages 0-17 years old. There are no bodies of water on premises. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom #1 (First floor), it has 2 twin beds, sleeps daughter and Child Ref #1 (C1) sleep in it. Bedroom #2 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps son. Bedroom #3 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps Child Ref #2 (C2) Bedroom #4 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps son. Bedroom #5 (Second floor) Licensee and her husband. All bedrooms have adequate closet and drawer space. All exits, and hallways were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. The carbon monoxide/smoke detectors throughout the facility upstairs and downstairs were checked to be operable and functioning. Water temperature was tested and was within regulatory guidelines. First aid kit was readily available, complete and stored in a laundry room cabinet. Medications were observed to be centrally locked in a locked area located in the upper and lower kitchen cabinet. Medications that needed refrigeration is stored in the garage refrigerator with a lock. Kitchen was inspected and food supplies both perishable and non-perishable were checked and found to be sufficient. Sharp knives and sharp utensils were made inaccessible. Per licensee there are no weapons in the facility. Cleaning solutions and toxins were locked in the garage, laundry room and kitchen cabinets, inaccessible to clients. Copy of facility license, facility sketch, emergency phone numbers, emergency disaster form were all prominently displayed in the home. LPA Martin reviewed the Emergency Intervention Plan. LPA reviewed two (2) client files and licensee's record. Licensee has current CPR and First Aid on file. Licensee is current with ongoing training hours. LPA checked required criminal record and child abuse index check clearance or exemption. The two clients are nonverbal; two clients takes food and medication through tube and C1 through a central line. The client's files contained: Admission Agreement, Medical Assessment, Consent Forms, Emergency Information, Individual Family Service Plan, Immunization Record and Personal Rights. The Safeguards for Cash Resources for C2 is no longer required per DCFS due to C2 being federally funded. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted with the licensee. LPA provided a copy of the following reports: LIC 809, LIC 809C, LIC 811, were provided to Jean Chiu.

On November 2, 2024 at 9: AM , Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Olena Maico conducted an unannounced annual inspection visit at the above facility. LPA met with the licensee Jean Chiu-Torres. Currently there is one client in placement (See LIC 811 - List of Confidential Names). At 10: AM, LPA conducted a complete tour of the inside and outside of the small family home (SFH) along with the licensee. Outside facility is in good repair and no deficiencies noted. Outside patio has enough room for the clients to use if needed. This two story SFH has 5 bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. Currently, there are one ambulatory client in placement with special health care needs. Facility is licensed to serve two (2) ambulatory and two (2) non-ambulatory children ages 0-17 years old. License is posted in the living room area and visible to the LPA. There are no bodies of water on premises. There are two cameras on premises, one in the living room area and one in the family room area. Licensee was advised to update the Plan of Operations for the camera locations. The entrance to the house has wheelchair accessible ramp and the door opens to the living room area and that leads to the kitchen and upstairs. All the entrances are free and clear from hazard. Kitchen has all the necessary appliances and working stove and microwave. Knives are locked away in the drawer and inaccessible, and medications are centrally stored in the locked drawer and the ones required refrigerating in the locked box in the fridge. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom #1 (First floor), it has 2 twin beds, sleeps daughter (13) and Child C1 (See LIC List of Confidential Names). Bedroom #2 (Second floor) it has two twin beds and sleeps son (7 years old). Bedroom #3 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps son (22). Son has a DOJ/FBI/CACI clearance in Guardian. Bedroom #4 (Second floor) it has a twin bed and sleeps son(17 years old). Bedroom #5 (Second floor) Licensee and her husband. All bedrooms have adequate closet and drawer space for the clients to store personal items. Bathrooms have enough personal hygiene items and toiletries. All exits, and hallways were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. The carbon monoxide/smoke detectors throughout the facility upstairs and downstairs were checked to be operable and functioning (connect to the alarm company). Water temperature was tested and was within regulatory guidelines ( F). First aid kit was readily available, complete and stored in a laundry room cabinet and expires 09/30/2025. Fire extinguishers located in the kitchen area and a second floor and are expiring October 2027. LPA Maico observed that the facility is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair. The passageways are unobstructed. The disinfectants and cleaning solutions were stored away from the kitchen areas, food preparation areas and inaccessible to the children. The food is safe and of the quality and the quantity necessary to meet the needs of the clients. Each meal meets at least 1/3 of the recommended in the USDA Basic Food Group Plan-Daily Food Guide. Supplies of staples non-perishable foods for one week and perishable foods for two days are maintained in the facility. The client does not consume regular food, C1 feeds using G-tube and central line. Per licensee there are no weapons in the facility. During the inspection a copy of the Register of Facility Clients and Personnel Report LIC 500 was provided upon request. The following topics were inspected: Emergency Intervention Plan: LPA Maico reviewed the Emergency Intervention Plan. It has all the necessary items and was just updated 10/01/24. Licensee added phone number and email address to the form. Emergency drills are conducted monthly and topics are rotated. CLIENT RECORDS: LPA Maico reviewed the 1 client file records. The files contain: Admission Agreement, Medical Assessment, Consent Forms, Emergency Information, IPP plan from the regional center, Immunization Record and Personal Rights, Medication Administration Log. All forms need signatures are signed. Safeguard for cash resources is not attached due to the cash being managed through the trust management company. Staff Records: A total of 4 employees' file was reviewed. The files contain the following documentation: Child Abuse Index Checks/Department of Justice (DOJ)/Federal Bureau of Investigation (FBI) criminal record clearances, criminal record statement and a health screening and tuberculosis and CPR. All the training required is provided in the employee's records and training includes, but not limited to implicit bias, LGBTQ right training, cultural competency, Mandated reported training. The Licensee and direct care staff are the responsible and capable for communicating with emergency personnel if needed. No further inspection is needed. No citation was issued. On February 3, 2023 at 09: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes began a pre-licensing inspection for Christiana Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Christiana Opoku who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve 2 clients ages 0 to 7. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed, will sleep the licensee, and one baby and has a master bathroom. · Bedroom #2 (daughters) has one twin bed and sleeps the daughter · Bedroom #3 (Client's) was vacant, had one queen bed, it will sleep one client. · Bedroom #4 (Client's) was vacant, had one queen bed, it will sleep one client. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an attached three car garage, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client's bedroom was arranged so that no more than one client will be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client's belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom and a carbon monoxide detector located in the downstairs hallway. The five smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide detector were checked, and they were working properly. The home's central air conditioning module was on the side of the house. The home's water heater was located inside the garage. Inside the facility there was a fireplace with a gate in the front. The appliances were in working order. : The client's files will be locked inside a cabinet in the upstairs office space. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. Sharp knives were located on the top shelf of the kitchen cabinet. The hot water in the Master Bathroom measured to be 129.5 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature of the client bathroom 1 was observed to be 132.5 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature in client bathroom number 2 measured to be 133.2 degrees Fahrenheit. The home's First Aid kit was accessible the first aid kit is located upstairs in the hall cabinet and had all required supplies. There was a locked container to hold medication and will be located upstairs next to the first aid kit. There were two fire extinguishers were present in the home and one was located downstairs in the hallway and the second was located upstairs in the hallway. It was observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. There was no pool or other body of water present at time of inspection. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The following deficiencies were observed: The required forms needed prior to operation, were not posted at the time of this inspection. (Complaint Hotline) The water temperature in all bathrooms were hotter than 120 degrees Fahrenheit. The hot water heater needs to be turned down The shower in the downstairs bathroom was inoperable Need to put a lock on the cabinet in the laundry room where detergent is kept. Need to put knives in a locked cabinet The request for a license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the Plan of Corrections are cleared. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Christiana Opoku.

On April 8, 2024 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Maya Chavez and Karen Beal began a post-licensing inspection for Christiana Small Family Home. LPAs met with applicant Christiana Opoku who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are two clients placed in the home. The home is a two story building with four bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has 1 king bed, 1 twin bed, 1 crib, will sleep the licensees, their two bio children, twin bed and crib are in nursery section of master bedroom. · Bedroom #2 was vacant. · Bedroom #3 (Client's) has two twins beds, sleeps foster child 1 and foster child 2. · Bedroom #4 (Client's) was vacant, had one queen bed. · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an attached three car garage, storage closet, and the backyard. The Client's bedroom was arranged so two clients can be in the room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client's belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom and a carbon monoxide detector located in the upstairs and downstairs hallways. The five smoke detectors and the carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. The home's central air conditioning module was on the side of the house. The home's water heater was located inside the garage. Inside the facility there was a fireplace with a gate in the front. The appliances were in working order. The client's files will be locked inside a cabinet in the upstairs office space. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of four days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A proper storage of all food was discussed. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. Sharp knives, scissors and forks were locked in the island cabinet. The hot water kitchen measured to be 114.2 degrees Fahrenheit. The water temperature of the client bathroom 1 was observed to be 112.8 degrees Fahrenheit. The home's First Aid kit was accessible and is located upstairs in the hall cabinet and had all required supplies. There was a locked container to hold medication and will be located upstairs next to the first aid kit. There were two fire extinguishers present in the home, one was located downstairs in the hallway and the second was located upstairs in the hallway. Both fire extinguishers observed to be expired. Applicant stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. There was no pool or other body of water present at time of inspection. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The following deficiencies were observed: Based on observation of two expired fire extinguishers, the licensee did not comply with the section cited above in 2 out of 2 fire extinguishers were expired which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. Based on CCR 83088(h) licensee is going to be cited with a Type-B violation and has 30 days to provide proof of correction. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to licensee, Christiana Opoku.

On August 8, 2025, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stefanie Mutialu conducted an unannounced annual required Inspection at Coastal Care. LPA met with Licensee, Kathy Aloe. The facility is licensed to serve clients ages 0-22 years old. The facility is cleared for one ambulatory and three non-ambulatory clients. The current census is two children. LPA observed all licensing fees to be current. The facility was toured inside and out. The home is a four-bedroom and a two-bathroom home. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the bathroom was measured to be 111 degrees, which is within regulatory requirements. The small family home's smoke and carbon monoxide detector was checked and were operable. The clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a cabinet in the laundry room of the home. The First Aid Kit contained all required supplies, which is stored in a locked closet in the hallway. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There are no swimming pools or bodies of water. Per Licensee there are no guns on the premises. ****Continued on Page 2**** ****CONTINUED FROM PAGE 1**** two client files and four staff files were reviewed during the inspection. All staff that work at the facility have Federal Bureau of Investigation, Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances per Title 22 requirements. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. An exit interview was conducted, this report was discussed, and a copy of this report and confidential names (LIC811) was provided to the Licensee, Kathy Aloe. A copy of this report will be placed in the facility file. Due to technical issues this report was emailed to licensee.

Throughout the course of the complaint investigation, for the allegation of foster parent is not providing medication to foster child, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison conducted interviews with all relevant parties. During the interview conducted with Adult #1, it was reported that the allegation was false. Adult #1 confirms that C1 is only prescribed one medication. Adult #1 confirms that medication is administered to C1 as follows: ½ pill at 6:00am and 1 ½ pill at 8:00pm every day by crushing the pill and placing it in water. Adult #1 watches to ensure C1 drinks the water containing the medication. LPA confirms the instructions on the bottle of medicine and by reviewing the daily entries on the medication log kept by Adult #1. Reporting party (RP) states Adult #2 confirms FP expressed medication was placed in a "shake" for C1 but when later asked by RP, Adult #1 denied this was true. LPA was unable to confirm whether C1's medication was placed in the shake on the day of the incident. Witness #1 confirms that the school does not administer or provide medication to C1. Collateral witness confirms that C1 is prescribed and taking one medication twice a day, once in the morning and once in the evening. Based on the interviews conducted, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. Due to inconsistent statements and documentary evidence obtained LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations were determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. No deficiencies were observed or cited at the time of this investigation. Exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report will be mailed to the Licensee.
investigation_findings: 13On November 16, 2021 at 4:09pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Cormier Small Family Home and spoke with the licensee. The purpose of this visit was to deliver the findings for the above complaint allegations. During the course of investigating the allegations for foster child's hygiene needs are not being met while in care and foster parent is not providing medication to foster child., LPA Edison conducted interviews with Adult #1 and other collateral contacts. During the interviews conducted with Adult #1, it was reported that the allegations were false. Adult #1 confirms that she sends C1 to school each day with clean clothes on as well as two sets of clean clothes and extra "diapers" in his backpack in case he needs to be changed at school. On the day licensee was interviewed, LPA conducted an inspection of C1's backpack and confirms extra unused diapers and two sets of clean clothes. LPA also noted that C1 had a small food stain on the front of his shirt, however, the rest of his clothing appeared clean. Adult #1 states that C1 has plenty of clothes, shoes, diapers, and cleaning wipes. Collateral witnesses state C1 often comes to school filthy and "reeks of urine". Adult #1 denies this allegation and states C1 takes a bath at 6:00am, 4:00pm, and 8:00pm daily. On this day, LPA observed C1 pulling Adult #1 towards the bathroom to run his bath. LPA was not able to make contact with collateral Witness #3, who was responsible for transporting C1 to school every morning up until September 8, 2021, to confirm the condition of C1's clothing and hygiene upon arrival every morning before school. LPA made several telephone calls and left messages with Witness #3's supervisor, however, the witness did not return phone calls to LPA. Other collateral witnesses state asking Adult #1 to pick up C1 from school and take him home due to him having soiled his clothes with urine and feces. Adult #1 refused to take C1 home but came to the school and cleaned C1 in the bathroom. C1 and C2 are both non-verbal, therefore LPA was unable to verbally interview them. LPA observed children to be clean. LPA was able to inspect each child's bedroom. LPA observed C1 and C2 have more than enough clothes and shoes, all in good repair, some still brand new to allow for multiple changes of clothing if needed daily. LPA also observed C1 having a big supply of "diapers' and cleaning wipes in his bedroom. Collateral witnesses confirm C1 and C2 are both clean and well-groomed children upon recent visits to the home. CSW #1 was interviewed and confirms issuance of a clothing allowance and observation of clothes purchased for C1 with this allowance upon a visit to the home. CSW #1 confirms no concerns about C1's placement or care in the home. Based on the interviews conducted, the information gathered did not produce corroborating evidence to support the above said allegations. Due to inconsistent statements and documentary evidence obtained LPA Edison was not able to determine if the above said allegations occurred, therefore the allegations were determined to be unsubstantiated, meaning that although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that a violation occurred. narrative: On May 3, 2022 at 1:14pm, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Daphne Edison made an unannounced visit to Cormier Small Family Home, for the purpose of conducting an Annual/Required inspection visit. LPA met with Gladys Cormier, Licensee who granted access to the facility. The facility is licensed to care for six (6) developmentally disabled children ages 0-17 years. The census on this day is one (1). The home is set up as follows: This is a single story, located in a residential area. There are four (4) bedrooms, one and three fourths (1 3/4) bathrooms, kitchen, living/dining area, laundry room, and a detached garage. There are no bodies of water on the premises. Licensee has an appropriate First Aid kit in the home which also contain scissors, tweezers, and a thermometer stored in the hallway cabinet. There are no guns/weapons in the home. Hot water temperature was tested and is within a safe range. The facility has two (2) regulation fire extinguishers fully charged. Licensee provides services identified in child's needs and services and individualized health care plans for children with special health care needs. Licensee provides direct supervision to clients. Licensee has written authorization to obtain medical and dental care. All posting requirements have been met. LPA reviewed one (1) client file. LPA unable to conduct client interview due to client is non-verbal autistic. Children in care are supervised and protected at all times. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with staff and others. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Based on the observations made during today's inspection, no deficiencies were cited per Title 22, Division 6, of the California Code of Regulations. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report will be mailed to the Licensee.

Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Connie Goldie and Monica Roberts made an announced pre-licensing inspection on 12/19/22 at 10: AM. LPA's obtained original signatures needed for the following documents that were updated and submitted: , LIC205, LIC400 and LIC610. LPA's also discussed the LIC999 details that needed to be added- utility shut off and upstairs rooms. The pre-licensing inspection for this facility is for a Small Family Home (SFH) license. The inspection was conducted with Administrator William Mattingly and Kendra Mattingly. LPAs observed the following during the inspection: The yard is clean and free of debris. Propane tank was observed to have debris that needs to be removed.. An unattached garage contained a gun safe, ammunition safe and miscellaneous supplies. There is adequate indoor and outdoor activity space. Chemicals are stored in a locked cabinet as well as sharps. Locked and centrally stored medications observed and a first aid kit. The facility has 2 bedrooms with double occupancy, 1 bedroom with single capacity and two client bathrooms. Individual cribs are brand new with mattresses. Adequate supply of linens and bedding were observed. Bedrooms are accommodating of all required furnishings. The dining room has a large table with chairs to accommodate all clients. Carbon monoxide detector and fire extinguishers observed. Facility maintains a current fire clearance. Appropriate forms posted in view of facility clients, facility does not have any open bodies of water. Items that need to be in place prior to licensure include: background clearance of all adults living in the home, updated facility sketch and a new LIC200 with capacity change to four. Surety bond needs to be at $3000. Additionally, the propane tank needs to be clear of debris. A copy of this report was discussed and provided to facility..

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Sara Luman-Gonzalez made an unannounced inspection on June 11, 2024, at 9: A.M. During the inspection LPA met with William Todd Mattingly, Facility Administrator who assisted with the inspection. LPA Luman-Gonzalez conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. Facility staff-client ratio at time of inspection 0 children placed at this time to the 2 staff, the administrator and their fellow licensee. LPA conducted 2 interviews LPA observed 3 resident bedrooms, 2 resident bathrooms. The upstairs is where the administrator and their fellow licensee stay which consists 3 bedrooms and 2 bathrooms. A total of 6 bedrooms and 4 bathrooms. LPA inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant LPA observed the required documentation posted throughout the home as required per the regulation. The fridge, freezer, and pantry were all fully stocked with plenty of perishable and non-perishable food. Menu options were posted on the fridge and a working telephone was available as needed. Smoke Detectors and Carbon Monoxide Detectors were observed to be in working order. There were 2 fire extinguishers that were recently inspected, fully charged. One was placed near the kitchen area and the other was placed upstairs. Fully Stocked First Aid kit is kept in the hallway near the locked medication cabinet. Common Room is available for everyone for watching television or reading or visiting with family. All bedrooms were observed to have plenty of storage space for items, clear space for equipment, and furniture is in good repair. (page 1 of 3) All bedrooms were observed to have clean linens. Hot water was tested at 108 degrees F and all bathrooms were observed to be in good repair. The motor vehicles utilized for the transportation of youths in care were all observed to be in good repair with current registration and insurance. The facility is well maintained and free of vermin. Operations LPA observed the operation of the facility and reviewed the program binder with Licensee. LPA recommended a different way of keeping a roster (See LIC TA) Disaster Preparedness Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan is available for review and Disaster Preparedness supplies were verified. Quarterly drills are practiced and marked in the Licensee's Binder. No deficiencies cited at this time. Staffing/Volunteers All Family members living at the facility are fingerprint cleared to be in the home or are associated via Guardian. The only current staff members are the Licensee and the Facility Administrator. No deficiencies cited at this time Client Records There are no clients currently placed in the home. On May 28, 2025, at approximately 11: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Orlando Areizaga made an announced inspection to the Small Family Home (SFH) for the purpose of conducting a case management inspection. LPA Areizaga met with Administrator, Bill Mattingly who granted LPA access to the facility. On May 6, 2025, Administrator requested a change to the facility sketch. Bedroom 1 has 2 doors. 1 that leads to the Garden and the other that leads into the home. Bedroom 1 provides sufficient privacy to a client in care. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Orlando Areizaga made an unannounced inspection on June 10, 2025, at 11: A.M. The fridge, freezer, and pantry were all fully stocked with plenty of perishable and non-perishable food. Menu options were posted on the fridge and a working telephone was available as needed. Smoke Detectors and Carbon Monoxide Detectors were observed to be in working order. There were 2 fire extinguishers that were fully charged. One was placed near the kitchen area and the other was placed near the client bedrooms. Fully Stocked First Aid kit is kept in the hallway near the locked medication cabinet. Common Room is available for everyone for watching television or reading or visiting with family. All bedrooms were observed to have plenty of storage space for items, clear space for equipment, and furniture is in good repair. All bedrooms were observed to have clean linens. Hot water was tested at 109 degrees F and all bathrooms were observed to be in good repair. investigation_findings: 13On September 14, 2021, at 10:10 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Enrique Hernandez made an unannounced visit to the above facility for the purpose of concluding the investigation on the above allegation and to deliver the findings. LPA met with the Licensee Marlene Creekmore, and together discussed the investigation details. Based on the confidential interviews conducted and file review the allegation cannot be substantiated. During the interview process with C1, LPA obtained inconsistent statements from C1. A1 and A2 denied that they hit or call C1 a pest. A1 and A2 said what they do as a discipline is take away C1's Ipad. In addition, SW confirms that C1's statements are inconsistent. SW said that C1 said that A1 and A2 have not put a hand on C1. SW does not believe that A1 or A2 wanted to hurt C1 but, they need more patience to handle someone like C1. During the times that SW visited the home, no marks or bruises were observe on C1. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. The Department has decided that the allegation Personal Rights is unsubstantiated but if any additional information is received this complaint can be amended and findings can be changed. Per California Code of Regulations, Title Regulations, Division 6, Chapters 4, there are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. Exit Interview conducted, and a copy of this report was left at the facility. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: On Friday May 20, 2022, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes conducted a pre licensing inspection of the facility. At time of inspection LPA met with applicant Kedra Creer. The facility was toured inside and out with applicant Kedra Creer. The home is a one-story residence with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. Bedroom # 1 is furnished with two twin beds and will be the clients bedroom. Bedroom # 2 is furnished with one twin bed and is the sons bedroom. Bedroom # 3 is furnished with one Queen bed and is the guest bedroom. Bedroom # 4 is furnished with one king bed and is the master bedroom Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. Hot water in bathroom number one measured to be 105 degrees, bathroom number two measured 106.7 degrees, and bathroom number three measured 105. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications will be stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals are stored in a cabinet in the locked laundry room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit is located in the laundry room and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors in each bedroom were checked and were operable. There are no guns located in the facility as stated by applicant Kedra Creer. The following required posted items will be made accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, and Visitation policies. () The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is a pool the fence is a mesh fence that is five feet high and has a self closing self locking gate that opens away form the pool.. The applicant will be scheduled for a Component III prior to licensure. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant Kedra Creer on this date.

On November 10, 2022 at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes, met with licensee Kedra Creer who granted access to the home. The purpose of this visit was to conduct a post licensing inspection of the small family home. Presently there are two clients in placement and no client was present during the inspection. The home is single story with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. Bedroom #1 has one full bed, and sleeps C Bedroom #2 has one full bed, and sleeps C Bedroom #3 has a two twin beds, and sleeps the licensee's two sons Bedroom #4 is the master bedroom, it is occupied by Licensee, and her spouse. Bedrooms are arranged so that there is no more than one client per room, and there is one client per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are locked and stored in cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the cabinet in the locked laundry room . Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The first aid kit is in the locked laundry room and contained all required supplies. There are no guns or weapons as stated by Licensee at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 108.3 degrees in bathroom one, 107.9 degrees in bathroom 2 and the clients do not have access to bathroom 3. All facility smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in appropriate working order; fire extinguisher is properly charged and serviced. LPA reviewed 2 of 2 client files all and required documentation was in the files. LPA reviewed 1 of 1 staff file and all required documentation was in the file. LPA observed that there was more than one psychotropic medication on one MAR. There will be a technical advisory note issued for this. LPA explained to Licensee that it is one psychotropic medication per MAR. LPA observed a two day supply of non-perishable and a seven day supply of perishable foods. LPA observed a pool on grounds there is a mesh fence around it with and automatic closing gate the pool contains no water at this time. Based on this post licensing inspection, the home is operating within the limitations of the license and is appropriate for a capacity of 2 children, ages 3-17 years, ambulatory only. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and left with Licensee.

investigation_findings: 13On January 12, 2024 at 9:30 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Nicole Strickland met with Creer Small Family Home Administrator (ADM), Kedra Creer to deliver the findings for the above stated allegation. A Health and safety inspection of the facility was conducted on August 23, 2023, and no immediate hazards were observed. The investigation included interviews with two foster youth (Child #1 [C1] and Child #2 [C2]), two staff (ADM and Staff #1) and three County Social Workers. In addition, county records and facility records were reviewed. On August 14, 2023, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received an allegation alleging staff (Administrator) abandoned client (C2) at hospital. Specifically, it was reported Administrator refused to pick up C2 from the hospital due to C2's behaviors. Confidential interviews and record review provided consistent reports that C2 was taken to the hospital for treatment and evaluation. Confidential interviews and record review revealed Administrator refused to have C2 return to the home due to threats made by C2 and a previous SubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Confidential witness statements indicated that RP1, RP2, and facility staff constantly monitor C1 and C2's interactions. Confidential interviews stated that C1 and C2 would not interact with each other due to their age and maturity level. Confidential interviews revealed that RP1, RP2, and facility staff would not allow C2 to sexually and verbally harass C1. Confidential interviews denied the allegation of sexually harassing children in care. The Department also received an allegation that the foster parent (RP1 and RP2) did not ensure the foster child (C1) lived in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home. Confidential interviews stated that C1 was not safe at the SFH because gang members worked or would visit the SFH. Confidential interviews stated that the visitor had tattoos on the arms and face and believed the visitor was a gang member due to seeing tattoos. Confidential interviews revealed that the RP1 and RP2's adult relatives occasionally visited them at SFH. Confidential interviews stated that RP1 and RP2 would visit with their family members on their side of the SFH in the garage area. Confidential witness interviews revealed that the SFH visitors would not interact with C1 or C2. Confidential witness interview statements indicated that RP1 and RP2's adult family relatives have tattoos on their necks. Confidential interviews indicated that the SFH would not hire a gang member to provide care and supervision for the C1 and C2. Confidential interviews stated that the adult relative fingerprint cleared, owns, and operates an SFH. Confidential interviews indicated that when entering the SFH, the client's bedrooms and living area are located on the right side of the SFH and that RP1 and RP2's bedrooms and living area are located on the left side of the SFH. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 would sneak out of their bedroom window throughout the night. Confidential interviews stated that C1 would return to the SFH the following day. Confidential interviews indicated that C1 would put themselves in an uncomfortable, unhealthy, and unsafe environment by leaving the SFH. Confidential interviews indicated that RP1, RP2, and facility staff provided C1 with a comfortable, healthy, and safe home. Based on inconsistent confidential interviews, the allegations that the foster parent (RP1 and RP2) did not prevent a child (C2) from sexually harassing other children (C1), that the foster parent (RP1 and RP2) did not prevent a child (C2) from verbally harassing other children (C1) in care, and foster parent (RP1 and RP2) did not ensure foster child (C1) lives in a safe, healthy, and comfortable home are unsubstantiated. The allegation may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were explained, and a copy of this report was provided to Small Family Home Facility Manager Cynthia Alvarez.

narrative: On March 4, 2024 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes completed a pre-licensing inspection of Creer Small Family Home. LPA met with Applicant Kedra Creer who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no clients in placement at this time. The home is a two story building with six bedrooms and three bathrooms which are set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 (Master) has one bed will sleep the applicant. · Bedroom #2 (Client's) has one bed, it will sleep one client. · Bedroom #3 (Client's) has one bed, it sleeps one client. · Bedroom #4 (Client's) has one bed, it will sleep one client. · Bedroom #5 (vacant) · Bedroom #6 (vacant) · A great room/living room, kitchen, dining area, three bathrooms, an attached two car garage, laundry room, and the backyard. The Client's bedrooms were arranged so that no more than one client will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the client's belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The six smoke detectors were checked, and they were working properly. There are two carbon monoxide detector one is located in the hallway downstairs and one is located in the hallway upstairs.. The carbon monoxide detectors were checked and they were working properly. The home's central air conditioning module was located on the back porch. The home's hot water heater was located inside the garage. The appliances were in working order. The client's files will be locked inside a cabinet in the kitchen. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable foods. A trash can for storage of solid waste had a tight-fitting lid and was present. The sharp knives will be in the locked laundry room. The medications will be located in a locked cabinet in the hallway. The hot water was accidentally turned off the hot water could not be measured at this time. The home's First Aid kit was accessible and is located in the laundry room and contained all required supplies. Two fire extinguishers were present in the home one is located in the kitchen by the kitchen cabinets and one is located upstairs in the loft area. They were observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. Licensee stated there were no weapons/firearms in the home. There is no pool or other body of water at the home. The backyard where clients will have access to play was completely fenced. The following corrections needs to be made: · Hot water temperature needs to be between 105 degrees Fahrenheit and 120 degrees Fahrenheit. · Lock needs to be installed on laundry room door. · Lock needs to be installed on medication closet. · Lock needs to be in stalled on cabinet housing client files. An exit interview was conducted. Application will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for Licensing.

On 8/9/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Dawn Mahecha made an announced visit to the Crescent Light Small Family Home for the purpose of a Pre-licensing inspection. LPA met with applicant and together did a walk thru of facility. LPA observed the following: This is a two story single family home located in a residential area. This home is a five (5) bedroom, four and a half (4 1/2) bathroom home with two (2) living spaces, kitchen, off wing suite and attached three (3) car garage. Home has backyard and cameras located on exterior of home. Cameras do have sound capabilities and are monitored by applicant. No cameras are located in private restricted areas of home. LPA observed the following: Downstairs Off wing suite- occupied by kitchenette, bathroom, storage closet equipped for stackable washer/ dryer, empty bedroom and moveable gym equipment in adjacent room. Suite is located off single car garage and side door. Doors from inside can be closed off to rest of home and locked Kitchen- Had required perishable and non- perishable food, pantry and locked cabinets for cleaning supplies and knives located under island. Dining room table had required amount of seating for capacity of 6 children. Living space occupied by one (1) sectional, TV mounted on wall. Storage closet located behind kitchen occupied by filing cabinet for client files, medications and first aid kit. 1/2 bathroom. Required signs hanging in kitchen area Upstairs: Bedroom 1: Vacant occupied by two (2) twin beds, closet and dresser drawers available Bathroom #1: Shared between bedrooms 1 and Bedroom 2: Vacant occupied by two (2) twin beds, closet and dresser drawers available Bedroom 3 (attached bathroom): Vacant occupied by two (2) twin beds, closet and dresser drawers available (all doors have inner locking mechanisms) Master Bedroom (attached bathroom): Occupied by licensee, walk in closet, door to bedroom able to be locked with key. Fire extinguishers were checked and up to code. First Aid Kits had proper materials. All passage ways were clear and free from obstructions. All bathrooms maintained Non- slip mats. All adult beverages, hazardous cleaning solutions are kept locked and made inaccessible to children. LPA reviewed emergency disaster booklet set in place for facility. LPA observed planned employee files and children files and required documents were present. At the time of this inspection all smoke detectors and carbon monoxide machines tested audible.
