Continue from page 1 . . . The caregiver (S1) denied the allegation and stated that minor was not threaten to be slap or hit. S1 stated that no corporal punishment is used to the minors in the home and that the minors are talked to about consequences for bad behavior. S1 stated that the minor and her come to an agreement when deciding on a consequence for a given behavior. A second caregiver stated that she has not seen S1 slap or threaten any of the minors in the home. The confidential interviews revealed contradicting statements. One minor refused to give a statement about the home and the caregiver and a second minor reported not witnessing S1 threatening to slap the other minor in the home or hitting the other minor. The second minor reported feeling safe in the home and did not report any concerns. The County Social Workers for both minors stated having no concerns with the care and supervision in the home. Based on the interviews and records reviewed, the allegation is found to be unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the allegation. Copies of LIC9099, LIC9099C, LIC811 and Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

narrative: On April 22, 2021 at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Abdoulaye Traore began a pre-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicants Anne Maina and Humphrey Gachanja who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicants. The applicants were applying for a capacity of 2 ambulatory developmentally disabled with special needs. The home is a two-story home and consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, the room consist of one full size bed- it will sleep one child- currently vacant. There was a living room, dining area, the kitchen, the garage and an additional storage under the stairs. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, the room was furnished with a full-size bed- It sleeps applicants' 12-year-old daughter. Bedroom #3, the room was furnished with a full-size bed (loft style)- It sleeps applicants' 10-year-old son. Bedroom #4, the room was furnished with a full-size bed- it sleeps applicants' 8-year-old daughter. Bedroom #4, the room was furnished with a Cal-king size bed- and a crib- it sleeps applicants and the crib was vacant. It will sleep a foster child. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. Upstairs outside the bedrooms, there was a loft designated game and play area which contained toys and books. It was observed to be safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children to be cared for. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. The fireplace was in the living room area and it was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in a cabinet in the kitchen area. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored under the kitchen sink. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen area. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 111 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible and contained all required items. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. Children files will be kept in a locked filing cabinet located upstairs by the master bedroom. There were no pool or other body of water and the backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. A Component III was scheduled on 04/26/2021 at 10: AM. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 2 ambulatory clients. All requirements were met at this time. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Facility will accept only two ambulatory developmentally disabled children and licensed for a capacity of 2 foster children age 0-17. Facility will serve 2 children that are medically fragile and with special health care needs Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and will be emailed to applicant. The original signature page will be placed in facility file.

The home is a two-story residence, and the home is set up as follows: Downstairs: Bedroom #5: the room consist of a full-size bed; it will sleep one foster child - currently vacant. Bedroom #1: the room consist of a Cal-King size bed and a crib - it sleeps Licensee, and the crib was vacant. It will sleep a foster child/infant. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two foster children are in a room, and there is one foster child per bed. Upstairs outside the bedrooms, there was a loft designated game and play area which contained toys and books. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The bathroom was clean and in good repair. The hot water was tested in the foster children's bathroom was measured to be 113.2 degrees. Proper storage of all food was noted and trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. The backyard is completely fenced and free of hazards. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. LPA did not review any foster child file or complete interview due to census is zero. LPA reviewed two of two staff files during the inspection and noted to have everything. A copy of this report was reviewed and given to Licensee Anne Maina

On May 21, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Crystal Spring Home Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct an unannounced random annual inspection. Currently, there is no client in placement, and the home is licensed for a capacity of two clients (two ambulatory clients and medically fragile). The Facility was toured both inside and out with licensee. The home is a two story building with five bedrooms and four bathrooms. During the inspection, LPA observed that the downstairs consisted of the kitchen, a living room, the garage, a dining area with a large table and one bedroom. Bedroom #5 was vacant, and it consisted of a full-size bed. The medications were stored and locked in a storage container in the kitchen cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The First Aid Kit was in the closet and kitchen cabinet, contained all required items. The garage was inspected and used for storage. The water temperature was tested and measured at 118 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. In addition to the downstairs space, there was also one full bathroom fully functioning and hallway closets for storing coats and shoes. A trash can was observed to have tight fitting cover. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: personal rights, visitation policy, and current menu. The fire extinguisher was observed and operable. The upstairs consisted of a laundry room that always remained locked. There was a master bedroom #1 for licensee and spouse and it consisted of a Calking size bed and a bathroom; The licensee's bedroom is not accessible for the clients; Bedroom #2 was utilized by a biological daughter 17-year-old, the room consisted of a full-size bed, a closet space. Bedroom #3 was utilized by a biological son 14-year-old, the room consisted of a full sized bed, a closet space. Bedroom #4 was utilized by a biological daughter 13-year-old, the room consisted of a full-size bed, a closet space. All bedrooms were arranged for one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawer and closet space for each child's belongings. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and working. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. The upstairs space includes a loft with some furniture, a television and there was an additional bathroom used for the clients. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients have access. All windows and screens were in good repair. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. There was a total of four cameras, the four cameras were located in common areas and outdoor which meet the title 22 camera policy. There were no clients in placement currently. The facility outside grounds were also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to Licensee.

..continued from LIC- Through confidential interviews with the LPA two out of two shared the victim (C1), had an aversion to water, did not like getting their face wet while bathing, and had no swimming experience. Eleven out of eleven confidential interviews revealed C1 was not using a floatation device. It was reported the reason C1 was not using a floatation device was there were two lifeguards present and C1 was only playing in the shallow end of the pool. FM and Regional representative confirmed that C1 presented with signs of autism and was developmentally delayed, although C1 not been officially diagnosed with autism. Eleven people interviewed by LPA and the County Social Workers stated C1 played in the shallow end of the pool without interacting much with the other children during the event. Two out of seven foster parents interviewed reported FM was sitting within five feet of the shallow end of the pool socializing with other adults. Four out of six foster youth interviewed, who were present at the pool, stated they did not interact with C1 or notice C1 in distress. The surveillance video footage revealed that C1 ventured toward the middle and the deep end of the pool several times, without FM noticing. In the video C1 was between the shallow and deep end of the pool while drowning and reaching their arms above the surface of the water, for approximately three minutes. Based on LPAs confidential interviews conducted, and records reviewed the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore the above allegation is found to be SUBSTANTIATED. The licensee is cited on the attached LIC9099D under the Health and Safety code 1550 (c) Conduct Inimical: Conduct which is inimical to the health, morals, welfare, or safety of either an individual in or receiving services from the facility or people of this state. Per the new Civil Penalty laws, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548(d), a civil penalty determination is pending due to the substantiated allegation concerning serious injury sustained to C1. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were provided to FM.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) (analyst name) made an unannounced annual inspection at Cunha Small Family Home located at Wisteria Way. Arcata, Ca at 11: AM, on 12/30/21. LPA met with, Foster Mother (FM), Judy Cunha. LPA conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. FM currently has no placements, but does have one guardianship child. LPA observed three bedrooms, and one bathroom. LPA interviewed FM. LPA did not conduct any client interviews, as there were no current placements. LPA, Whitlow, inspected and reviewed the following: Posting of license, disinfectants/cleaning solutions inaccessible. Refrigerator temperature was below 45 degrees F and freezer Temperature at 0 degrees. LPA observed nonperishable food for one week and fresh perishable foods for two days. There was a working telephone and cell phone. Carbon monoxide detectors and smoke detectors are in working order. LPA observed a fully stocked First Aid Kit, a common room available, dining area furniture in good condition, Medication is centrally stored and locked. Hot Water was between 105-120 degree F. LPA observed a fire extinguisher, clean toilets, and bath and shower fixtures in good repair. There were laundry facilities available. Bedrooms contained required linen and furnishings, FM's motor Vehicle is properly maintained. The facility was free of vermin. LPA is providing technical advisory (TA), in reference to California Code of Regulations, 80023(a): Disaster and Mass Casualty Plan. There were no deficiencies observed. An exit interview was conducted and the LIC 809 was signed and sent to FM electronically. FAS was not functioning properly and did not save the LIC 809 or CARES tool at the time of inspection. LPA generated both again on 1/1/22 and sent electronically to FM at 11: AM on 1/1/22.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Lyta Vue arrived unannounced at the facility on this date and met with Judy Cunha, Administrator. The purpose of the visit was to complete an Annual Inspection using the CARE tool. The facility is licensed to care for four ambulatory children ages 7-17. The facility has one staff. The facility has 0 clients in placement. LPA completed a Health and Safety Inspection of the facility. The facility is a home-like setting, with two client bedrooms for three clients and a Master bedroom for the administrator. There is 1 bathroom and 1 half bathroom for clients and staff. All toilets, showers, and sinks were functioning properly. The living area is spacious, with a bookshelf with books and puzzles, and a TV. The home was clean, but cluttered, and there were no safety hazards observed. The room temperature was comfortable, and no odor was detected. Smoke alarms were in working order, the fire extinguisher was not current and has no inspection tag with date, and a first aid kit was fully stocked. Disinfectants are locked in the laundry room and medications are locked in a hall closet. LPA observed the kitchen to have at least 2 days of perishable food and 7 days of non-perishable food on hand, but there are no clients. Client's bedrooms had clean bedding, along with a dresser and closet which provided ample storage space for personal belongings. There is no swimming pool or other body of water on the premises. There are no firearms or other weapons in the facility. LPA reviewed 0 client files due to no clients in placement. LPA reviewed 1 staff file only due to no hired staff. LPA interviewed 0 clients due to no clients in placement. LPA interviewed 1 staff. Annual document continued on 809c Facility is issued a citation per Title 22, division 6, 83087(e): Buildings and Grounds (e) Every small family home shall have one or more functioning carbon monoxide detectors on every occupiable level of the home, Including basements, and near all sleeping areas as required by the California Fire Code, that meets the standards established in Health and Safety Code Chapter 8 (commencing with Section 13260) of Part 2 of Division 12. The detector shall be audible in each bedroom. Facility is issued a citation per Title 22, division 6, 83008(h): Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies (h) The licensee shall keep at least one operational fire extinguisher in the home, as required by Title 24, Part 9, of the California Fire Code. A signed copy of this LIC-809, LIC-809C, and LIC 809D report was provided to Judy Cunha, Administrator. An exit interview was conducted. Appeal rights were provided.

On October 31, 2024 on 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Abdoulaye Traore arrived at Cynthia Robinson Small Family Home to conduct pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA and LPM met with applicant Cynthia Robinson who led a tour of the entire home. The applicant is applying for a capacity of six children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two- story building with five bedrooms and four bathrooms. The downstairs consists of one bedroom, and it will sleep two non-ambulatory children and has two twin size beds- currently vacant, a furnished living room, a bar area, a dining room with a table, kitchen and the garage. The second floor consists of a master bedroom for the applicant, an office, a large loft with furniture and television, a bedroom furnished with two full size bed to be utilized for two children and currently vacant, a bedroom furnished with one full-size bed and bathroom, another bedroom furnished with a Cal-King-size bed and another bathroom. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children's belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Sharp knives, sharp objects, and cleaners/ chemicals were locked in a cabinet in the garage with a locked door. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 112 degrees. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the laundry room. Two fire extinguishers were observed. The fireplace was in the living room area, and it was properly screened. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies observed at this time. Applicant was advised to contact the department within 30 days of their first placement and the Component III orientation was completed on October 10, 2024. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final review and approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Cynthia Robinson.

On April 2, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez began a post-licensing inspection for Cynthia Robinson Small Family Home (SFH). LPA met with licensee Cynthia Robinson who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out. Currently there is three children placed in the home. The licensee was approved for a capacity of six children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two- story building with five bedrooms and four bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of one bedroom that is utilized for one client and has two twin size beds that were missing bed frames but had storage space for personal belongings. The hallway leading to the bathroom has fire extinguisher #1 and a storage closet storing extra household items. Bathroom #1 was downstairs and was fully functioning with water temperature reaching 112.2 degrees F. The laundry room was accessible to clients but had locked cabinets storing clients files, personnel records, medications, cleaning supplies, first aid kit (missing anti-septic solution), and extra hygiene supplies. There was also fire extinguisher #2 as well as all required postings such as personal rights, emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, and daily schedule in the laundry room. The Kitchen was clean and sanitary with a fully stocked refrigerator and pantry storing perishable and nonperishable foods. There was also a table. There was living room #1 that had a couch and television, living room #2 that had couches and a dining room that had a dining room table with adequate seating. The upstairs consisted of a master bedroom for licensee with bathroom #2, an office, a loft that had a facility sketch posted as well as fire extinguisher #3. There was bedroom #3 that had two full size beds and closet space that was occupied by two clients. There was bathroom #3 that was fully functioning, a linen closet with adequate towels and linen. Bedroom #4 had a full size bed and bathroom #4 that was utilized as a guest bedroom. Bedroom #5 had a cal-king size bed and was utilized for licensee's daughter on rare occasions. The garage stored extra household items and an extra freezer with abundance of foods. The garage was locked at all times. The home has a telephone service. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children's belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Facility cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division Six, Chapter 4. regulation 83088 (c): Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies. See 809D. The client and facility files were reviewed as well as one staff and two clients were interviewed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report, 3 technical assistances and 1 deficiency were discussed and provided to licensee Cynthia Robinson.

Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Jean Stidman made an announced Pre-Licensing inspection on 8/7/23 at 10:15am. During the inspection LPA met with Cynthia & Calleb Aringo, who assisted with the inspection. LPA Stidman conducted a walk-through of the facility inside and out. At time of inspection both applicant's were present and no clients are in placement. The home is a two story four bedroom, three bathroom home. LPA Stidman inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant: Personal Rights OK Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions inaccessible OK_ Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees F OK Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees OK Nonperishable Foods one week and fresh perishable foods two days minimum_N/A_ Menu present and posted_N/A__ Working telephone OK Carbon monoxide detectors OK_Smoke Detector OK_ First Aid Kit fully stocked OK Common Room available OK Dining area (enough seating, furniture good condition, not broke or damaged) OK Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible _N/A Office (locked and privacy) _OK Hot Water between 105-120 degree F (Properly labeled if over 125 degree F_Hot water temp is 107 degrees Farenheit Fire Extinguisher missing purchase/inspection date Toilets wash basin, bath and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature OK_ Soap and Paper towels OK Laundry Facilities(available, work assign dates) OK Bedrooms-required linen and furnishings one bedroom is missing drawer space_ Motor Vehicle properly maintained , lights, tires, registration/insurance and working seat belts_OK Facility free of vermin OK Locked Facilities (open locked storage area/building/sheds) OK Bedroom (required bedding/furniture, furniture in good repair) OK Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Article 03, regulation 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance as the applicant's are "In Process" with Guardian for their background clearance. Facility citation violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Article 07, Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies for 83088(f),(g) and (h) for missing toys, games, books and recreational and educational materials for the children, one bedroom is missing a drawer space to accommodate child's clothing and personal belongings and the fire extinguisher is missing documentation of purchase date or inspection date within the last 12 months. Disaster Preparedness The LIC610C disaster and mass casualty plan was reviewed and available. Emergency Intervention The facility will not do any manual restraints. Staffing/Volunteers THe Personnel Roster LIC 500 has the two licensee's and both of these files were reviewed. Client Records No client's files were reviewed. Special Health Care Needs (SHCN) No clients are in placement. The facility is not licensed at this time. An exit interview was conducted with and a copy of this report was left with Cynthia & Calleb Aringo, applicant's.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted a case management via telephone as a result of Covid-19 related restrictions and spoke with Administrator Irene Morris. The purpose of the phone call was to discuss a client residing in the facility. Based on record review, client (C1, see 811 for confidential names) has been residing in the home since 5/9/2012 and is now over the age range that the facility is licensed. An exception was granted by the Department for C1 to reside in the home until June 2020. Records show there was communication between the facility and Department about C1's placement until 12/1/2020. After that date, there is no record of facility contacting the Department on the C1's moving update. Facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation 80010(a) Limitations on Capacity and Ambulatory status. A copy of this report and appeal rights were sent via email to Administrator for signature.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced annual inspection at D&I Morris Children's Home. LPA met with facility representative Irene Morris. LPA inspected the facility, inside and out. Centrally stored medications and sharps are maintained in kitchen in a locked cabinet. All facility smoke detectors appear to be in appropriate working order, fire extinguisher is properly charged and was last serviced May 20, 2021. There is at least one week supply of nonperishable but not enough supply of perishable foods. The facility is maintained at 74 degrees. Hot water temperature measures 115 degrees. Facility does not have any cameras in the facility. There are no bodies of water at the facility. No firearms or weapons are allowed in the facility. There are two pets in the facility. Administrator, Irene Morris is present at the facility a minimum of 20 hours a week, as verified by staff schedule and interviews. Appropriate staff/client ratios were verified during this inspection. The facility employs 5 direct care staff. Four children's and eight staff records were reviewed with Irene Morris. LPA discussed the following with the Administrator: Incident reporting, including incidents; Provider meetings; recent PINs; and updates to the Program Statement. Deficiencies are being cited during this inspection A copy of the report was left at the facility.

On this date, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced Case Management inspection at D&I Morris Children's Home and met with Irene Morris. The purpose of the inspection was to clear a POC. LPA extended the POC deadline via telephone to 12/6/2021. LPA inspected the home and reviewed client and staff files. LPA interviewed staff and confirmed that some of the required training has not been completed. Some POCs were cleared but some were not. Deficiencies will be issued for the uncompleted POCs. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection.

On this date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced inspection at D&I Morris. The purpose of the inspection was to clear POC for deficiencies issued during last visit. LPA met with Ana and Denise, child care workers. LPA cleared three POCs and extended one POC. LPA also discussed the waiver approved for NMD. Staff said NMD will be leaving the home next week. No deficiencies will be issued. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection.

On this date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo conducted an unannounced inspection at D&I Morris. The purpose of the inspection was to clear POC for deficiencies issued during the 12/21/2021 visit. LPA met with Denisse Yanez, child care workers. LPA was unable to clear the POCs during the 2/25/2022 visit due to a family emergency. LPA cleared POCs. The facility is being cited today because the administrator is not regularly present in the home as by definition of small family home, meaning any residential facility in the licensee's family residence proving 24-hour a day care for six children who are mentally disordered, developmentally disable or physically handicapped and who require special care and supervision as a result of such disabilities. No deficiencies will be issued. A copy of this report was left at the facility at the conclusion of inspection.

On this date Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo arrived at the home and met with Dennis Morris. The purpose of the visit was to make sure the home there were no more kids living in the home. Dennis informed LPA that the home will be shutting down and is surrendering the license as of 05/13/2022. LPA observed there is no more children residing in the home and obtained the licensed signed by the provider.

On October 09, 2024, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez met with applicant Taiye Beoghene for a Component II. LPA went over revisions needed for the application prior to licensure. LPA gave a copy of the notification of incomplete application (LIC 184), Letter of Application Revisions, and additional correspondence to assist with the revisions needed to the application. Copy of this report was emailed to applicant and a signed copy will be placed in the facility file.

On November 22, 2024 on 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Daella Small Family Home to conduct pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Taiye Beoghene who led a tour of the entire home. The applicant is applying for a capacity of three children ages 0 to 17.The home is a two- story building with five bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. The downstairs consists of a locked hallway closet with first aid kit and hair products, a bathroom with water temperature measuring 114.4 degrees, two bedrooms for two ambulatory children that has one full size bed in each room -currently vacant, an office, living room with couch and TV and dining room with table and pantry, Kitchen with perishable and non-perishable foods, a work out space, storage closet, a hallway with fire extinguisher and a locked garage. The second floor consists of a master bedroom with bathroom for the applicant a large loft with furniture and television,a hallway closet stocked with linen and towels, a bedroom furnished with two full size beds to be utilized for two children and currently vacant, a bedroom furnished with one full-size and one twin bed for applicants children, a bathroom and a laundry room that stores cleaning supplies and detergents that must be locked at all times. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed.No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children's belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order.A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. LPA observed there to be no landline telephone service, knives and sharp objects were not made inaccessible to children. The medication was found unlocked in bathroom cabinets. Cleaning supplies/chemicals were unlocked under kitchen sink and in bathrooms. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan and visitation policy were not posted at this time. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: - Lock and store away all sharp objects such as: knives, scissors, forks and butter knives. - Lock and store away all cleaning supplies/ chemicals - Lock and store away all medications - Lock and store away all Liquor - Obtain a land line with a stationed home phone - Obtain a lock box for cash resources - Obtain client folders such as a 3-ring binder - Put a lock on laundry room door - Post facility sketch, emergency disaster plan, and visitation policy. After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant Taiye Beoghene

On December 4, 2024 at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Daella Small Family Home (SFH) and met with applicant Taiye Beoghene. The purpose of this visit was to ensure corrections were made from the pre-licensing inspection on November 22,2024. The applicant is applying for a capacity of three children ages 0 to 17. The home is a two- story building with five bedrooms and 3 bathrooms. Applicant Taiye Beoghene gave a tour of the home. The downstairs consists of a locked hallway closet with first aid kit, hair products, and LPA M. Perez also observed the scissors and medications to be locked and stored there as well. Downstairs also has a bathroom with water temperature measuring 114.4 degrees, two bedrooms for two ambulatory children that has one full size bed in each room -currently vacant a locked office where LPA observed there to be a locked cabinet for clients files/ binders and cash resources. There is a living room with couch and TV as well as a dining room with table and pantry, LPA observed the Kitchen to have perishable and non-perishable foods, the sharp objects such as knives, butter knives and forks were locked in a kitchen cabinet as well as liquor locked in another kitchen cabinet. Applicant obtained a home phone landline that is located in the kitchen. There was also chemicals and cleaning supplies locked and stored away under kitchen sink. There is a work out space, storage closet, a hallway with fire extinguisher and a locked garage. The second floor consists of a master bedroom with bathroom for the applicant, a large loft with furniture and television, hallway closet stocked with linen and towels, a bedroom furnished with two full size beds to be utilized for two children which is currently vacant, a bedroom furnished with one full-size and one twin bed for applicants children, a bathroom and applicant obtained a lock for laundry room door that stores cleaning supplies and detergents that is locked at all times. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closets for children's belongings. Lpa M. Perez observed the facility sketch, emergency disaster plan and visitation policy to be posted near front door entry way. The backyard was observed to be clean and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Corrections made: Applicant locked and stored away all sharp objects such as: knives, scissors, forks and butter knives. Applicant locked and stored away all cleaning supplies/ chemicals Applicant locked and stored away all medications Applicant locked and stored away all Liquor Applicant obtained a land line with a stationed home phone Applicant obtain a locked place for cash resources Applicant obtained binders for client files Applicant put a lock on laundry room door Applicant posted facility sketch, emergency disaster plan, and visitation policy. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of 3 ambulatory clients. All corrections were made. Applicant completed component III orientation during inspection on December 4, 2024 with LPA M. Perez. The request of license will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final review and approval. Applicant was advised to contact the department within 30 days of their first placement An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant Taiye Beoghene.

On January 30, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez began a post-licensing inspection for Daella Small Family Home. LPA met with licensee Taiye Beoghene who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out. Currently there is 1 child in placement. The licensee was approved for a capacity of three children ages 0 to 17. The downstairs consists of a clean/ sanitary kitchen with an abundance of perishable and non-perishable foods, a dining room with table and pantry, an office, living room with couch and TV and a bulletin board with disaster plan, visitation policy, facility sketch, menu, and license posted. The bathroom is fully functioning with water temperature reaching 111.2 degrees. The downstairs also has two bedrooms that are currently vacant with full size beds and adequate drawer/closet space for children's belongings and a work out space, storage closet, a hallway with fire extinguisher and a locked garage. The upstairs consists of a master bedroom with bathroom for licensee a large loft with furniture and television. There is also a hallway closet stocked with linen and towels, a bedroom furnished with two twin size beds to be utilized for two children one which is occupied by the one client and the other vacant. Also upstairs is a bedroom furnished with one full-size and one twin bed for licensees biological children, a bathroom and a laundry room that stores cleaning supplies and detergents that is locked at all times. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The home has a telephone service. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. The client and facility files were reviewed as well as two staff and one client were interviewed. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Appliances were in working order. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and 4 technical assistances were discussed and provided to licensee Taiye Beoghene.

narrative: On June 9, 2021 at 2:45PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams arrived at the Darden Community Care, INC, The Small Family Home to conduct an annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Sherry Ware who granted LPA access to the home. At 3: PM, LPA began a tour both inside and out with the Licensee. There were six children in the home at the time of this inspection. Three clients and three of the licensee children. The home was set up as follows: • Bedroom #1 downstairs has a mattress and it sleeps licensees 18-year-old daughter. • Bedroom #2 downstairs has two twin beds. It sleeps licensees 13 year- old child and 14- year -old child. • Bedroom #3: upstairs is the master bedroom sleeps licensee and spouse. Furnished with an queen-- sized bed. • Bedroom #4: upstairs has a queen- sized bed. It sleeps 14- year-old foster child #1 (FC1). • Bedroom #5: upstairs has a toddler bed and a twin bed. It sleeps 7 -year-old foster child #2 (FC2) and 5- year-old foster child #3 (FC3). Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes was used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The facility has no fire place. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications were locked and stored downstairs in the laundry room in a tool box. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room. Sharp knives were inaccessible and locked in the laundry room. . The first aid kit was located in the kitchen in the kitchen pantry. The facility has two guns that are locked in a closet in the master bedroom. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within regulation requirement. Proper storage of all food was noted. Bathroom #1 downstair has a tight fitting trash can lid. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map and Personal Rights were posted at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There was no pool or other body of water on the premises. Toys were safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children being cared for. CPR and the First Aid cards expired in June 2020. Children and staff records are organized. Administrative records included: A review of one staff and three client's records on this date indicates that all facility. Staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances and required documents. In accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4, there were no deficiencies being cited at this time. LPA issued technical assistance to the facility. Based on this annual inspection, the home was operating within a capacity of three children. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and confidential names List (LIC 811) were given and explained to the licensee along with LIC Advisory Notes were provided to Sherry Ware.

It sleeps 16 year-old adopted son. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. On August 22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at DBA Rosetta Canyon Kids Care Small Family Home (SFH) for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Rhonda Culton who led a tour of the entire home inside and outside. The applicant is applying to serve four ambulatory children ages 0 to 17 years old. Currently there are no clients placed in the home. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of an entry way with a formal dining room with adequate seating, a living room with couches, TV, and a screened fireplace, the kitchen had a dining table, a locked cabinet under the kitchen sink storing cleaning supplies, a locked cabinet for knives/sharp objects, fire extinguisher #1 that was operable, a first aid kit with all required elements, and a refrigerator and pantry that was fully stocked. Bathroom #1 was fully functioning with water temperature measuring 120 degree's Fahrenheit. Applicant was advised not to adjust the water temperature any higher as it should be in the range of 105-120 degrees F. There was a hallway closet storing clothes and shoes, an office space that will store client files and personnel records in a locked cabinet, a bulletin board with all required postings such as emergency disaster plan, facility sketch, visitation policy, and personal rights. Bedroom #1 was also downstairs it was occupied by applicants biological child and was fully furnished with a full size bed. The upstairs had a loft area that was utilized as an office and had a desk, computer, emergency escape ladder, and fire extinguisher #2. Bedroom #2 was utilized for two foster children and had two twin size beds with dresser/ closet space, lighting, and all required bedding- currently vacant. Bathroom #2 had dual sinks, a shower/ bath tub, and a locked cabinet for storing medications/cleaning supplies. The laundry room was locked at all times as it stored laundry detergents/ laundry essential's. Bedroom #3 was occupied by applicants biological son and was fully furnished with a full size bed. Bedroom #4 was utilized for two foster children and had a twin sized bunk bed with railings on the upper tier. There was dresser/ closet space, a desk, TV, and all required bedding- currently vacant. The hallway leading to the master bedroom had cabinets storing extra blankets, linen, and towels. Bedroom #5 was the master bedroom that was locked at all times and had a Cal- King size bed, two closets, and bathroom #3 that was fully functioning. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced, had a gate with a latch and was free of hazards. There were no pools or other bodies of water and no weapons/firearms as stated by applicant. There was a land- line telephone service, all appliances were in working order, and all trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The garage stored extra house hold items and was locked at all times. Based on this inspection, there are no corrections needed at this time therefore, the home is appropriate for a capacity of four ambulatory clients. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. Component III orientation was also completed this day of August 22nd, 2025. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Rhonda Culton.

narrative: During the investigation LPA Turner was informed that the nonminor dependent initially refused medical assistance and declined self-cleaning. The facility administrator respected the nonminor dependent's autonomy while also making efforts to encourage proper hygiene. It was later determined by a physician that the nonminor dependent's condition is chronic and hereditary and not due to neglect or a lack of hygiene. Due to the involvement of a conservator, the facility administrator had to obtain approval before providing any medical care for the nonminor dependent. Once the approval was granted, the facility administrator followed procedures and ensured the nonminor dependent received medical attention and was properly diagnosed. Although the allegations may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur, therefore the allegations are UNSUBSTANTIATED. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three full bathrooms which are set up as follows: Bedroom #1(first floor)- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #2- It consisted of one queen bed. The bed had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep applicants' bio son. Bedroom #3- It consisted of two single beds. The beds had linen, comforters, and pillows. It will sleep two clients. Bedroom #4- It consisted of one queen bed. The bedroom will be utilized for guests. Bedroom #5- (applicants) It consisted of one king bed and a crib for possible infant placement. It will sleep applicants. A living room, dining room, kitchen, family room, laundry room, office space, two car garage, and a backyard. The garage will be utilized to store perishable food and as a storage space accessible to clients The clients' bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients will be in a room. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate closet space for the clients' belongings. There was a smoke detector in every bedroom. The nine smoke detectors were checked and working properly. The two Carbon Monoxide detectors were checked and working properly. The home's central air conditioning module was in the backyard. The water heater was in the garage. The appliances were in working order. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of perishable food and non-perishable food. The home had a trash can for storage of solid waste with a tight fitting lid. The hot water was at a temperature of 114.0 degrees Fahrenheit. There was one fire extinguisher present in the home located in the downstairs hallway. It was observed to be properly charged and inspected by the fire department. There are no firearms in the home. There is no pool at the home. The backyard is fully fenced and free of debris. The home has one Ring Camera on the outside premise of the home. No corrections to be made. Component III was conducted. On March 6, 2025 at 1:00pm Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Emelyn Sanchez P. and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith arrived at the above facility, for the purpose of conducting a Pre- licensing inspection for a Small Family Home License. LPA/LPM met with applicant, Jenelle Thompson who granted access into the home. The applicant and LPA/LPM toured the facility both inside and out. Currently residing in the home is the applicant. Applicant is requesting to be licensed for 2 clients ages 6-17 ambulatory only. The home was inspected and the following was observed: This is a one-story house, with a backyard and a garage in the back. Living Room: There is adequate furniture which is in good condition. The area is equipped with a sofa, two chairs and a television. Home entrance has a wooden door with mounted camera door bell. The side entrance door is protected by a screen door, followed by a wooden door. Windows operational with vertical blind and screens are operational. There is a floor heater in the living area that is turned off and not in use per Applicant. Smoke alarms/carbon monoxide detector located in every bedroom were tested during the inspection and they were all in working condition. Fire Extinguisher was fully charged and available near the entrance to the kitchen area. Kitchen: Is equipped with an operable 5 burner stove, refrigerator/freezer, small kitchen counter appliances. Below the sink is an unlocked cabinet where cleaning solutions are being stored. Dinning Room: Dinning area contains a two seated dining set with round table. Laundry Room: There is washer and dryer in working condition. There is also a working telephone in the laundry room. Report Cont. on LIC 809-C. Bedroom #1: is for the licensee and is equipped with a full size bed, drawer, TV and a closet. Bedroom #2: Will be designated for two children/placements and has two twin beds. LPA/LPM observed a closet space, a small drawer, operable tub, sink, and toilet. Bathroom: is clear of all cleaning solutions with a working toilet, sink, and shower. Outdoor activity space (back yard) free of obstructions. The garage is locked and being used for storage. The home will utilize a Honda HRV to transport clients in care. Current automobile insurance is with Triple AAA. Insurance and registration is current. The following items must be corrected: • Disinfectants/Cleaning Supplies need to be made inaccessible. • Applicant will place a lock on the cabinet located under the kitchen sink. • Applicant will also ensure to make sharps inaccessible. • Applicant will purchase a first aid kit with manual. • The emergency disaster plan must be posted. • Applicant will purchase perishable and non-perishable foods and post food menu. • Applicant will obtain trash cans with lids to place in the kitchen and bathroom. • Applicant will replace light bulbs in bathroom and laundry room. • Applicant will clear containers located in the kitchen/dinning room area and outdoor side patio area. • Applicant will remove all miscellaneous items located in living room, Bedroom #2, and ladder located in the laundry room. • There is concerns for Bedroom #2 due to the tub, sink and toilet as these are a safety concern for children who will be placed in the home. • Doorframe leading into the kitchen needs repairing due to the paint peeling. An unannounced case management inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Christopher Larios and Juliet Robles on 3/29/25 at 2: PM. During the inspection LPAs Larios and Robles met with Administrator Kyis Jeter. The purpose of the inspection was to follow up on information obtained by law enforcement while investigating the facility. On 9/24/24, at 12: PM, San Bernardino County Sherriff's Department Detectives served a search warrant to Destined Greatness SFH located at Sicilian Dr. Rancho Cucamonga, Ca 91730. During the search detectives located at .40 caliber XD magazine, a 9mm caliber Smith and Wesson loaded with seven rounds of 9mm cartridge case ammunition in a dresser in the master bedroom. In addition, law enforcement conducted interviews that concluded the facility administrator provided false identification information regarding facility personnel. The administrator provided law enforcement with the name, description and contact information of a reported witness (Ref. #1, See Confidential Names form LIC811 dated Date) whose identity detectives determined was being utilized by Ref. #2. In addition, law enforcement obtained records from a daycare utilized by the facility. The daycare records revealed an identification card with Ref. #1's information was on file however, the individual photographed on the card was Ref. #2. Per statements obtained from daycare staff, identification is required to sign enrollment forms and pick up the children from daycare. Continued on page Page On 3/13/25, at 2: PM, LPA Larios attempted an inspection for the purpose of delivering investigation findings. A staff (Ref. #2) did not allow LPA Larios to enter the facility and advised LPA Larios to return later when the facility administrator was available. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulations Title Div. 6 regulation 80087(g)(1) Buildings and Grounds, regulation 80087(g)(3) Buildings and Grounds, regulation 80046(a)(1)(a)(2) Exclusions and 80044(a)(2) Inspection Authority of the Licensing Agency. A copy of this report, LIC809D, LIC811 and appeals rights were provided to the above-mentioned facility representative. Exit interview conducted.

Page The Department received a complaint alleging a foster child in placement sustained unexplained injuries while in care. Facility personnel provided inconsistent statements to the Department, placement agency social workers and law enforcement regarding the incident. Initially, the facility reported a plastic highchair accidentally fell over and struck the foster child's (FC1) face on or about 9/02/24, 7: PM, causing no injury. The following morning, daycare staff observed FC1 with an abrasion on the left eye and nose, which later worsened to a bruising with swelling. Daycare staff requested the licensee pick up FC1 and suggested medical follow up. On 9/06/24, a forensic medical exam was conducted on FC1. The exam findings concluded FC1 sustained a nose fracture, facial contusion injuries and swelling of the facial area. The extent of the injuries was inconsistent with the explanation provided by licensee. In addition, the facility failed to seek timely medical attention for the child until they were advised to do so by daycare staff. On 9/3/24, FC1 was treated by a doctor for facial injuries. The doctor observed the child with bruising to his nose, cheek and eye areas and recommended completing x-rays to assess for broken bones or other damage. The doctor reviewed the child's record on 9/27/24 and x-ray results were not on file, indicating it was not completed. Also, the doctor who conducted the forensic exam on 9/6/24 noted the delay in seeking medical care for the child is consistent with neglect. Furthermore, the facility failed to follow reporting requirements. Until advised by the Department on 9/11/24, the facility failed to report the extent of the child's injuries as observed by daycare staff on 9/3/24 and the child's medical visit. Based on information gathered from interviews conducted and record review the allegations are substantiated. The facility is cited for violation of California Code of Regulation, Title Div. 6 regulation 83072(d)(1) Personal Rights, regulation 80061(b)(1)(D) Reporting Requirements and regulation 83075(b) Health Related Services. Continued on page Page Per the new Civil Penalty laws, Health and Safety (H&S) Code section 1548(E), an Enhanced Civil Penalty (ECP) determination is pending due to the substantiated allegations. If an ECP is warranted, a Community Care Licensing (CCL) representative will return to the facility to deliver the penalty assessment. Exit interview conducted. A copy of this report, LIC811, LIC9099D and appeals rights were provided to the above-mentioned staff.
investigation_findings: 13An unannounced follow up complaint inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Christopher Larios and Juliet Robles on 3/28/25 at 2: PM. During the inspection LPAs Larios and Robles met with Administrator Kyis Jeter. The purpose of the inspection was to deliver findings regarding the above-mentioned complaint allegations. The investigation was conducted by Community Care Licensing Division (CCLD) Investigations Branch (IB) State Investigator (SI) Shawniece Poinsette and LPAs Joseph Vargas and Brent Lockhart. During the course of the investigation SI Poinsette conducted interviews with a San Bernardino County Sheriff's (SBCS) Detective on 9/30/24, interviewed a daycare staff and attempted to interview three facility staff on 10/25/24, obtained a SBCS report on 12/09/24, attended an attempted interview of FC2 on 01/07/25 and interviewed a former foster child on 02/05/25. In addition, LPA Vargas and Lockhart interviewed a facility staff, a daycare staff and others on 9/11/24. A record review was conducted by LPAs Vargas and Lockhart on 9/11/24 and copies of medical reports, incident reports and photographs were obtained. narrative: During the investigation, Licensee reported that she was away from home for one night to celebrate her anniversary. In the morning, she contacted her father and she learned that FC1 was fussy and didn't sleep the night before. Therefore, she asked to do a facetime video and she felt that FC1 had an unusual behavior. Licensee added that she rushed back home, and she realized that FC1 medication was not given as prescribed. Licensee's father administered 4 mg of Baclofen instead of 0.4 mg prescribed dosage of Baclofen. Licensee stated that she immediately called 911 and the FC1 was taken to the hospital. A confidential witness reiterated the medication error and added FC1 receiving the wrong dosage wasn't intentional or causing harm to FC1. Additionally, other interviews reported FC1's placement at the SFH was appropriate and FC1 was under a good care. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the Department has determined the allegation that an adult in the home did not dispense FC1's medication as prescribed is substantiated. The SFH is being cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Regulation 83075(d)(4): Health Related Services. This poses an immediate Health, Safety, or Personal Rights Risk to children in care. Exit interview conducted. Copies of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights provided to licensee. During the investigation, Licensee disclosed that the adult in home that cared for FC1 was her father who has been involved in the care and supervision of the children for a longtime. Licensee denied that her father was not trained to provide care for the children. Licensee stated that she was a registered nurse and provided ongoing trainings with her father. Licensee added that she felt comfortable to leave the children with her father and she believed her father made an error in reading the prescription dosage wrong. A confidential witness stated several medication trainings were covered; however, they didn't believe documentation was needed to prove that the trainings have occurred. CPS Investigator indicated that there was no record of medication training, however, the county has already provided a medication administration training in response to the medication error. LPA was unable to obtain any written documentation to show that the father received medication training. Although the allegation may have happened or may be valid, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation that an adult in the home was not trained to provide care to child with special health care needs The Department's finding is that this allegation is unsubstantiated. Exit interview conducted. Copies of this report, LIC 811, and appeal rights provided to licensee

narrative: On February 18, 2022, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Darlene Almaraz-Oseguera conducted an unannounced Annual inspection to the Diaz Small Family home. LPA Almaraz met with licensee Connie Diaz who let a tour of the home. The facility was toured inside and out at 9:30am. There are currently one client in the home. The home is a seven bedrooms and 4 1/2 bathrooms home. The home is set up as follows: • Bedroom 1 # Master bedroom has Cal king bed sleeps licensees. • Bedroom 2 has a hospital bed - sleeps adopted daughter • Bedroom 3 has a twin bed- sleeps bio-son • bedroom 4 has a twin bed and sleeps 1 bio daughter Bedroom 5 has a twin sixe bed and one crib Bedroom 6 has a twin bed and sleeps adopted son. Bedroom 7 has twin bed sleeps adopted son Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The fireplace is properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Medications are locked in the hallway closet next to the master bedroom. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room and under the kitchen sink with tot locks. The first aid kit contains all required items. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in the kitchen cabinet. Licensees had current CPR/ First Aid certificates. Licensee provided proof of 8 hours of continued education training. There are no guns or weapons as stated by licensee at this time. Water temperature was tested and is safe and within regulation requirements. Smoke detectors & carbon monoxide detector in hallways are all rooms were tested and operable. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted at this time. The back yard is safe and free of hazards. There is a huge trampoline, barbecue area, lounging area next to the gym in the backyard. Toys are safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children being cared for. Three (03) children files and three (03) staff files were reviewed. Children and staff records are organized and up to date. Medications and log was reviewed. Administrative records included: A review of staff records on this date indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. In accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4 there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. Based on this annual inspection, the home was operating within the limitations of the license. Exit interview conducted and copies of this report, appeal rights given and explained to the licensee.

On the above date Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Babatunde Aborchie, Cindy Hamilton and Sarah Smith met with licensee Ms. Hannah, who granted access to the home. The purpose of this visit is to conduct an annual inspection of the small family home. Presently there are three foster children in placement and two of the three were present during time of inspection (See LIC 811). The home is a two story with five bedrooms and four bathrooms. During the inspection LPAs reviewed the children and licensee's files. LPAs observed the licensee's First Aid and CPR cards expired on August 19, 2021. A review of staff records on this date indicates that all adults residing in the home or providing care and supervision to children have not received fingerprint and child abuse index check clearances. During the review of the children's files, LPAs observed Client #1 (C1) did not have a separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Record (PMAR) for the prescribed psychotropic medications. Also, licensee did not have accurate written directions for administering the prescribed psychotropic medication to C1. Licensee did not have a file for Volunteer #1 (V1) and no documentation of a Tuberculosis test, criminal background clearance, health screening or Statement of Criminal Record History. In addition, licensee did not have any documentation of completion of required trainings for V1. Based on interviews and record review the facility was cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80066(b)(3)(A), 80066(b)(3)(B) Personnel records. V1 did not have a statement of criminal record history and also did not have a criminal record clearance or exemption which poses an immediate health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. Licensee also cited for violation of Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 1, Section 80066(b)(2) Personnel Records, V1 did not have proof of a Tuberculosis test which poses a potential health, safety or personal rights risk to persons in care. In addition, facility was cited for violation of Small Family Homes, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4 section 83064(f), 83064(g) and 83064(h) Licensee Duties and Requirements, Licensee did not have any proof of completion of any of the required training for V1. Licensee also cited for 83075(g) and 83075(e) Health Related Services. Licensee did not have written directions from physician stating when not to administer psychotropic medications. Based on records review the facility was issued LIC Technical Violations 80071(a)(1)(A), 80071(a)(1)(B) 80071(a)(1)(C), 80071(a)(2), Register of Clients, licensee did not have a register of clients prepared or displayed. Also issued for 83070(b)(12)(A) Child Records, licensee did not have separate Psychotropic Medication Administration Records for C1's medications. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was reviewed and given to Ms. Hannah along with the LIC 811.

During the investigation, LPA conducted interviews with the foster mother (FM), foster child (FC1), (FC2), (FC3), a Grand Son GS and Adult in the home (AD). A confidential interview disclosed that FC1 had weight issues from birth, and the primary doctor was aware of FC1's weight issues, therefore, the doctor made a referral to Loma Linda "Failure to Thrive Clinic". It was added that Desert Regional Center was concerned about FC1's weight in comparison to FC1's age and doctor asked why primary Doctor has not referred FC1 to Loma Linda yet. The confidential interview stated that an appointment was missed on October 14, 2021 due to another foster child in the home was sick and the hospital was contacted to reschedule another appointment. Confidential interview reported on November 10, 2021 that a call was received from the hospital to reschedule FC1's appointment; FM notify Desert Regional Center that FC1's primary physician has made a referral to Failure to Thrive Clinic in Loma Linda. A confidential interview stated that the appointment at Desert Regional Center was a follow up for FC1's weight loss. LPA verified that the referral document was in the child's file. Other confidential interview did not disclose any information regarding the medical appointments, Regarding uncleared adults living the home allegation, a confidential interview stated that the adult came to repair a car in the garage for short period of time and denied any other adults living in the home besides foster mother's sixteen-year-old grand son. Other confidential witnesses stated that they were not aware of an adult living in the home. LPA was unable to verify that uncleared adults were living in the home at this time. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the allegations that foster parent had not been bringing FC1 to medical appointments and uncleared adults are living in the foster home may have occurred, however, are not supported or proven by evidence. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated.

narrative: On June 10, 2022 at 2: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a pre-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. Divine Kindness Small Family Home was previously licensed and has relocated to the above address for a new license. LPA met with applicant Renell Hannah who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are three children placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve six children ages 2 to 17. The home is a story building with four bedrooms and three baths home which is set up as follow: · Bedroom #1 has no beds, will sleep licensee, has a bathroom, kitchenette; it was vacant · Bedroom #2 had two twin-sized beds; it was vacant. It will sleep two foster children. · Bedroom #3 had a twin-sized bed and a baby bed. It was vacant. It will sleep two foster children. · Bedroom #4 had two baby beds. It was vacant. It will sleep two foster babies. · A living room, two kitchens, dining area, storage, three bathrooms, three car garage and the patio/backyard, a laundry room. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Inside the facility there was no fireplace. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored a locked cabinet in the kitchen. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of two days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 107.5 degrees. First Aid kit were accessible with all required items and it was in the kitchen pantry. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pool or other body of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for relocation and license capacity increase will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to licensee

Regarding the allegation that FM did not ensure FC1 was taken to scheduled medical treatments, a confidential interview denied not taking FC1 to a scheduled medical appointment. Confidential interview stated that medical appointment was rescheduled due to illness of another foster child in care. A confidential witness denied observing FC1 was not taken to scheduled medical appointment. Confidential witness was not aware FM did not ensure FC1 was not taken to scheduled medical appointment. Regarding FC1's dietary needs not being met, a confidential interview denied FC1's dietary needs were not met. Confidential interview added that there was a conflict of information when FM tried to notify physician office of the need to substitute FC1's prescribed Pedi sure. A confidential witness observed FM provided FC1 with prescribed Pedi sure. Confidential witness believed physician orders were being followed by FM. LPA received a conflicting information regarding the allegations. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegation that FM does not ensure minor is taken to scheduled medical appointments, FC1's dietary needs is not being met, FM not following Doctor's orders, may have happened or are valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, the allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to the SFH

narrative: On September 7, 2023, at 12: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Karen Beal met with licensee Renell Hannah, who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an annual inspection of the Divine Kindness Small Family Home (SFH). The SFH was toured inside and out with Renell Hannah. The home is a single level home with a three car garage. The home is set up as follows: · Master Bedroom #1- Licensee · Bedroom #2- Aiyana Sudyka · Bedroom #3- Bow Kalke and Oliver · Bedroom #4- Solana · Casita Studio- is vacate Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There is adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are locked and stored in the kitchen cabinet. At 3: PM LPA ended the annual inspection due to the time . LPA will continue the inspection on September 8, 2023. ****Continued on LIC 809-C*** ***Continued from LIC 809 dated 09/07/2034*** On September 8, 2023 at 9:19AM, LPA returned to Divine Kindness to continue the annual inspection. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are locked and stored in the kitchen upper cabinet. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the laundry room. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a locked cabinet in the kitchen. The first aid kit is located in the dining area on a bookshelf. There are no guns or weapons as stated by Renell Hannah at this time. There is no fireplace located in the home. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 108 degrees. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There is no pool or other body of water. Toys are safe, clean, and age appropriate for the age group of children being cared for. One foster child was interviewed due to the developmental ages of the other three foster children. CPR card expires 09/24/23, and the First Aid card expires 09/24/23. Children and staff records are organized. Administrative records included: A review of staff records on this date indicates that all facility staff have received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. Exit interview conducted and copy of the annual inspection and appeal rights given and explained.

Continued from LIC The licensee stated the children in care would get bruises from playing or having tantrums daily, however, she didn't know that she needed to report those injuries. Based on confidential interviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation that licensee did not report child's injury is substantiated. Facility is cited for violation of Title California Code of Regulations (CCR) Division Chapter 1 80061 (b)(1) Reporting Requirements (see LIC 9099D). Continued from LIC 9099-A During the investigation, confidential interviews stated FC2 would have a tantrum whenever school ended. FC2 enjoyed being at school and did not want to leave. FC2 would have a tantrum and fall on the ground. Once FC2 is placed in the car, FC2 would continue to have a tantrum. FC2 would fall in between the seats, refuse to get into the car seat and scream and kick the seats once FC2 buckled in the car seat. FC2 would obtain bruises from the tantrums. Licensee stated that she didn't know how to prevent FC2's behaviors because they occur only during school pick up times. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that licensee did not manage FC2's behavior to prevent injury, may have occurred or may be valid, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegation. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. Copy of this report, Confidential Names (LIC 811) and appeal rights were discussed and provided to Licensee Renell Hannah. Reporting Requirements. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report LIC 9099 along with the appeal rights were discussed and provided to the Licensee, Renell Hannah
