narrative: Regarding the allegation that LS did not report an incident involving minor in care as required. A Confidential interview stated FC1 was playing on the kitchen chair when FC1 fell. Confidential interview did not see injury on FC1's knee. Confidential interview did not report the incident involving FC1 in care as required. LS disclosed that an incident report was written but it did not get sent to the appropriate parties. County Social Worker reiterated that she was not notified or received any written reports regarding the incident. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met and the allegation that LS did not report FC1's injury is substantiated. Facility is cited for violation of Title 22, Division Chapter Article 06 80061(a)(E) Reporting Requirements (see LIC 9099D). A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to the SFH along with the appeal right. Regarding the allegation that LS did not properly supervise FC1 resulting in FC1 sustaining an injury while in care. It was specifically stated that FC1 had bruises on both knees. A Confidential interview denied not properly supervising FC1 resulting in FC1 sustaining an injury. LS stated FC1 was playing and got injured. CSW did not observe or witnessed FC1 sustaining injuries, however, she reported that FC1 was very playful and could be injured while playing. Based on the confidential interviews, the allegation that LS did not properly supervise foster child (FC1) resulting in FC1 sustaining an injury while in care may have happened or is valid, but there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove that the alleged violation occurred. Therefore, the allegation is unsubstantiated at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 811 was reviewed and provided to the SFH along with the appeal right.

Regarding the allegation that licensee handled minor in a rough manner, it was specifically alleged that foster mother grabbed C1 by the back of C1's neck and put foster mother's hand over C1's mouth. On April 25, 2024, LPA Enriquez initiated the investigation at the SFH and obtained pertinent documents. Additionally, LPA conducted a safety inspection of the SFH, no immediate health and safety hazards were observed. During the inspection, LPA interviewed Licensee and C1. LPA was not able to interview C2, C3 and C4 because they refused to be interviewed. On April 17, 2024, Community Care Licensing (CCL) received a complaint alleging that licensee handled minor in a rough manner. UnsubstantiatedEstimated Days of Completion:

narrative: Regarding the allegation that minor in care was transported by vehicle in an unsafe manner, it was specified alleged that C2 reported the licensee's teenage relative drove C2 in the car the other day. Confidential interviews stated licensee's granddaughter drove C2 to the swap meet to buy a hat that C2 had been asking for. It was added that Licensee's granddaughter is 17, has a drivers permit and has only driven C2 once, however, the licensee's granddaughter does not have a driver license to drive independently, therefore, she was not an authorized driver to transport a minor by herself in car without an adult supervision. Based on confidential interviews and file reviews, the preponderance of evidence standard has been met, therefore, the allegation that C2 was transported by vehicle in an unsafe manner is substantiated. The facility is being cited for violation of Title Regulation 80074 (a) Transportation. (See LIC 9099D). An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were provided to facility representative Regarding the allegation that licensee did not seek appropriate medical attention for minor in care, it was specifically alleged that C1 stated that C1 was sick and not feeling good and asked to call an ambulance. During the investigation, confidential interview stated that C1 was not feeling well and was taken back to the home from the pool. It was added that C1 was watched over by S1 and did not have a fever or any other symptoms that would require C1 receiving medical attention. Additionally confidential interviews stated that Child Protective Services (CPS) and the police came to the SFH to check on C1 and did not request C1 to be taken to the hospital. LPA was unable to interview C3 and C4 due to them refusing to be interviewed. LPA was unable to gather additional information. In regard to the allegation that facility staff yelled at minor in care, it was specifically alleged that C2 was getting yelled at for "starting trouble". Confidential interviews denied that staff yelled at C2 or any of the other children. It was added that staff might have a sterner tone in their voice if the children were not listening but know not to yell at them. Additionally confidential interviews concurred that sometimes staff speak more sternly if the children are not listening. LPA was unable to interview C3 and C4 due to them refusing to be interviewed. LPA was unable to gather additional information. Based on confidential interviews, the allegations that that licensee did not seek appropriate medical attention for C1 and facility staff yelled at C2 may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support or deny the allegations. Therefore, the above allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report along with the appeal right were reviewed and provided to facility representative.

narrative: Information obtained during investigations did not confirm the allegation as there were no eyewitness statements regarding the licensee engaging in drug use in the present of the foster children or appearing under the influence of a controlled substance. CCL received an allegation that alleged a lack of supervision resulted in a missing child (FC3). It was reported that FC3 had multiple unauthorized absences from the SFH. Special Incident Reports submitted to the Department indicated that FC3 left the SFH without permission and had a history of similar behavior in other facilities. However, confidential statements provided to the Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) denied inadequate supervision in the home and reported that FC3 would leave late at night or after the scheduled bedtime. Additionally, it was noted that, due to FC3's behavior, supervision during evening hours was increased. Confidential interviews also reported that the licensee took the necessary precautions to ensure FC3's safety while in care. Alarms were installed on the windows and doors, which would alert the licensee to any attempts by FC3 to leave the facility. Further, there were no concerns regarding FC3's continued placement in the SFH, as it was reported that FC3's authorized representative is aware of the behavior and a safety plan will be created specifically to address FC3's tendency to leave the home without permission. CCL also received allegations that the licensee did not provide adequate meals to children (FC1-FC4), licensee did not ensure children had clean clothing, and licensee did not ensure hygiene needs of children were met. Documentation reported that multiple unannounced visits were conducted at the SFH, and the home was observed to have adequate food and the foster children (FC1-FC4) were reported to have sufficient clean, and appropriate clothing. Hygiene products were also observed in the home, and it was reported the children bathed daily. Further, documentation of other confidential interviews consistently reported that the needs of the foster children (FC1-FC4) were being met. Based on confidential interviews and pertinent documentation, the allegations the licensee used methamphetamine in the home while children (FC1-FC4) were present, a lack of supervision resulted in missing child (FC3), licensee did not provide adequate meals to children (FC1-FC4), licensee did not ensure children (FC1-FC4) had clean clothing, and licensee did not ensure hygiene needs of children (FC1-FC4) were met may have happened or be valid, but there is not preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. Therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report, the LIC 811, and appeal rights were explained and given to Renell Hannah.

On 02/15/23, Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Pamela Silva and Ashley Ruacho, conducted an unannounced inspection at the small family home (SFH) above for the purpose of conducting a 2-Yr Required inspection. LPAs met with the licensee of the home, Ms. Sheila Downtain. Currently, there is one (1) minor non-ambulatory client in placement. There are no bodies of water on premises. A physical plant inspection was completed. The facility license, facility sketch and personal rights form were all prominently displayed in the home. All exits, and hallways were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstruction. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors are in working order. Water temperature was tested and was within regulatory guidelines. First aid kit was readily available and complete. Food supplies, both perishable and non-perishable, were checked and found to be sufficient. Knives and sharps are locked in a kitchen drawer. Medications are locked inside a small cabinet located within the laundry room. Chemicals and cleaning products are locked in a cabinet in the laundry room. Ms. Sheila confirmed there are no weapons and/or ammunition in the home. Overall, the facility is clean, safe and sanitary. The following sleeping arrangements were noted: Bedroom # Licensee and partner sleep in it. Bedroom # It has two twin bed and sleeps two adopted adult sons.. Bedroom # It has two twin bed and sleeps two adopted adult daughters. Bedroom # It has two twin beds and sleeps the minor client and one minor legal guardianship daughter. Individual beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good condition. Each bedroom has sufficient drawer and closet space. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two persons share a room and there is one person per bed. There are two full bathrooms in the home, and both are found to be in working order. The licensee is the main caretaker of the home. Client file is stored under lock and key in the file cabinet in the living room. There was no Emergency Disaster Plan for LPAs to review. There was no documentation of emergency drills. LPAs reviewed one (1) client records. Licensee's file was not available on site. Licensee's CPR and First Aid is expired. LPAs checked required criminal record and child abuse index check clearance or exemption for all adults in the home. The client is nonverbal. The client's files contained: Admission Agreement, Medical Assessment, Consent Forms, Emergency Information, Individual Family Service Plan, Immunization Record and Personal Rights. LPAs issued three (3) deficiency citations (see LIC809D) and one (1) Technical Advisory LIC9102TV during today's inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, LIC811, LIC809D, LIC9102TV, along with appeal rights, were provided to licensee, Ms. Sheila Downtain.

The investigation revealed an allegation whereby an unknown minor individual may have contacted the only foster child in placement through Instagram in a sexually suggestive manner of communication and in person at the resource home. Confidential statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegation as the foster child denied that they have been contacted by anyone on social media or in person at the resource home with a sexual connotation. The foster child denied any knowledge of the minor individual described by the complainant who allegedly contacted the foster child. The resource parent stated that no individual has visited the resource home soliciting contact with the foster child, and that she was unaware of any inappropriate contact that allegedly occurred with the child's social media. Other statements obtained during the investigation were unable to corroborate the allegation. Based on the information gathered, the allegation is unsubstantiated as the preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation was not met although the allegation may have happened or is valid. A copy of this report, Confidential Names Form and Appeal Rights were provided to the facility representative. There were no deficiencies cited during this inspection.

narrative: On April 30, 2024, at 9:00 a.m., Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) John Bonilla arrived at The Downtain Home, a Small Family Home (SFH), for the purpose of conducting an unannounced Annual/Required inspection. LPA met with Sheila Downtain, Licensee. The SFH currently does not have any clients in placement. There are no bodies of water on the premises. LPA toured the home and observed the following: the facility license, personal rights poster, and evacuation plan were posted in a prominent location. Exits, hallways and doors were observed to be free and clear of hazards and obstructions. The home had three complete first aid kits readily available, fire extinguisher in home was up to date and charged. Medications are kept in a locked cabinet in the laundry room next to the kitchen. Cleaning supplies are kept locked in the laundry room as well, away from medications. Smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors in the home were tested and found to be working properly. Knives and sharp objects are kept locked in a kitchen drawer. There was observed to be an adequate food supply of perishable and non-perishable foods. There is ample space for activities both inside and outside the home. Licensee confirmed that there were no weapons or ammunition on site. Overall, the facility is safe and sanitary. The SFH was issued one deficiency and one technical violation during this inspection. Refer to LIC809-D and LIC9102-TV. Exit interview conducted. A signed copy of this report, LIC809-D, and LIC9102-TV were provided to Licensee. Appeal rights provided. No further action required.

Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, relevant parties confirmed the allegation. The licensee admitted to restraining client on one occasion due to client attempting to AWOL from the facility. Confidential interviews indicated client was restrained by the licensee on one occasion. Client was held down by client's legs and arms by the licensee. CSW indicated the licensee admitted to restraining client one time due to client wanting to AWOL. The other agency's investigative report indicated the licensee admitted licensee restrained the client on one occasion. Based on the information gathered, the allegation stated above is/are SUBSTANTIATED. A substantiated finding means the preponderance of evidence standard has been met. These violation pose an immediate and/or potential Health, Safety, or Personal Rights risk to children in care. The Small Family Home is being cited under California Code of Regulations Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Article 06. Continuing Requirements 83072 (d)(11) Personal Rights. Appeals rights were provided, and a copy of the report and LIC 9099-D has been provided to the FFA representative mentioned above. On 4/2/24 the Department received a complaint alleging licensee did not prevent client from AWOLing. Based on the information gathered during confidential interviews, relevant parties denied the allegations indicating the licensee would attempt to redirect, call social worker, and call law enforcement when client would AWOL. Confidential interviews indicated the licensee would attempt to convince the client not to leave, would report the AWOL and would call law enforcement. CSW indicated the licensee would call CSW each time client AWOL'd from the facility. CSW had no issues with supervision. Based on the interviews and records reviewed the allegation is/are found unsubstantiated. Although the allegation may have happened or are valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the allegation. Appeals rights were provided and discussed with the facility representative mentioned above. There were no deficiencies cited.

On 6/25/ Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Ramos and Licensing Program Manager Abdoulaye Traore (LPM) arrived at Durojaiye Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct a random annual inspection. LPA and LPM met with licensee who granted access into the home and led a tour of the home. The home is single story-house with four bedrooms and three bathrooms. During the inspection, LPA and LPM observed that the home consisted of a formal living room with sofa and a large dining table, a kitchen, a family room, the garage and four bedrooms. Bedroom #1 consisted of two twin-size beds, and it sleeps an adult (A1). Bedroom #2 consisted of two twin-size beds and sleeps an adult (A2). Bedroom #3 was a guest bedroom that contained a queen-size bed and a twin-size bed currently vacant. Bedroom #4 was the master bedroom and occupied by the Licensee. There were three bathrooms in the home, and they were clean and in good conditions. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients share a room, and only one client per bed. No bedroom was commonly used for other purposes, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for residents' belongings. Beds were observed with appropriate clean linens, pillows, comforters, and mattresses in good repair. The fireplace was properly screened. All hazardous were locked items and inaccessible to residents. The medications, cleaners/chemicals and First Aid Kid were locked and stored in the closet by the living room. Per Licensee, there are no guns or weapons in the home. The LPM and LPA observed the home to be clean and organized. All windows and screens were in good repair. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable. The water temperature was tested and measured at 114.6.F. LPA and LPM observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. The backyard was also inspected, and there were no hazards or obstructions observed. The pool was observed and inspected to be inaccessible by a five-foot mesh fence that had a self-latching gate that swings outward as required. There were six cameras in total, three of them were in common areas of the home and the other three were outdoors and meet the title 22 camera policy. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

On April 16, 2025, at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Erika Butler, arrived at Eason Small Family Home for the purpose of conducting a Pre-Licensing Inspection. LPA with Applicant Geremy Eason who granted access to the home and together a tour of the interior and exterior home was conducted. The home is set up as follows: This is a three bedroom, one bathroom home located in a residential area. The home consists of a living room, dining room, kitchen, laundry space, and backyard area. Living room: is equipped with mounted TV, sectional couch, ottoman, fireplace with a door, exercise bike and cabinet. Dining room: is equipped with a table with 6 chairs, file cabinet, and printer. Kitchen: is equipped with a refrigerator/freezer, a six burner gas stove (all burners were operational at the time of the inspection), and microwave. Sharp knives will be kept inaccessible in a locked cabinet in the laundry room. LPA observed a covered trash can. LPA observed ample and non-perishable food items. The Applicant will ensure that three nutritious meals and snacks will be provided to the clients. 809 continued on page 1 of Bedroom #1: Applicants bedroom equipped with queen bed, crib, drawer space, adequate closet space, adequate lighting, and window with bar. Bedroom #2: used for belongings for their baby, shoe cabinet, drawer space, adequate closet space, adequate lighting, and window with bar. Bedroom #3: client's bedroom equipped with twin bed, drawers space, adequate closet space, lighting, and window bars. Bathroom: Bathroom was observed to be clean and in working condition. Vehicle: The Applicant will use a Mercedes GLE to transport client. Insurance is valid from April 6, 2025 - April 6, 2026. The vehicle was observed to be in good condition. The home's temperature is maintained by central air/heating. LPA observed two fully charged fire extinguishers which are located in the hallway, and in the cabinet. Extra linens will be stored in cabinet in the hallway. The smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. First Aid kit was found to be be complete with required items. Disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked cabinet in the hallway. LPA reminded Applicant to ensure the following when children are in placement: Children are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. Applicant acknowledges abuse reporting requirements. Applicant will ensure grievance process, Disaster Plan, discipline policies and procedures will be posted in dining room area. Report continued on LIC 809C. (Page 2 of 3) During the inspection, LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. Applicant informed that the following corrections will need to be made: Applicant will purchase a lock box for refrigerated medication. Applicant will remove bars from the remaining windows. Applicant needs to set up a Guardian Account. LPA informed Applicant that a Component II meeting will be held April 22, 2025, at AM. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of report will be emailed to Applicant Geremy Eason.

Email revisions to erika.butler@dss.ca.gov. The Applicant's fingerprints and fire inspection are pending. A copy of this report will be emailed to the Applicant, Geremy Eason..

On May 13, 2025, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Erika Butler conducted a Small Family Home (SFH) Component III office meeting with Applicant, Geremy Eason . LPA Butler met with Applicant to discuss forms required to be maintained, available, and posted at the facility for inspections. We discussed child and personnel records that are required to be documented, retained and available for inspection. We also discussed specific requirements, concerns and issues operating a SFH, such as, reporting requirements, personnel requirements, supervision, intake issues, compatibility, removal/discharge policies, complaint procedures, transportation, health services, food, hygiene, visitation, personal property, searches, and community sensitivity. Licensee is pending revisions to Program Statement. A copy of this report was provided to the Applicant, Geremy Eason.

On 4/22/22 at 9:26AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the Small Family Home to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Maria Edano and informed of the purpose of the visit. Safety precautions were taken, including mask-wearing and pre-visit screening call. The CARE Inspection Tool was used to conduct this inspection. The facility is clean, tidy, and free of obstructions and serious hazards. There are two double-occupancy bedrooms downstairs, currently with one resident to each room. Hot water and room temperatures measured within permitted ranges, at 114. F and F, respectively. Linens are clean, and bathroom and kitchen are in sanitary condition. Food meets the quality and quantity standards to meet the needs of the residents in care. Caregivers are certified in First Aid/CPR and have background clearances associated to the facility. Facility files are organized and complete. At 10:30AM, LPA observed that the medication administrator records (MARs) for resident R1 (See LIC Confidential Names) did not log psychotropic medications separately. Fluoxetine and Clonidine should be logged on separate logs each. LPA printed a copy of the LIC 622B Psychotropic MAR at visit. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Chapter 4, Article 6, Section 83070(b)(12) Children's Records. See attached LIC 809-D. The following were observed during visit and advisories issued (See attached LIC 9102s): During file review, LPA observed that the most current JV-220 had not been received by the social worker yet, authorizing the current psychotropic medications for resident R1. Licensee checked email and could not find an email from social worker. Physician's orders are maintained, and the MAR reflects administration follows prescribing physician's orders. The previous JV-220 was available for review. LPA advises that Licensee continue to follow-up with social worker to ensure documentation of authorization is on file. During file review, LPA observed that there was no LIC Register of Facility Clients, or version of client roster. LPA provided the form at visit, and licensee completed at visit. LPA advises that Licensee ensure to maintain this form in a central location in the home, updating whenever there are changes to residents in care. During file review, LPA observed that the personnel records did not contain a scan of Licensee's driver license. Licensee's driver license was observed to be valid and current. LPA advised that copies/scans of the driver licenses for all facility staff/caregivers who drive residents be maintained in the personnel records. During tour and file review, LPA observed that there were no copies of the menus for the past 30 days, reflecting what was served. LPA advises that Licensee ensure copies of weekly menus are maintained for at least 30 days. During tour, LPA observed multiple dog feces around the backyard and side yard. LPA advises, as technical assistance, that these be picked up to maintain the outdoor activity space in safe and hazard-free condition. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Maria Edano, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/6/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted a case management visit at the facility and met with Licensee Marie Edano. The visit was announced. The purpose of this visit is to confirm the transition of the facility to a new location. The prelicensing inspection at that location was completed just before this visit, and no deficiencies were observed. Licensure of the new site is anticipated for 4/7/23. Licensee plans to move over fully to the new site this weekend. LPA obtained the old license and will send the new license by 4/7/23. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Marie Edano, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 4/6/23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins conducted an announced and scheduled prelicensing inspection and met with Licensee Marie Edano. There are currently two clients in the licensee's care, who are on an outing with Licensee Ramon Edano. The facility is clean and tidy. The smoke detectors were observed to be working, and hot water in the client bathroom measured within the permitted range. The kitchen is stocked with food to meet the needs of the clients in care. Bathrooms are ready for use, with shower curtains, toiletries, and linens. Medications and sharps will be stored in a locked cabinet inside, and client files will be stored in a separate locked cabinet in the garage. Personnel files will be stored inside. The first aid kit will be maintained in the garage cabinet. There are three client bedrooms, with one double-occupancy and two single-occupancy rooms. The single-occupancy bedrooms are furnished and ready for the two clients in care and are decorated similarly to their rooms at the old facility site to ease the clients' transition over to the new site. Licensee plans to move over completely this weekend once licensed. No deficiencies were observed, and there are no pending items. Licensure is anticipated for 4/7/23. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Marie Edano, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

On 7-19-23, 9:09AM Licensing Program Analysts George Karkazis and Deputy Director Kevin Gaines conducted an unannounced Post Licensing Inspection at listed facility. LPA and Deputy Director met with Marie Edano, Licensee and toured the facility inside and out. Safety precautions were taken including screening call. The Small Family Home is licensed to serve four clients. Present during the inspection were one staff and no clients. At 9:25AM LPA Karkazis reviewed client and staff files. All client and staff files were complete, current, and in order. Files were stored in a locked cabinet in the garage. At 10:45AM, LPA Karkazis toured the facility. LPA Karkazis observed four bedrooms and two bathrooms. LPA observed facility license, personal rights, facility sketch, meal menu, and other forms posted on the walls throughout the facility. LPA Karkazis tested the water temperature and found it to be 111 degrees which is in range. The thermostat read 73 degrees, which is within range. Sharps were locked and chemicals were safely stored. There were two days of perishable foods and seven days non-perishable foods present. The medication was also stored and locked in the upper kitchen cabinet. The facility is in good repair and clean. LPA Karkazis interviewed one staff and no clients, no clients present. At 10:56AM LPA Karkazis toured the backyard. There were no open bodies of water. The backyard was in good repair and clean. At this time there were no deficiencies. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed and a copy of this report was given to Marie Edano, Licensee.

On 04/12/24 at 10AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Celeste Aparicio, Assistant Program Administrator (APA) Angela Carmack, and Policy Analyst (PA) Jennifer Scott made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of conducting the facility's annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee's Ramon and Marie Edano who helped facilitate the inspection and were informed of the purpose of this inspection. The CARE Tool was used to conduct this inspection. At the beginning of the inspection LPA, APA, and PA started with the physical plant section of the CARE tool by conducting a walkthrough of the facility inside and out. LPA observed a four-bedroom house with a dining area, kitchen, living room and client bathroom located in the hallway. Client bedrooms were supplied with proper bedding including clean linens and lighting in accordance with the client's preference/needs. Sufficient drawer space to accommodate the child's clothing and personal belongings was provided and located in the dining area and the garage due to the client's behaviors. All toilets, sinks, bathtubs, and showers were maintained in a safe and sanitary operating condition. LPA observed a smoke alarm and carbon monoxide detectors located in the hallway. In the kitchen LPA observed the sharp knives and scissors to be in a locked cabinet, there was sufficient two day perishable and seven day nonperishable food supply, a menu posted on the refrigerator, and a proper supply of utensils for the clients to use when dinning. LPA opened the cabinet under the kitchen sink and observed one container of disinfectant cleaning solution wipes located inside a cabinet. This cabinet is accessible to the clients in care. LPA issued a citation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Section 83187(r)(3) Buildings and Grounds. A fire extinguisher was observed on a kitchen wall in case of emergency. A second fire alarm was observed to be in the dining area and appeared to be in working condition. Continued on LIC809-C... The house thermostat read at 68 degrees and water temperature measured at 105.6F. LPA and PA made their way to the backyard of the facility where the following was observed: the licensee provided outdoor activity space with a wide open area for the clients to play, there was a rusty shovel, fence door without secured wiring, and metal pole of the ground of the back yard. LPA issued a technical violation for the objects observed in the backyard. APA and PA reviewed two client files and LPA reviewed three staff files. All files were complete and organized. LPA is issuing one technical violation for one staff member lacking a health. LPA conducted an exit interview with Licensee, Marie Edano, at 4:15PM. A copy of this report was provided at the completion of this inspection.

On 04/02/ Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs), Celeste Aparicio and Will Ea made an unannounced visit to the facility for the purpose of conducting the facility's annual inspection. LPAs met with Licensee Marie Edano, and informed the Licensee on the purpose of this inspection. The CARE Tool was used to conduct this inspection. LPAs reviewed the facility's plan of operations, client files, staff files, and conducted a walk through of the facility inside and out. During the facility walk through LPAs observed the facility to be maintained at 68 degrees, hot water temperature to measure within range, a large outdoor activity space free from hazards, and each child to have their own bedroom and beds equipped with clean comfortable mattresses, blankets, and pillows as needed. Overall the facility appeared to be clean, safe, sanitary, and in good repair. No clients were present at the facility during the time of the inspection due to clients being at school. All clients are nonverbal. LPAs reviewed 2 of child's records and 4 of staff personnel files on site at the facility. LPAs interviewed 1 of staff on site to discuss the facilities policies and procedures of operation. (See page LIC809-C) PAGE During the personnel file review, LPAs found that staff S3 and S4 (See LIC 811) does not have a background clearance associated to the facility. LPAs informed licensee about the need to remove the staff from the premises. LPAs identified three areas in which there were Technical Violations. (See associated LIC9102 forms). LPAs are issuing citations of California Code of Regulations (CCR), Title 22, Sections 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report, the LIC 811, LIC9102s and the licensee's appeal rights were provided to the Licensee, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

deficiencies.title:
Criminal Record Clearance

(e) All individuals subject to a criminal record review pursuant to Health and Safety Code Section 1522 shall prior to working, residing or volunteering in a licensed facility

narrative: On February 10,2021, at 9:00 am Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Stephanie Hudak and Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams conducted a component II meeting with applicant Sandra Emele. LPM Hudak discussed the corrections and or revisions needed for her application. · Applicant confirmed that Amara is her daughter that is a backup staff, and does not live in the home. LIC 501 will not be required for application purposes. · Children's medication regulations. The children can decline the medication, it should be documented in the plan of operation. Review the Technical Support Program medication guide for children and add information to plan of operation, i.e., JV 220, court authorizations for psychotropic medications as needed. · Contact regional center to inquire about Vendorization classes after getting licensed from CCL. · Admissions policy, we need to ensure you're addressing compatibility. Types of clients that the home will not take. Needs and service plans, explain that everyone is apart of the needs and service planning. · Children should be supervised at all times. All activities should be agreed by all the parties, social worker and regional center. Make corrections to children be unsupervised in the community. ·Please address special diets in the sample menu. ·House Rules / Sign in and out procedures; some clients based on developmental level may not be able to be unsupervised. ·Adults cannot share a room with a child and 2 children per bedroom per regulations. ·Proper eviction procedures. Children placed via County require 14 to 30 day notice to remove to the Social Worker. Regional Center also has seperate policy for removal of children, please address. ·Transportation policy: please research new seatbelt laws and revise plan. LPM Hudak stated applicant will have up to 30 days to submit corrections/revisions, (DUE by 3/10/21). LPA Williams will then review the corrections and will contact Ms. Emele to schedule the pre licensing inspection. Based on today's discussion applicant's home can only meet the needs of one (1) child due to her own children living in the home as well. Exit interview conducted and copy of this report given and explained to applicant.

On April 08, 2021 at 10: AM Licensing Program Analysts (LPA) Kourtney Williams began a pre-licensing inspection for a Small Family Home license. LPA met with applicant Sandra Emele who led a tour of the home. The home was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant is applying for a capacity of two ambulatory children. The three-story condominium home consists of: Downstairs first floor: Bedroom #1- The room was furnished with two twin-size beds. It sleeps applicant's 12-year-old son. The other twin bed is currently vacant. Upstairs second floor: Office area, kitchen, living room, dining area, a common restroom, laundry room, storage area and a patio with a sliding door. Upstairs third floor: Bedroom #2- The room was furnished with two twin-size beds. It sleeps applicant's 14-year-old daughter and a -16-year-old daughter. Bedroom #3- Master bedroom. It sleeps applicant/licensee. The room consists of a twin-sized bed and a bunk bed. Applicant said this is extra and understands no children will sleep in there. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and working properly. The garage has scooters, a bike, and a skateboard for children to play with. Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. The home has a house telephone. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medications are inside a locked box on top of the second refrigerator in the kitchen. The first aid kit is located on top of the second refrigerator in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored under the kitchen sink. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored underneath the kitchen sink. There were no guns or weapons as stated by Applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 114 degrees Fahrenheit. Proper storage of all food was discussed. The kitchen trashcan has a tight-fitting lid. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. There are three parks located inside the gated community for residents only. There is a basketball court located inside the gated community. There is a resident pool located in the center of the gated community. The pool meets all of the licensing requirements. The pool is accessible to residents using a small electronic key. Applicant/ licensee's pool key is inaccessible to children. Based on this inspection, the home is appropriate for a capacity of one ambulatory client, however, the licensee needs to add one trash-can with a lid inside bathroom #1 also inside common area restroom on the second floor. Applicant needs to add a thermometer to the first aid kit. After the correction is completed, the applicant will notify LPA Williams. The applicant has been scheduled for a Component III on Wednesday April 14, 2021. The request of License will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval once the component orientation is completed and the correction has been made. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report was discussed and provided to applicant this date.

On April 19,2021, at 10:00 am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kourtney Williams and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Stephanie Hudak conducted a Small Family Home (SFH) Component III virtual orientation with applicant Sandra Emele via Zoom due to COVID-19 pandemic. During the Component III, LPM and LPA went over rules and regulations governing facilities licensed by Community Care Licensing including regulations specific to SFHs. The information presented to applicant was to assist the applicant on the maintenance and operation of the facility as well as provide applicant with information to avoid potential problem areas. LPA emailed applicant LIC 311E, entitled, Records to be Maintained at the Facility-Small Family Homes. This form provides a list of all licensing related forms to be used by SFH providers for facility, client and staff documentation and record keeping. Most forms will also be reviewed during post, annual, and complaint inspections. It was also recommended to Sandra Emele to complete Mandated Reporter for Child Abuse training online at the following address: https://mandatedreporterca.com/ During the Orientation, LPM also reviewed Electronic Special Incident Reporting (ESIR) as an option for the applicant to use during operation of the SFH. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Sandra Emele

narrative: On December 07, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie conducted an unannounced complaint inspection to the Small Family Home (SFH) and met with licensee (LS) Sandra Emele to initiate an investigation for the above allegations between LS, FC1, and FC2. LPA B, Aborchie conducted health and safety inspection with no immediate concerns and conducted interviews with licensee (LS) and staff #1 (S1). In addition, LPA M. Chavez conducted collateral interviews with FC1, FC2, and County Social Workers. Regarding the above allegation that licensee and an adult in the home handled foster child in a rough manner, it was specifically reported that LS grabbed FC1 by the wrists and pulled FC1 into the house and grabbed FC1 by the feet and dragged FC1 across the floor. During investigation, a confidential witness stated that LS was dragging FC1 inside the SFH and even recorded the incident occurring. Another confidential interview disclosed that they received a blurry image of what appeared to be FC1 being dragged down the hallway by an adult man. However, other interviews denied handling any foster children in a rough manner. LPA's received inconsistent information. Regarding the above allegation that licensee yelled at foster children, a confidential interview disclosed that LS does not yell at foster children in home however, when necessary, LS will use a higher voice level to redirect foster child's behaviors. Another confidential interview disclosed that LS would yell but not a lot. LPA received a conflicting information. In regard to licensee did not prevent foster child from being harmed by another child and did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for foster children allegations, a confidential interview disclosed that a child at the SFH would hit, curse, and push FC1 and LS could not control the child nor discipline the child. In addition, confidential interviews disclosed that there was an incident where the child was throwing rocks at FC1 and FC2 and LS could not get the incident under control ultimately leading to calling the police for help. As a result, FC1 did not feel that the SFH was a safe and comfortable environment. Furthermore, confidential interview disclosed that when living at SFH FC1 always felt nervous and had anxiety and living there felt like a jail. Another confidential interview disclosed that staff always ensured supervision and at no time has a child hit another child. Regarding the above allegations adult in the home spoke inappropriately to and threatened foster child. It was specifically reported that an adult male threatened FC1 that he would pour ice cubes down FC1's shirt after telling FC1 no to going outside and that an adult female told FC1 to shut up after throwing FC1 on to a bed. It was also specifically reported that an adult female told FC2 "your mother is a bad mother. She's not worried about you." A confidential interview disclosed that no adult in the SFH has ever threatened foster children and it was specifically stated that FC2 constantly called biological mother to report dislikes in the home and would sometimes make-up stories. Another confidential interview disclosed that adults in the home told FC2 that FC2's biological mother didn't care about FC1 and FC2 because she isn't doing her classes. In addition, confidential interview disclosed that an adult male tried to trip FC2 then pulled down FC'1 shirt to pour ice onto FC1's body. Regarding the allegation that resource parent did not administer foster child's medication in a timely manner. A confidential interview disclosed that when FC2 was sick FC2 did not receive medicine. Another confidential interview disclosed that both FC1 and FC2 do not have any doctor prescribed medication but when FC2 had a cough or upset stomach, FC2 was given an over-the-counter remedy. Another confidential interview disclosed that FC2's biological mother prescribed FC2 an over-the-counter medication for a cough. In addition, confidential interview stated that when FC2 was on the phone with bio-logical mother the mother heard FC2 cough and then stated that FC2 coughed because FC2 was not being given the over-the-counter medication. LPA received a conflicting information. Based on interview and record review, the allegations that licensee and an adult in the home handled foster child in a rough manner; licensee yelled at foster children; licensee did not prevent foster child from being harmed by another child; licensee did not provide a safe and comfortable environment for foster children; Adult in the home spoke threatened and inappropriately to foster child; and licensee did not administer foster child's medication in a timely manner may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Licensee.

narrative: In regard to the allegation that licensee forced the minors to sleep, it was specifically reported that LS made FC1 and FC2 go to bed between 5:00PM and 6:00PM. During a confidential interview it was stated that LS would make FC1 and FC2 go to bed at 5:00PM while the sun was still up because LS is tired. Another confidential interview stated that FC1 and FC2 are sent to their room after dinner so that LS can sweep and mop the downstairs area after dinner. Then, FC1 and FC2 turn in their tablets at 8:00PM so they can go to bed at 9:00PM. In regard to the allegation that licensee denied the minors access to food, a confidential interview stated that FC1 and FC2 have freedom to get snacks in between meals and that LS prepares meals daily. Another confidential interview stated that LS provides food, and it is fine. LPA didn't receive any additional information. Regarding the allegation that licensee demonstrated inappropriate form of discipline, it was specifically reported that when FC1 misbehaved, the one-on-one staff would throw FC1 over his shoulder. A confidential interview disclosed that there was a time FC1 went outside without permission, therefore, FC1 was dragged back inside by the wrists by LS. Confidential interview also disclosed that another time when FC1 was in trouble an adult picked FC1 up and threw FC1 into the bedroom. Another confidential interview stated that the LS disciplines FC1 and FC2 by taking away their tablet privileges or time-out in their bedrooms. In regard to the allegation that licensee allowed a minor to provide care and supervision to other minors in care, it was specifically reported that there is a fifteen-year-old foster child in the SFH that at times has supervised FC1 and FC2. During a confidential interview, it was disclosed that when LS went to the store there were no adults in the home and that a fifteen-year-old watched FC1 and FC2 while LS was at the store. Another confidential interview disclosed that LS's daughter who is in college comes home on the weekends and supervises FC1 and FC2 and has fingerprint clearance. Based on interview and record review, the allegations that LS forced the minors to sleep; LS denied the minors access to food; LS demonstrated inappropriate form of discipline; LS allowed a minor to provide care and supervision to other minors in care may have occurred, however, there was not a preponderance of evidence to support the alleged violations, therefore, these allegations are unsubstantiated at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Licensee.

narrative: On June 11th, 2025, at 10: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Claudia Aguilera arrived at Eden Loving Home Small Family Home (SFH) to conduct an unannounced annual licensing inspection. The Facility was toured both inside and out with Licensee Sandra Emele. The home is a three-story building with six bedrooms and five bathrooms. Upon entry of the home, LPA observed a receiving area with a sectional couch, message chair, and workout equipment. LPA also observed a small office that included a small couch, desk, computers, printer, and filing cabinet. Bedroom #1 is located downstairs, it currently vacant it included two empty twin beds, closet, and storage space readily available for future clients. Bathroom #1 is also located downstairs; the bathroom was fully functioning. A closet was also observed downstairs, and it is utilized for guests' coats. The hallway led to the kitchen that was fully inspected. The knives/sharps are kept locked under the kitchen sink. The medication box was also located in a kitchen cabinet and observed to have a lock. The first aid kit was also observed to be in a kitchen cabinet and easily accessible to clients. The fire extinguisher was observed to be operable and located in the kitchen. The kitchen included a large dining room table with sufficient seating, in addition, three chairs were available in the kitchen island for additional seating. LPA also observed a trashcan in the kitchen that contained a tight-fitting cover. The garage was also inspected and observed to store two refrigerators, a freezer, and it is used for additional storage and one parked vehicle. The family room was also located downstairs and included a large sectional sofa, television, a basket with blankets, and a covered fireplace. The upstairs consisted of Bedroom #2 occupied by licensee's biological daughter which also includes bathroom #2. Bedroom #3 was vacant with two twin beds, a closet and storage space for future clients. Bedroom #4 was also vacant with two twin beds, a closet and storage space for future clients. Bathroom #3 was in the hallway; the bathroom was inspected and fully functioning. Bedroom #5 is occupied by licensee and always remains locked which also includes bathroom #4. All bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two clients share a room and one child per bed. No room was commonly used for other purposes other than a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. Bedroom #6 is located on the third floor which includes a loft and bathroom #6 which was occupied by licensee's biological son. The water temperature was tested and measured at 118.8 degrees F. LPA observed a minimum of seven-day non-perishable and a three-day perishable supply of food. One fire extinguisher was observed and operable. All windows and screens were in good repair. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and operable. There were no guns or weapons in the home as stated by Licensee. The following required posted items were observed accessible: personal rights, visitation policy, emergency numbers, and license. The backyard was also fully inspected, no hazards or obstructions were observed. There are two cameras, one located at the entry door and one in the backyard which meet the Title 22 camera policy. Based on today's inspection and observations, there are no deficiencies being cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was provided to Licensee.

On Friday 11/20/20 at 10:15AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made an unannounced visit to the house for a prelicensing inspection. LPA met with Applicant Ella Bell. Safety precautions were taken in regard to COVID-19, including wearing masks, maintaining social distance, and using disinfectant / hand sanitizer. The house is a two story, tan house in a residential neighborhood. The house is clean, tidy, and fully furnished. There is a front living room, dining room, kitchen, family room, garage, and powder room downstairs. Knives are kept in a bowl on a high shelf in a cabinet above the refrigerator. They are not locked but are not easily accessible. Chemicals and cleaning solutions are kept in a locked bin in the garage. Laundry detergents are stored on a high shelf above the washer and dryer. Applicant plans to use prudent parenting when it comes to items that pose a risk. Youth are not permitted in the garage and will not have access to the laundry detergent or chemicals bin. If a youth is a bit taller, applicant agreed that knives can be moved to an even more secure location. Additionally, glassware in the upper cabinets and in the dining room cabinet can be secured. The kitchen and cabinets are fully stocked with food that is quality, varied, and not expired. The fire extinguisher was cleared by the fire marshal and is stored under the sink. The first aid kit will be stored in an upper cabinet in the kitchen. The first aid kit was observed to be missing tweezers, scissors, and thermometer, which applicant agreed can be placed in / added to the kit. There are three double-occupancy bedrooms upstairs, a bathroom, and a master bedroom and bathroom. One of the rooms is for applicant's two children. The other two rooms are for clients. Each client bed has mattress pads and clean linens. The bedrooms each have a closet, dresser, and a television. The televisions are wide screen and not currently secured to the wall or dresser. Applicant agreed that they could be secured. The room temperature and upstairs bathroom sink water temperature were measured to be within permitted ranges, at F and 115. F, respectively. Applicant will get a lockbox for client medications and keep it stored in the upper cabinet. Medication logs and client files will be kept locked in the garage storage. The backyard is free of obstruction. There is a small gap under the back fence/wall that a cat or small animal has dug, which applicant agreed to block off. A couple animal droppings observed in the backyard will be removed. Applicant does not have any pets, but there is at least one cat that has come into the backyard previously. There is one camera over the garage door monitoring the front of the house. Footage is viewable from applicant's mobile device, and the monitor records. Applicant agreed to submit a request for a camera waiver. Applicant is seeking a capacity of 6 ambulatory only children ages 5 to 12 years, including applicant's own 2 children. Applicant will not be admitting children with special health care needs and understands the requirements around specialized health care. Applicant and LPA discussed capacity requirements, reporting requirements and to notify LPA if applicant/licensee will be absent from the house for an extended period of time, the caregiver background check bureau (CBCB) and having family members cleared and associated to the facility, prudent parenting policies, labeling of unlabelled food items, storage of client records and medication logs, first aid kit, the camera waiver and camera usage, and posting of license, facility sketch, emergency plan, and personal rights. LPA agreed to send applicant an email with resources for applicant's reference, including links to CCL forms, medication logs, CBCB, and camera waiver instructions. The following will be addressed prior to licensure: 1. The first aid kit will be completed. 2. The client files storage will be obtained/organized. 3. The camera waiver will be obtained. 4. The sketch, emergency plan, and personal rights will be posted in the facility. The anticipated licensure date is 12/01/2020. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report left with applicant Ella Bell, whose signature on this form confirm receipt.

On 12/10/21 at 11AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility for a required annual inspection. LPA met with Licensee Ella Bell and informed of the purpose of the visit. LPA used the CARES Inspection Tool to complete the inspection. The inspection was completed during visit, but a follow-up visit is needed in order to complete the report. The facility was observed to be in safe condition. There is one client in care. Bedrooms have clean linens. Resident in care reported feeling safe and comfortable. LPA observed that staff S1 (See LIC Confidential Names) is not cleared/associated to the facility and has worked in the facility providing care and supervision to client in care. LPA is issuing a citation of California Code of Regulations, Section 80019(e). Per Section 80019(g), LPA is issuing an immediate civil penalty of $100 per violation for a maximum of 5 days, for a total of $500. LPA informed Licensee that S1 cannot work in the facility until the clearance is obtained or transfer of clearance is complete. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee Ella Bell, whose signature on this form confirms receipt. This report has been amended on 12/13/21 to correct the staff reference "S1" typo in the original report.

narrative: Based on confidential interviews, the care team does not have concerns about the incident and does not feel the youth was abandoned. The youth is doing well and improving in licensee's care. Although the allegation(s) may have happened or is/are valid, based on LPA's observations and interviews with residents and staff, there is not a preponderance of the evidence to prove the alleged violation(s) did or did not occur. Therefore, the allegation(s) is/are Unsubstantiated. LPA advises licensee that since the facility is a 24/7 facility, the facility should ensure the ability to respond to notifications pertaining to the youth at all times, especially when the youth has been removed on an emergency basis, in case there is an urgent matter that requires the licensee to take action. See attached LIC 9102. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights provided, and a copy of this report left with Licensee Ella Bell, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.
investigation_findings: 13On 7/1/22, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Mariah Hawkins made a visit to the facility to deliver findings of an investigation of the above allegation. LPA met with Caretaker Judy Bell and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on confidential interviews and record review, the licensee had been informed by emergency personnel when the youth was transported by ambulance for a psychiatric hold, which caregivers do not typically join, that youth would be held overnight to be assessed, which is standard procedure for psychiatric holds. Due to this, licensee had not expected to be called in the middle of the night to pick up the youth, and assistant caregivers had been granted time off to rest after the escalated event, which was the first of this level for this youth. Licensee was initially unresponsive due to being asleep and unaware of the situation, and it appeared that the hospital did not conduct a full psychiatric evaluation or provide the youth with their prescribed psychotropic medication, but licensee did pick up the youth in the morning without issue while still ensuring care for the other children in licensee's care. narrative: On 09/3/24 at 10:30am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Kristin Pierotti conducted a case management visit in order to discuss an incident report that was received. LPA met with Licensee and informed of the purpose of the visit. Based on record reviews, LPA observed that a manual restraint was used on a client. The facility's Program Statement does not state that manual restraints will be utilized. LPA also observed that staff are not trained in the use of manual restraints. LPA is issuing a citation of Interim Licensing Standards (ILS) Section 87022(f). See attached LIC 809-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights were provided, and a copy of this report was given to Licensee, whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Intellectual and developmental disabilities is a disability characterized by significant limitations both in general intellectual function resulting in, or associated with, deficits or impairments in adaptive behavior. The disability must manifest before age 18. Persons with closely related conditions refers to individuals who have a severe, chronic disability that meets ALL of the following conditions: a. is attributable to cerebral palsy, epilepsy; or any other condition, other than mental illness, found to be closely related to intellectual and developmental disabilities because this condition results in impairment of general intellectual functioning or adaptive behavior similar to that of mentally retarded persons, and requires treatment or services similar to those required for these persons." The facility is accepting clients who do not meet the criteria that is stated in the Plan of Operation. The preponderance of evidence standard has been met, and therefore the above allegation(s) are found to be substantiated. This is a violation of Title The facility is being issued a citation on the attached page LIC 9099-D. An exit interview was conducted, appeal rights discussed, and a copy of this report was left with Licensee whose signature on this form confirms receipt.

Licensee stated that the client has their own private room and does not share with clients or staff. LPA reviewed documentation for the client and found that the client does have a medical condition which requires close monitoring. Licensee stated that they would request an updated copy from the client's physician that pertains to the need for close supervision. There are no deficiencies at this time. LPA conducted an exit interview and a copy of this report was left with Marshe Neal, whose signature confirms receipt.

On September 5, 2025, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Embrace Samshi Home Small Family Home (SFH) for a pre-licensing inspection for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Lucy Gitonga who led a tour of the entire home inside and out. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant is applying to serve four clients (two ambulatory and two non-ambulatory) ages 0-17 years old. The home is a two-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. The downstairs consisted of a entry way with a formal living room, a kitchen with a fully stocked refrigerator and pantry storing perishable and non- perishable foods. There was also fire extinguisher #1 that was operable, a first aid kit with all required elements, a locked cabinet storing knives/sharp objects, a locked cabinet for medications and a locked sink cabinet storing cleaning supplies. There was a dining table with adequate seating and a family room with couches and a TV. Bedroom #1 was also downstairs and was utilized for two non-ambulatory clients that was fully furnished and had two twin size beds, dresser/ closet space, and a sliding door exit way leading to the side yard gate. The trash can in the bedroom needed a tight fitting lid and the bedroom was vacant. Bathroom #1 had a walk in shower, a sink and toilet but was missing a trash can with a tight fitting lid. Hot water temperature was measuring 105.2 degrees Fahrenheit. There was a hallway storage closet storing coats and jackets. The upstairs consisted of a loft with couches, TV, work out station for age appropriate client use, and a desk with locked file cabinets storing client files and staff records. However, there was a missing lock box for clients cash resources. Fire extinguisher #2 was in the hallway and was operable. Bathroom #2 had a walk in shower, a sink, toilet, and a trash can with a lid. There was a storage closet with extra towels and wash clothes. Bedroom #2 was a guest bedroom that had a queen size bed and was fully furnished. Bedroom #3 was for applicants biological son and had a queen size bed and was fully furnished. The laundry room was accessible to clients but had a locked closet storing laundry detergents, laundry essentials and extra linen/ blankets. The trash can in the laundry room was missing a tight fitting lid. Bedroom #4 was utilized for two foster children and was fully furnished with two twin size beds, dresser/ closet space, all required bedding, and lighting. The bedroom was currently vacant and needed a trash can with a tight fitting lid. Bedroom #5 was the master bedroom for applicant that will be locked at all times it was fully furnished and had a crib with all required bedding and bathroom #3 that was fully functioning. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked and are working properly. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced, free of hazards and had two side yard gates, each with a latch. There were no pools or other bodies of water and no weapons/firearms as stated by applicant. There was a land- line telephone service and all appliances were in working order. The garage stored an extra deep freezer with frozen goods and extra house hold items, clients to be supervised when in the garage. Based on this inspection of the home, the facility will need the following corrections: Four trash cans to have tight fitting lids/ covers A lock box for storing clients cash resources After corrections are completed, the applicant will notify LPA so that another inspection can be completed. Component III orientation was also completed this day of September 5th, 2025. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was provided to applicant Lucy Gitonga.

On September 24, 2021 at approximately 9: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Raymond Wu conducted an announced pre-licensing inspection at the above address. Upon arrival, LPA met with Esther Wanyoike, Applicant. Together they toured both the external and internal areas of the home. The following was observed at the time of inspection: Physical Plant This facility is a two-story townhouse located in a quiet residential community. The facility consists of 2 bedrooms, 1.5 bathrooms, living room, kitchen, dining room, 2-car garage, and patio. Overall, the facility is clean, sanitary and in excellent condition. Passageways are free from obstruction. The residential community has a swimming pool that is for communal use that is approximately 500 feet away from the home and is gated/secured. Knives and sharps are kept locked and secured in the kitchen drawer while disinfectants and cleaning solutions are kept locked and secured in cabinets inside the garage. Drawers and cabinets have child locks throughout the home. Per applicant, there are no firearms on the premises. The facility has a centralized heat and air-conditioning unit. Temperatures throughout the home during the inspection was comfortable. Carbon monoxide and smoke alarms were tested and observed to be operational. Per local fire department instructions, the home has one fire extinguisher upstairs and one downstairs. The home has a working telephone that is available for client use. A fire inspection was conducted by the Ontario Fire Department on 07/01/21 and a fire clearance was granted for ambulatory clients. Fixtures, Furniture, Equipment, and Supplies The home has two toilets, two wash basins, and one shower/bath for clients' use. LPA observed adequate hygiene supplies including but not limited to shampoo, soap, toothbrush, toothpaste, and toilet paper. Client bedroom was observed to be clean, orderly, and contained one full-size bed and one crib. LPA observed clean pillows, pillow cases, bed sheets and blankets. LPA advised that as future clients outgrow cribs, they will need to have their own bed and cannot share with other clients. Client bedroom has adequate closet and drawer space to accommodate client's clothing and personal belongings. Heath Related Services and Record Keeping Medications, client and staff records will be centrally stored and locked in a cabinet by the kitchen. The first aid kit is readily available in a central location. The kit contains all required supplies. LPA also conducted Component III - Category Specific Orientation with the applicant. The following items were discussed: - Continuing Requirements (General Licensing Requirements & Small Family Home regulations) - Buildings and Grounds requirements - Personnel Records (forms) - Client Records (forms) - Other administrative forms No deficiencies were observed no this date. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this form was emailed to the Applicant.

On March 04, 2024 at 11: A.M. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Stephannie Verna made an announced pre-licensing inspection at the facility and met with Esther Wambui Kiiru, Licensee, who assisted LPA with the inspection. LPA inspected the facility's interior and exterior building and grounds. The facility is comprised of four bedrooms and three bathrooms. There are three client bedrooms, and the licensee has the ability to provide bedroom accommodations to meet the requirements related to the license capacity and client special health needs. At this time, there are no clients in care, however pending placement of a client into the facility, the licensee is prepared to provide care and has the following maintained at the facility: a locked and secure location for cash resources to be entrusted to Licensee; a secure location and process for locking and maintaining medication in a centrally stored location; and maintaining a separate client records for each client to ensure the confidentiality of the records maintained. The facility has no swimming pool or bodies of water on the property, and no use of security recording cameras in private areas. A few fence posts were observed to be missing from the backyard fence, due to a storm. The licensee filed a claim with their home insurance company and is in the process of repairing the backyard fence. The facility was observed to be clean, sanitary, and in good repair; and no deficiencies were observed. continued on 809-c LPA reviewed the Licensee's personnel record, and observed all required documentation present, and filed, including documentation pertaining to criminal record clearance, mandated reporter statement, and current (RN) Nursing License and CPR and First Aid Certification. LPA completed Component Three of the licensing process with the Licensee. The Licensee will keep in communication about placement of clients into the facility, and will submit required documentation to the Department as required, including Incident Reports and LIC 500, Employee Rosters. An exit interview was conducted with Esther Wambui Kiiru, Licensee, and a copy of this report was provided to them.

On 09/09/ Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Elena Gonzalez-Soto and Jean Stidman arrived at the facility for a case management inspection. LPAs met with Licensee, Esther Wambui. At the beginning of the inspection, LPAs observed two staff and two children present in the facility. At the of the inspection LPAs observed one more child arrive. LPAs conducted an inspection of the home and observed two fire extinguishers with no dates of purchase or service, one dresser in one child's room with exposed screws, a camera placed in one child's bedroom, one staff's personal items in a child's bedroom, LPAs observed one staff was present and working in the facility without a criminal record clearance. LPAs observed a wading pool filled with water and exposed extension cords throughout the backyard. LPAs conducted a file review of three staff and four children's records. Facility Citation Violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, Buildings and Grounds, 83010.1(a) Limitations on Capacity for Specialized Small Family Homes, and 80019(e) Criminal Record Clearance on the attached D. Exit interview conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights was left with Licensee, Esther Wambui.

780087(a) and (e) Buildings and Grounds	
The facility shall be clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair at all times for the safety and well-being of clients, employees and visitors.
All licensees serving children or serving clients who have physical handicaps, mental disorders, or developmental disabilities shall ensure the inaccessibility of pools, including swimming pools (in-ground and above-ground), fixed-in-place wading pools, hot tubs, spas, fish ponds or similar bodies of water through a pool cover or by surrounding the pool with a fence. narrative: On 10/14/2024 at 10:00 a.m. Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Elena Gonzalez-Soto and Jean Stidman arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced Post-Licensing Inspection. LPAs were greeted by Licensee, Esther Kiiru who assisted with the inspection and file review. LPAs observed the facility is a four-bedroom, three-bathroom two story home. When LPAs arrived two staff and three children were present. During the inspection one child arrived. LPAs inspected the facility inside and outside. LPAs inspected and/or reviewed the following: Client Records: LPA Stidman reviewed three children's files and observed all three were missing written consent forms, an account of cash resources and personal property/valuables, and needs and services plans. Two children's files were missing authorization for psychotropic medications. Two Centrally Stored Medication Logs were incomplete. Staff Records: LPA Gonzalez-Soto reviewed six out six staff files and observed six out of six staff did not have documentation of training requirements. The following items were reviewed for compliance: Guardian Roster, LIC500, copy of LIC400 and original LIC402. Facility Citation Violation of California Code of Regulations, Title 22, Division 6, 83064(a)(2), 83064(h),83064(j)(1) Licensee Duties and Responsibilities, 80070(b) Clients Records, 83070(b)Child's Records, 80075(k)Health-Related Services, 83068.2(a)Needs and Services Plan. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report and appeal rights were left with Licensee, Esther Kiiru.
