narrative: On 10/15/2024 at Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Elena Gonzalez-Soto arrived at the above facility and conducted an unannounced continuation Post-Licensing Inspection. LPA was greeted by Mamadou Bah (S6) and notified LPA that Licensee, Esther Kiiru was on her way home. LPA thanked S6 and waited for Licensee to arrive. Licensee arrived shortly after and assisted LPA with the inspection. When LPA arrived two staff and no children were present. LPA observed the facility is a four bedroom, three bathroom two story home. LPA inspected the facility inside and outside. LPA inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant: Posting of license, Personal Rights, Disinfectants/Cleaning solutions inaccessible, Refrigerator Temperature at or below 45 degrees F, 36 degrees, Freezer Temperature at or below 0 degrees, 0 degrees F, Nonperishable Foods one week and fresh perishable foods for three days, menu present and posted, working telephone, First Aid Kit fully stocked, Common Room available, Dining area (enough seating, furniture good condition, not broke or damaged), Medication centrally stored, locked/inaccessible, Hot Water between 105-120 degree F, 122 degrees, Fire Extinguishers purchased September 2024. Toilets wash basin, bath and shower fixtures in good repair/no leaks/hot water temperature 122 degrees, soap and enough washing rags, Laundry Facilities available, Bedrooms-required linen and furnishings in good repair, Facility free of vermin. Disaster Preparedness: Disaster and mass casualty plan updated and available, quarterly drills conducted and documented, Disaster preparedness supplies verified. LPA interviewed one staff member. One Technical Violation was issued related to CCR 83070.1(d)(4) Children's Records. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was left with Licensee, Esther Kiiru.

On 11/26/2024 at 12:35 p.m. Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Elena Gonzalez-Soto and Maie Soliman arrived unannounced at the Small Family Home (SFH) for the purpose of a Plan of Correction Inspection. LPAs were greeted by Mamadou Bah (S2). S2 called an adult downstairs and LPA introduced themselves. LPA Gonzalez-Soto asked their name and if they are staff. The individual provided their name and said they are staff but later said they are not staff but visiting the SFH. The individual called Mabel Strasser-King, Facility Designee (FD) and notified FD LPAs arrived. LPA Gonzalez-Soto spoke with FD at 12:50 p.m. and asked FD their estimated time of arrival. FD said 20 to 30 minutes. At 1:21 p.m. FD arrived to the SFH and assisted LPAs with the Inspection. LPAs reviewed three children's files for: Needs and Services Plans (NSP), Cash Resources and Valuables Logs, Medication and Administration Logs, and Psychotropic Medication Logs. LPAs observed C1 and C2 have NSPs signed on 11/25/2024. C3 did not have a signed NSP by his discharge date of 11/19/2024. LPAs observed C3 has a signed Consent Form dated 09/19/2024, C1 and C2 have signed Consent Forms dated 10-18-2024. LPAs observed C1, C2, C3 had an account of cash resources and personal property with no dates. LPAs observed C1 and C2 have separate logs for psychotropic medication, but was missing the quantity prescribed, prescription filled, prescription number and number of refills. LPAs observed C1 and C2 did not have court approved JV-220 forms. LPAs reviewed six staff files for: documentation of training on psychotropic medications and administration, Foster Youth Bill of Rights, Reasonable Prudent Parent Standard, Children's right to sexual reproductive health information, Supporting LGBTQ+ Youth in Care and cultural competency. LPAs observed S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, S6 have certificates of completion for Foster Youth Bill of Rights and Reasonable Prudent Parent Standard Training issued on 11/7/2024. Cont. on 809-C. LPAs observed S4 has certificate of completion for Supporting LGBTQ+ Youth in Care issued on 11/13/2024. LPAs observed S1, S2, S3, S5, and S6 did not have certificates of completion for Supporting LGBTQ+ Youth in Care. LPAs observed S5 did not have a certificate of completion for First Aid. S5 is registered for the course to complete first aid on 11/30/2024. LPAs observed S1, S2, S3, S4, S5, and S6 did not have documentation of completed training in psychotropic medication and administration. LPAs observed S1 did not have documentation of training in children's right to receive sexual and reproductive health care and information. LPAs conducted one confidential interview. Due to provider not meeting POC deadline, the SFH is receiving a civil penalty for failure to correct deficiencies of Title 22, Division 6, CCR 83064(h) and (j)(1) Licensee Duties and Responsibilities, 83070(b) Child's Records, 80075(k) Health-Related Services in the amount of 1,200 dollars for the period of 11/15/2024 to 11/26/2024. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report, civil penalty, and appeal rights was issued to Mable Strasser-King, Facility Designee.

On 12/24/2024 at 9:55 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Elena Gonzalez-Soto arrived unannounced at the above facility to conduct a confidential interview related to a complaint investigation. During the investigation, the following documents were gathered and reviewed: Needs and Services Plans, Admission Agreements, and photos Confidential interviews were conducted with three individuals, and attempted with one individual, during the period of 09/05/2024 to 12/24/2024. LPA's interviews conducted with Staff 1, Staff 2, and Reporting Party and records reviewed were inconsistent that the Small Family Home provides lack of care or supervision that resulted in injuries to child in care. Based on LPA interviews conducted, and records reviewed, the preponderance of evidence standard has not been met, therefore the above allegations are found to be UNSUBSTANTIATED. Although the allegation may have happened or is valid, there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove the alleged violations did or did not occur. An exit interview was conducted with and a copy of this report was provided to Esther Wambui, Licensee.

narrative: On 04/02/2025 at 11:00 a.m. Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Elena Gonzalez-Soto arrived at the facility to conduct a required annual inspection. LPA knocked on the door and there was no answer. LPA called Esther Kiiru, Licensee to determine when licensee will be at the facility. Licensee informed LPA they would be at the home soon. Licensee arrived at the facility at 11:20 a.m. Licensee assisted LPA with the inspection. LPAs inspected and/or reviewed the following: Physical Plant: LPA observed the facility is a two-story home with five bedrooms a front yard and a backyard. LPA observed posting of personal rights, working carbon monoxide and smoke detectors, first aid kit, fire extinguisher purchased 9/19/2024, inaccessible cleaning solutions, food menu, appropriate amount of fresh perishable and non-perishable foods, hot water temperature of 120F, Fridge Temperature of 53F, and freezer temperature of 0.7F. Operations: LPA observed register of clients, posting of license, safeguards for client resources and valuables, Disaster plan and drill log, and plan of operation. LPA observed fire clearance but new fire clearance is needed for new addition of a partition in master bedroom. Client Records: LPA reviewed two children's files and observed written consent forms, an account of cash resources and personal property/valuables, immunization records, signed personal rights, and individual education plans. Cont. on 809-C Staff Records: LPA reviewed six staff files and observed six out of six staff had a first aid certificate, criminal record clearance, personnel record, signed employee rights, health clearance, and applicable training. LPA conducted interviews with staff. The following items were reviewed for compliance: Guardian Roster, LIC500, copy of LIC400 and original LIC402. No citations or advisories were issued related to this inspection. An exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report was issued to Ester Kiiru, Licensee.

On June 23, 2021, at 10:27am Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Adrian Mendez conducted an unannounced Post Licensing/Annual Required Inspection of the small family home. LPA met with Licensee Pamela Salaguinto. The facility was toured inside and out. The home is a four bedroom and three bathroom home. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The First Aid Kit contained all required supplies and is stored in the kitchen and bathrooms of the facility. The clients' medications were observed to be inaccessible and stored in a lockbox in the kitchen of the home. The small family home's smoke and carbon monoxide detector was checked and were operable. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom sink was measured at 10:43am to be 115.3, which is within regulatory requirements. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no swimming pool/bodies of water located on the premises. The facility currently has no clients placed. One staff/licensee file was reviewed during the inspection. The file appeared to be completed and in order. All staff that work at the facility have Department of Justice and Child Abuse Clearance Index clearances. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews on this date, there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Licensee Pamela Salaguinto.

narrative: On November 8, 2022 at 10:30 am, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Charmaine Linley arrived unannounced at the facility for a required annual inspection of the small family home. LPA met with Licensee's sister, Melody Quijano. Upon arrival, LPA was informed by Ms. Quijano the facility would not be interested in continuing with their license. LPA advised Ms. Quijano if the facility did not want to continue with the annual inspection, the facility could surrender their license, and send an email to LPA. Ms. Quijano consulted with the licensee and decided to continue with the annual inspection at this time. At 11:15am, LPA entered the facility. The facility was toured inside and out. The home is a four bedroom and three bathroom home. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there were no beds in the bedroom. There were no clients placed at this time. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The First Aid Kit contained all required supplies and is stored in the kitchen of the facility. The small family home's smoke and carbon monoxide detector was checked and were not operable, as they are chirping. The bathrooms were clean and in good repair. The hot water in the client bathroom sink was measured at 109.4 at 11:30 am, which is within regulatory requirements. The hot water in the kitchen sink was measured at 109.7 at 11:31 am which is within regulatory requirements. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. There is no swimming pool/bodies of water located on the premises. The facility currently has no clients placed. The licensee has all of the staff files and fire clearance with them and are not in the facility LPA could not review staff files in the facility at this time. A review of administrative records indicate that the facility has paid their current licensing fees. Ms. Quijano was advised LPA will need to return to check the bedroom, staff files, and smoke detectors before the facility accepts any children into the facility. Based on the facility inspection , there are no deficiencies found at this time. A copy of this report was reviewed and provided to Licensee Pamela Salaguinto.

On this day Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Cynthia Galindo met with Licensee Katherine McDonell via Zoom, due to COVID-19 restrictions. The purpose for this Case Management is in regards to the death of a client (see 811 for confidential names). On behalf of Community Care Licensing, LPA gave condolences to the licensee and staff for their recent loss. Client was admitted the hospital on 11/13/20 and was discharged on 11/19/2020. Client was once again admitted to the ER on 11/28/2020. Doctors were trying to stabilize her condition but unfortunately, client's condition was too fragile and passed away on 11/29/2020. Licensee has requested a copy of the death certificate. The facility is expecting a copy within the week. LPA requested copies of client's recent medical progress notes along admission agreement and legal guardianship information. There are no deficiencies to be cited on this date. Due to Covid-19 requirements, this report is being emailed to the facility for a signature and a scan back to CCL on this date.

investigation_findings: 13On October 29, 2021, at 1: PM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA), Babatunde Aborchie arrived at Evelyna's Small Family Home (SFH) to deliver the finding of the investigation involving the small family home and a foster child (FC1). LPA met with a staff (S1) who granted LPA access into the home. On July 20, 2021 a complaint report was referred to Community Care Licensing (CCL) alleging that lack of supervision resulting in foster children engaging in a physical altercation, foster child is kept in bedroom for a long period of time and adult in home made an inappropriate comment towards a foster child. On July 26, 2021 at 1: PM, LPA conducted a safety inspection with S1. There were no immediate safety hazards observed at the time of inspection. LPA reviewed the children's file and obtained copies. During the investigation, LPA conducted interviews with the foster mother (FM), foster children (FC1, FC2, FC3, FC4) and S1. All confidential interviews denied being kept in the bedroom for a long period of time, staff or FM conduct room visit hourly on the average. narrative: On February 10, 2022 at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie, met with staff Sarah Arungah, who led a tour of the home. The purpose of the visit was to conduct an annual inspection of the Evelyna's Small Family Home. The facility was toured inside and out with the staff. Currently, there were four foster children in the home. FC1, FC2, FC3 and FC The home is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 has a queen size bed, used as a guest room. It sleeps currently one live in staff. · Bedroom #2 has two full beds, sleeps one client (FC2). · Bedroom #3 has one full and one twin beds, sleeps one clients (FC3) · Bedroom #4 has one twin bed; sleeps one client (FC1) · Bedroom #5 has a king-sized bed, sleeps licensee and one client on a crib, a month-old baby (FC4) . Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room and there is one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There were adequate drawers and closet space for children's belongings. The fireplace was properly screened. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. Cleansers/chemicals were stored and locked in the laundry room cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in locked kitchen cabinet. The first aid kit was in the locked closet between the hallway and the living room. There were no guns or weapons as stated by staff at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be within regulatory requirements. Proper storage of all food was noted. Trash cans for storage of solid wastes had tight fitting lids. The smoke detectors located in the hallways were tested and were in good working order. The carbon monoxide detector located downstairs was operable. The Emergency Disaster Plan with exit map, Title Personal Rights, and visitation policies are posted at this time. The backyard where children will have access to play is completely fenced and free of hazards. There were no bodies of water on the premises. A review of staff records on this date indicated that all facility staff had received criminal record and child abuse index check clearances. In accordance with Title 22, Division 6, Chapters 1 & 4 there were no deficiencies being cited at this time. Exit interview was conducted and a copy of this report along with a Confidential Names List (LIC 811) was provided to facility staff.

On December 15, 2023 at 03: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Babatunde Aborchie began a Pre-Licensing inspection for a Small Family Home relocation license. LPA met with applicant Sarah Arunga Bland who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. The applicant is applying for a relocation and to serve 6 ambulatory clients. The home consists of: Downstairs: Bedroom #1, It was furnished with a full-sized bed and a crib. It was vacant. There were also an office, a visitor lounge, a family room, a living room, two dining areas, a pantry, a kitchen and one bathroom. Upstairs: Bedroom #2, The room was furnished with two full-sized beds. It was vacant. Bedroom #3, The room was furnished with two twin sized beds. It was vacant. Bedroom #4, The room was furnished with two twin sized beds. It was vacant. Bedroom #5, Master bedroom. The room consisted of one king sized bed. It sleeps the applicant/Licensee. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The smoke detectors were checked and were working properly. Inside the facility the fireplace was properly screened. Telephone service and appliances were in a working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where children will have access. The medication will be locked in the kitchen cabinet area by the pantry. Cleansers/chemicals were locked and stored in the laundry room cabinet. Sharp knives were inaccessible and stored in a locked kitchen cabinet under the sink. There were no guns or weapons as stated by the applicant at this time. The hot water temperature was tested and noted to be 111 degrees. Proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste have tight fitting lids. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the hallway closet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The Facility Sketch, Emergency Disaster Plan, visitation policy and Personal Rights were posted. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for relocation will be forwarded to the Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to Applicant/Licensee.

***Continued from LIC 9099-C*** . A confidential interview denied the incident occurred. Another confidential interview stated children are not allowed in each other's rooms, and the foster children are always monitored. A confidential interview said, "Nothing is happening in this home." A confidential interview disclosed that no relative of the Licensee lives in the home. During another confidential interview, it was stated that none of the foster children in the house ever reported being touched or spoken to inappropriately. Based on confidential interviews, the allegation that facility staff did not provide adequate supervision resulting in inappropriate interaction between minors (unknown and FC1) in care, resulting in a foster child (FC1) being touched and spoken to inappropriately, is unsubstantiated. The allegations may have happened or be valid, but there is not a preponderance of evidence to prove that the alleged violations occurred. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report and appeal rights were explained and given to Licensee Sarah Bland.

On May 09, 2024, at 10: AM, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Rafael Enriquez began a pre-licensing inspection and component III for Evelyna's Small Family Home 2 for an initial license. LPA met with applicant Evelyn Oyombera who led a tour of the home. The facility was toured both inside and out with the applicant. Currently there are no children placed in the home. The applicant was approved to serve six children ages 0 to 17. The home is a single-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 sleeps a caregiver, has a bed and a crib. · Bedroom #2 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #3 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #4 will sleep two foster children, has two beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #5 sleeps the applicant, has a California King bed, a crib, has a bathroom and a walk-in closet. · A formal living room, formal dining room, living room, kitchen with dining area, two storage rooms, three bathrooms, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room. Bedrooms were arranged so that no more than two children share a room, and there was one child per bed. No room commonly used for other purposes is used as a bedroom, and no bedroom serves as a passageway to another room. There was adequate drawer and closet space for children's belongings. The smoke detectors and carbon monoxide detectors were checked, and they were working properly. Telephone service and appliances were in working order. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients/children will have access. Sharp knives and sharp objects were locked in a cabinet in the kitchen. Cleansers/chemicals were inaccessible and stored in laundry room which has a lock on the door. There was adequate food storage space and a supply of three days of perishable foods and a week of non-perishable food. A proper storage of all food was discussed. Trash cans for storage of solid waste had tight fitting lids. The water temperature was observed to be at 112.6 degrees. First Aid kit was accessible with all required items, and it was in the hallway closet. A Fire extinguisher was observed and properly charged. The fireplace was in the living room area, and it was properly screened. All the appropriate forms were posted in view of facility clients. As stated by applicant, there were no weapons/firearms and there were no pools or other bodies of water. The backyard where children will have access to play was completely fenced and free of hazards. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. The request for licensure will be forwarded to Licensing Program Manager for final approval. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to applicant Evelyn Oyombera.

On June 21, 2024, at 09: AM, a post-licensing inspection was conducted by Licensing Program Analysts (LPAs) Rafael Enriquez and Maryjane Perez. LPAs met with licensee Evelyn Oyombera. During this inspection, LPAs and licensee inspected the facility inside and out. The home is a single-story building with five bedrooms and three bathrooms which is set up as follows: · Bedroom #1 sleeps a caregiver, has a twin sized bed and a crib. · Bedroom #2 will sleep two foster children, has two full sized beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #3 will sleep two foster children, has two full sized beds. It sleeps one foster child. · Bedroom #4 will sleep two foster children, has two twin sized beds. It was vacant. · Bedroom #5 sleeps the applicant, has a California King bed, has a bathroom and a walk-in closet. · A formal living room, formal dining room, living room, kitchen with dining area, two storage rooms, three bathrooms, three car garage, backyard, and a laundry room. The Small Family Home (SFH) is operating within capacity/limitation, is clean, safe, sanitary and in good repair, the outdoor area is free of safety hazards, no pool, or other bodies of water on premise. The SFH has adequate supply of perishable and nonperishable foods, chemicals are locked in the laundry room in a locked cabinet. The knives are locked underneath the sink cabinet. The water temperature was measures at 113.9 degrees. Medications are stored in a locked hallway storage closet. The disaster plan, personal rights, and other documentation are properly posted, smoke detectors are operable/tested. There are no firearms or dangerous weapons per licensee. First aid kit is maintained, and complete First Aid certifications are current. All adults subject to background checks are cleared. There are no deficiencies to be cited at this time. An exit interview was conducted. A copy of this report was provided to licensee Evelyn Oyombera.

On January 23, Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Maryjane Perez arrived at Evelynas Small Family Home 2 to initiate a complaint investigation. Based on LPA's observation, the facility is cited for violation of the California Code of Regulations, Title Division Six, regulation 80054(b) Penalties: Notwithstanding Section 80054(a) above, an immediate penalty of $100 per cited violation per day for a maximum of five (5) days shall be assessed if any individual required to be fingerprinted under Health and Safety Code Section 1522(b) has not obtained a California clearance or a criminal record exemption, requested a transfer of a criminal record clearance or requested and be approved for a transfer of an exemption as specified in Section 80019(e) prior to working, residing or volunteering in the facility. narrative: On Thursday January 27 2022 at 08: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Linda Haynes conducted an annual inspection of the facility. At time of inspection LPA met with Licensee Mona Skinner. The facility was toured inside and out with Licensee Mona Skinner. The home is a one-story residence with five bedrooms and three bathrooms. No client was present at time of inspection. Bedrooms are arranged so that no more than two clients are in a room, and there is one client per bed. There is adequate shelf and closet space for client's belongings. The bathroom was clean and in good repair. The hot water in the clients bathroom was measured to be 115.6 degrees the clients do not have access to the other bathrooms in the home. All hazardous items have been properly made inaccessible to areas where clients will have access. The medications were stored and locked in a cabinet in the kitchen with a lock box in the refrigerator for refrigerated medications. Cleansers/chemicals are locked and stored in the cabinet under the kitchen sink. Sharp knives are inaccessible and stored in a cabinet above the stove which the clients cannot reach. The First Aid Kit is located in the kitchen and contained all required supplies. The facility's smoke detectors in each bedroom were checked and were operable. The carbon monoxide detector is located in the hall way and was operable. There are no guns or weapons in the facility as stated by Licensee Mona SKinner. LPA observed a minimum 7-day non-perishable and a 2-day perishable supply of food. There was a variety of snacks available for clients as well. The following required posted items were observed accessible to clients: Grievance Procedures, Personal Rights, Visitation policies, and current menu. The facility outside grounds was also inspected and it was observed to be clean and well maintained. Emergency exits were free from obstruction. The pool was surround by a five foot tall wrought iron fence with a gate that closes by it self and can be locked to make it inaccessible to clients. A sample of client files were reviewed during the inspection and noted to have documents required per regulations in file. There were no clients present at time of inspection to be interviewed. The Licensee does not have staff. The licensee needs to have her CPR and first aid card renewed as it is expired. Based on the facility inspection and file reviews this date, there was one deficiency found at this time. A copy of this report and LIC 809-D was reviewed and given to Licensee Mona Skinner.

narrative: Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with Mr. Harrison to conduct the pre-licensing inspection. The following was observed. This is single family home located in the City of Gardena, CA. There are three bedrooms and two bathrooms. There are no bodies of water on the premises and no security bars on windows and windows are operational. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher in the kitchen area. There are smoke detectors in each bedroom and a combination smoke/carbon monoxide detector in the hallway. There is locked storage space for medications, knives and household chemicals. The kitchen and bathroom areas are in good condition. Stove and refrigerator are in good working condition. All trash cans are covered. Hot water tested at 115 degrees. There is a living room area/dining area with a dining table and 4 chairs, a sofa and love seat, coffee table and TV. There is a separate laundry room and an unused garage. Backyard area is free of visible hazards. Bedrooms are assigned as follows: Bedroom number 1 is reserved for two clients. It has two twin beds. It has closet and drawer space adequate for two. There is a smoke detector in the room There are no security bars on the windows. Bedroom number 2 is reserved for one client. It has a full size bed and drawer space. However there is no closet. There is a smoke detector in the room There are no security bars on the windows. Bedroom number 3 is used by the applicant. It has one queen sized bed and a master bathroom. There are no security bars on window. LPA observed two first aid kits in the home. LPA Jones-Steward observed that Mr. Harrison has an LIC 503 completed by a medical doctor and that he is in the process of revising the Program Statement and the LIC 500. LPA advised Mr. Harrison that the following actions are necessary: Submit revised Program Statement, LIC 500 and LIC 503 to the Department Obtain a set of tweezers and a first manual for the first aid kit Obtain a portable closet for bedroom # Mr. Harrison was advised that if he wishes to convert the unused garage to a play area, another fire clearance will be needed. Review of the application will continue when the above requested actions have been taken. Applicant may present photographic proof that tweezers and portable closet have been obtained.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with applicant Willie Harrison, Jr. and his assistant Janice Harrison for the purpose of conducting the Component II, face-to-face meeting. The following areas were discussed during the meeting: Licensee Duties and Responsibilities, Personnel Requirements, Needs and Services Plans, Buildings and Grounds, Fixture, Furniture, Equipment and Supplies, and Applicant Qualifications. An overview of the regulations was provided and Mr. Harrison was advised on how to locate and familiarize himself with both the Small Family Home Regulations and the General Regulation LPA Jones-Steward received from the applicant and reviewed with applicant the following updated documents: LIC, 200, LIC 215, LIC 503, LIC 402, LIC 500, House Rules and Sample Menu. The requirements for background clearances and health screenings for all staff were discussed.. LPA Jones-Steward advised applicant that additional follow-up is needed to verify the authority of the person who signed the LIC 503. The pre-licensing walk through was scheduled for August 24, 2023 at 1: PM. LPA Jones-Steward advised Mr. Harrison on how to prepare for the walk-through.

Licensing Program Analyst Connie Jones-Steward met with applicant Willie Harrison, Jr. to conduct the Component III meeting of the application process. LPA and applicant discussed the both general and category specific forms. Applicant was given copies of the forms that are necessary to run a Small Family Home. Progress on the corrections listed during the pre-licensing visit was also reviewed. LPA observed that applicant has obtained the tweezers, first aid manual and portable closet as required. Applicant is in the process of reformatting the program statement. Applicant submitted updated LIC 500 and LIC 503. Application review will continue when the re-formatted program statement is received. LPA collected orientation certificate to be returned to applicant upon application approval.

Licensing Program Analysts Connie Jones-Steward and Reagan Cohen met with Mr. Harrison to conduct a case management inspection. The purpose was to verify that staff are being trained as required by Title 22 80065(f)(3) & 83065. LPAs reviewed the files of all employees and did not find proof of training. Mr. Harrison stated that he has certificated to prove that staff have taken DSP I & II training. He states that staff also have training from contracted behaviorist Mark Hurrell. LPA Jones-Steward requested that proof of trainings be emailed to the Department by November 4, 2024. There is a training in Crisis Intervention Essentials scheduled for November 13, 2024. The seminar was suggested by the WRAP team and will be conducted online by UMASS Global. Mr. Harrison will submit proof of the trainings to Regan Cohen via email. LPA Jones-Steward also reviewed employee schedule revisions with Mr. Harrison and asked that an updated LIC 500 be sent to Reagan Cohen by November 4th, 2024. Exit Interview was conducted.

On 2/7/25 at 9: AM Licensing Program Analyst (LPA) Reagan Cohen and Licensing Program Manager (LPM) Lakescia Smith made an unannounced visit to Family Life Small Family Home for the purpose of an annual/Random inspection. LPA and LPM met with Albert and Administrator Willie Harrison arrived after. A tour of the home was conducted. The facility is licensed to provide care and supervision services for three (3) children, ages 3-17 years old, ambulatory only. The census today is two (2) and living in the home currently are the Licensee, Adult 1, and 2 clients ages 13 &11. The facility is set up as follows: There are three bedrooms and two bathrooms. There are no bodies of water on the premises and no security bars on windows and windows are operational. There is a fully charged fire extinguisher in the kitchen area. There are smoke detectors in each bedroom and a combination smoke/carbon monoxide detector in the hallway. Living Room/Dinning Area: There is a living room area/dining area with a dining table and 4 chairs, a sofa and love seat, coffee table and TV. Kitchen: has a four (4) burner gas stove/oven (all burners were operational during the inspection), and a refrigerator /freezer. Sharp knives are located under the sink in a locked cabinet. Cleaning supplies and disinfectants are kept under the kitchen sink in a locked cabinet and made inaccessible to children in care. The kitchen has an exit door leading to the backyard. Laundry area: is located off the house in the backyard and is equipped with a washer and a dryer. Backyard: a spacious area with a basketball hoop, clear of debris. LPM noticed a crawl space to beneath the house in the backyard that Licensee will ensure remains inaccessible to clients. Detached garage: remains locked at all times and LPA observed the garage to be used for storage. Bedroom #1: is reserved for two clients. It has two twin beds. It has closet and drawer space adequate for two. There is a smoke detector in the room. There are no security bars on the windows. There is a television, working lights, and two windows. Bedroom #2: is reserved for one client. It has a full size bed and drawer space, there is also a dresser. There is a smoke detector in the room There are no security bars on the windows. The room contains working lights and windows. Report continued on LIC 809C Bedroom #3: is occupied by Licensee and Adult 1. The room is furnished with a queen size bed, dresser, television, a working light, windows, and a closet. The closet contains personal belongings. (2) Bathrooms: one bathroom is located along the hallway, and the second bathroom is located inside bedroom #3. The bathrooms contain a toilet, sink, and a shower. The hot water was tested and found to be with 105-120 (F). The hallway has a cabinet which store extra linen. The smoke and carbon monoxide detectors were tested and found to be in working order. Medications are stored in a locked box inside a kitchen cabinet and made inaccessible to children in care. The home has a working telephone readily accessible to children in care. The First Aid Kit was checked and found to be complete. LPA observed the home to be clean, safe, and sanitary. Passageways, stairways, inclines, ramps and open porches are unobstructed. The front and backyard were clean and free of debris. There are no bodies of water located on the premises. Licensees ensure that children in placement are accorded personal rights and the corresponding form is in their file. Children are supported and encouraged to participate in extracurricular activities. Children are allowed and encouraged to contact the licensing agency, in confidence, without threats or punishment for making complaints. Children are accorded dignity in personal relationships with others in the home. LPA reiterated the importance of submitting Special Incident Reports and reporting all changes within the facility to Community Care Licensing and any other appropriate agency. All posting requirements for Small Family Home Licensor and Emergency Plan were met. LPA reviewed the following records during the inspection: Client Records: The home currently has a total of two (2) clients. LPA reviewed the client's records and found the Needs and Services Plan and Pre Appraisal Plan missing for one client. LPA also found the Personal Rights incomplete for one client. LPA found the TB test missing for both clients. LPA instructed Licensee to contact the clients social workers to receive the required information and update the clients files ASAP. Emergency and Disaster Plan: LPA reviewed facility Emergency and Disaster Plan. LPA reviewd the disaster drills for the facility. LPA recived a copy of the facility staff and client rosters. An exit Interview was conducted, and a copy of this report was left with the Licensee, Willie Harrison.
